talk.start.para: âOrder! Pursuant to order, I call on matters of public interest.

âToday I conclude a series of speeches relating to the future of regional Australia. I will start by stressing what I said earlier this year on Wednesday, 25 August, which was that the big challenge for rural and regional Australia, particularly given the opening up of the economy and the move towards deregulation and globalisation, is to come up with effective strategies to assist the bush to survive in the new global environment.

speech.para: I would also like to re-endorse the findings of the McKinsey report of 1994, which outlined the direction that should be taken in rural and regional Australia. The principles of that report were basically that leadership was vital at the business and regional level and that the role of government had to shift from being a doer and director to being a change leader in a region's economic development. The essence of these processes is to engender and maintain in regional leaders a self-help attitude. The vital question that remains, therefore, is this: how to empower our rural and regional communities to leverage their own future development.

I am proud to say that the Howard government is in fact the first government in the history of this country to call a regional summit to discuss the implications of this very basic question, particularly for government policy. That summit occurred from 27 to 29 October in Parliament House in Canberra this year. There were 282 delegates from the community and from government and business. They met over a three-day period to discuss problems and opportunities for regional Australia.

The Prime Minister gave the keynote address and expressed his commitment to a whole of government approach for `a better understanding of areas where we can make a difference and where we can make a contribution'. He emphasised the notion of a social coalition at the heart of the regional summit. This is about encouraging coalitions or partnerships between government, business and communities to find realistic solutions to the challenges faced by rural, regional and remote Australia.

The Deputy Prime Minister illustrated how the partnership could work in practice by using the example of call centres and going through the process of how they can be established in regional centres rather than in capital cities. Firstly, governments at both the federal and state levels need to provide the necessary infrastructure and services so that modern telecommunications services can be put in place. Secondly, there has to be a commercial commitment from business by promoting the placement of call centres in country communities of an adequate size. Thirdly, the local communityâstarting with the local councilsâhas to ensure that the required skills are, and continue to be, available within the local work force. This cameo is a very good illustration of how the recommendations of the McKinsey report would work in a practical way through partnership between the community, business and government.

At the regional summit there were over 30 key speakers from communities, business and industry. There was a reference group of six, which was chaired by the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, and there were 12 expert facilitators assisting working groups that were structured around the 12 key themes of the summit. These themes were communications; infrastructure; health; community wellbeing and lifestyle; governmentâlocal, state and federal rolesâfinancing and facilitating entrepreneurship; value adding to regional communities and farming industries; new industries and new opportunities; community and industry leadership; education and training; philanthropy and partnerships; and sustainable resource management. Some inescapable facts came through the summit process. Bringing together the findings of those 12 groups, the overwhelming conclusion was, of course, that we live in times of very rapid globalisation, that technology is going through an almost daily revolution and that, therefore, the future certainly is not what it used to beâas was stated by one of the participants.

Significant demographic trends have emerged in rural and regional Australia over recent years, and many of these are disturbing in nature. One is the coastal drift, where a very large proportion of faster growing municipalities and smaller towns are located on the eastern seaboard and south-west coastal areas of Australia. The second is the rise of `sponge cities'. In increasing parts of Australia, there are regional sponge cities like Toowoomba in Queensland, Wagga in New South Walesâ

talk.start.para: âWhat is a sponge city?

âSenator, I will tell you in a minute. The third one I was going to quote is Horsham in Victoriaâwhich I am sure you are well familiar with, Senator Patterson. A sponge city occurs where the regional centre grows and the towns and villages in the surrounding districts decline. It is a phenomenon that is typical right across Australia and is perhaps our greatest challenge in rural and regional policy. To take a New South Wales example, Dubbo's population has risen by 53 per cent from 1976 to 1997âup by half in just over 20 yearsâbut this has been at the expense of the surrounding municipalities: in Warren, the population is down by 15.8 per cent over a similar period; in Coolah, down by 13.5 per cent; in Coonabarabran, down by 6.9 per cent; and in Wellington, down by seven per cent.

speech.para: We have a picture in rural and regional Australia where the small centres are becoming smaller but the bigger regional centres are becoming larger. The total drift is not all into the big cities, such as Sydney, completely: it is also into these bigger towns which, particularly in New South Wales, are doing quite well. It is the ones at the next level down, such as Coonabarabran, that are not doing well; and that is where our challenge is.

The next rather disturbing trend is the age profile. The summit showed three essential things happening here. Young adults in the 15 to 34 age group are still moving to the city for work, education and training opportunities. Older and retired adults over 65 keep moving out of regional rural areas and into the bigger towns or to the city for better access to health care as well as leisure facilities. The third trendâand this is perhaps a hopeful trend in many regional areasâis that the adults in the 35 to 64 age group are gradually being drawn back into the country areas to raise their families and take advantage of a perceived better rural lifestyle. KPMG Consulting's Population growth report for 1999 estimates that in the last 22 years some 200 rural shires in Australia have lost population. At a state level, Victoria, for example, has lost about one-third of its rural residents since 1982, with knock-on effects for services like banks and schools and a lingering sense of alienation in the regions.

The core message that came out of the summit, and formally endorsed in its communique, was that there are no magic bullets or quick fixes, particularly given the constant changes in the global economy and technology. Communities that have committed themselves to identifying and capitalising on their natural strengths, resources and assets have been the ones to successfully reinvent themselves. Regional communities that are very keen to include and invest in their youth are the ones that are often committed to working in partnerships with government and business at all levels; they want to resource the necessary skills, learning, education and training to develop their younger adults.

The communique statement said that governments must accept responsibility for facilitating adequate provision and maintenance of basic infrastructure and that regional Australians ought to have more equitable access to essential services, including telecommunications, power, energy, water, transport, health and education. Above all, regional, rural and remote Australians want to shape their own futures on a journey in partnership with business and government at their own local level. They are unanimous in not wanting a top down or a one size fits all approach from the big smoke.

John Anderson, the Deputy Prime Minister, summed up the mood of the summit for a bottom-up approach, as well as the practical realities facing Australia in the new millennium, when he said in his closing speech on Friday, 29 October 1999, that:
. . . the political mantra of the new Century will be, "It's local stupid" rather than "It's the economy stupid'.

talk.start.para: âYesterday, the government tabled the final Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, now the Australian Transport Safety Bureau, report on its inquiry into the G class airspace demonstration. This is the second damning report on the administration of aviation safety in this country in as many days, and it is the second damning report on the management of aviation safety by Mr Vaile and now Mr Anderson. Both have been shown to have been, at best, negligent in their duties to ensure that our skies are safe.

speech.para: I would like to remind the Senate of the statement Mr Anderson made in the other place almost 12 months ago to the day. He said:

The reality is that I have kept very close to CASA because I am concerned about aviation safety in this country. I want to be satisfied that we have an excellent board, that the director of aviation safety really knows what he is talking about.

If Mr Anderson had been keeping a close eye on the CASA board, he would have noticed that that board had not lodged a corporate plan. Given this statement, how did the Deputy Prime Minister not notice that the CASA board had put itself in breach of its own act, the Civil Aviation Act? After all, CASA's failure to provide such a plan meant that he too was effectively in breach of the Civil Aviation Act because he failed to table the CASA corporate plan in both houses of parliament.

I want to go to the findings of what was the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation and is now the Australian Transport Safety Bureau. The report is described as a `Systemic report into Class G airspace demonstration'. A series of summary conclusions is set out on pages 106 and 107. I want to detail those for the Senate, in particular, findings 6 to 10. Finding 6 is:
CASA's overall project management of the Class G airspace demonstration was deficient because:
. the purpose of the demonstration was not clearly defined;
. the selection of the timing and location of the demonstration placed significant pressure on CASA to ensure that consultation, safety analysis and education issues were comprehensively addressed;
. safety analysis activities contained several significant deficiencies;
. there was a lack of appropriate consultation in the early phases of the project;
. the design and management of the education program contained several significant deficiencies; and
. late changes made to the airspace design and procedures significantly compromised the effec tiveness of CASA's safety analysis and education activities.

I remind the Senate that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority is charged with administering aviation safety. Here we had a body which was seeking to be a reformer in terms of the regime that it was to administer. In doing that, the very reputable organisation now known as the Australian Transport Safety Bureau found that they could not establish, under the control of the board as they were then, the proper purpose of the demonstration or properly define it so that those people operating within it could properly understand it; they could not appropriately select timing and location of the demonstration; and that they were guilty of establishing safety analysis activities which contained several significant deficiencies.

Given the Auditor-General's report into CASA that was tabled on Monday of this week, one can see that CASA had difficulties in performing its duties in terms of the regulation of aviation safety and in terms of not carrying out the detail of the safety inspections that they were required to carry out under their act and the regulations which apply to CASA. In that climate, for CASA to have become effectively the proposed agent of change was for CASA to take a step too far. Can I go on and say that the Australian Transport Safety Bureau found a number of other things, for example, point 7 states:
A number of guiding principles associated with the project were based on flawed assumptions.
No. 8 reads:
Adequate justification for the air space changes associated with the Class G demonstration was not provided.
In other words, the changes which CASA was implementing could not be justified. That is, CASA did not have information on which it could justify the activities it was undertaking. Point 9 says:
A significant proportion of the aviation industry did not conduct an appropriate level of education and training to prepare for the demonstration.

That is a very significant point because, of course, the nature of the regime was one which relied upon significant understanding of the trial, given that it relied upon signifi cant alertness by pilots operating in the system and it being a trial which did not rely on the same level of oversight and control by, for example, the normal regulatory bodies such as air traffic control. To find that organisations had not attended to training the operators in the area is to find that the trial was taking place in an atmosphere quite inappropriate for such a trial and in an atmosphere where people did not actually understand what they were supposed to be doing. Point 10 goes on:
The following organisational factors adversely influenced the ability of CASA to effectively manage the class G demonstration project.
In other words, these are the issues which were relevant within the organisation of CASA which adversely affected the trial.
There are six points here. I think these add to the findings of the Auditor-General tabled in this place on Monday and the dot points are:
. There was a lack of established processes within CASA for conducting safety case and consultation activities for large change-management projects.
. CASA's management profile and staffing prior to July 1998 reduced the ability of the organisation to effectively monitor and control its activities.

A very significant factor I must say about that is that the management profile of CASA and the staffing of CASA made it, I would suggest, impossible for CASA to have properly operated the trial that they embarked upon. The dot points continue:
. There was a lack of appropriate internal and external review mechanisms for ensuring the objectivity of the project.
. The division of roles and responsibilities between CASA and Airservices Australia regarding the design and regulation of airspace was not clearly defined.
. The division of roles and responsibilities between the CASA Chairman and the Director and other management was not clearly defined.
I want to come back to that. The final dot point is:
. The influence of the CASA Chairman's involvement in airspace reform and management style contributed to the project management's deficiencies associated with the demonstration.
That, of course, is a reference to the role of the then chairman, Mr Dick Smith.

If you look at page 104 of the report, you will see that this very damning passage is contained in it. It is damning of the organisation and it is certainly damning of the role of the then chairman, Mr Dick Smith, and I want to put this matter on the record as well. It reads:
The chairman's close involvement in project management became associated with a number of undesirableâ
I stress that wordâ

consequences including the removal of previous internal review processes including important review mechanisms at higher levels than the decision maker; a decrease in the ability of CASA managers and the organisation as a whole to coordinate their decision making processes; an increase in confusion among staff and external parties regarding who in CASA was making decisions and what decisions were valid; and uncertainty among CASA staff regarding their ability to query the chairman's decisions or instructions due to his senior position.

It was subsequently reported by CASA staff that the chairman's management style was characterised by micromanagement, an unwillingness to consider other views and rigid adherence to a predetermined path. The chairman also appeared to show a level of interest in activities that could lead to delays in the implementation process. Many of the problems associated with planning and implementation of the demonstration were related to inadequate safety analysis, consultation and education activities. Although there were many reasons for the problems encountered, there is considerable evidence to indicate that the influence of the Chairman's active involvement and management style contributed to those problems.

Let me say that the then chairman, Mr Smith, attended a hearing of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs References Committee and was asked questions by Senator Woodley. Senator Woodley has subsequently come into this place and has indicated that he was, in effect, asked by Mr Smith to ask him those questions. In my view, the chairman used parliamentary privilege to make outrageous allegations about other participants in the aviation industry to protect his own position. It is significant that the finding of this inquiry is quite forthright about the role of Mr Smith and particularly that his desire to manage the process, his desire to initiate this change, played a significant part in the failure of the trial and the need for the trial, in effect, to be ended prematurely because it obviously was not working.

But the fact of the matter is that Mr Smith's chairing of this organisation, which was the organisation charged with administering aviation safety, seems to have become a crusade to achieve what he thought should be achieved rather than the management of an organisation charged with ensuring that the existing regime was safe and that any changes which were being put in place were safe. So, in effect, it was a crusade for a change in which Mr Smith, as chairman of CASA, was substantially responsible for the failure of CASA in its involvement in this project and for effectively making parts of the organisation ineffective.

The findings are particularly clear about these matters. For example, `the management style was characterised by micromanagement'âin other words, Mr Smith wanted to do other people's jobs rather than leave them to do theirs. The report also refers to `an unwillingness to consider other views'âand I must say that anyone who has sat down with Mr Smith will hear a lot from Mr Smith and not have many opportunities to say anything in response. It also refers to `rigid adherence to a predetermined path'. I think those are signs of a person who wishes to lead but who is unable to take into account the views of others. Quite frankly, this report demonstrates that the role of the chairman in this trial was actually quite detrimental to the possibility of the trial being successful.

Of course, the report finds that there were valid reasons to examine options for change, but those reasons were, in effect, undermined by the way the change was pursued and perhaps even by the means by which CASA was used as an agent for change rather than as an organisation whose basis for existence was the administration of aviation safety and not as a change agent. I think those lessons will be carried forward and in the future, hopefully, the CASA board, when it gets its act together, will learn great lessons from the findings of the Australian Transport Safety Bureau. The Senate committee is inquiring into this matter. Perhaps many of the matters that the Senate committee needs to inquire into have been dealt with adequately by this report.

talk.start.para: âToday I would like to speak about unemployment in regional areas. Unemployment in regional areas is one of the most serious problems we face as a nation. The statistics on regional unemployment levels are disturbing, especially for young people and indigenous people, and must be of concern to all Australians. According to the Small Area Labour Market report in June 1999, some rural and regional areas have reported significantly higher unemployment rates than the rest of the country. For example, Broome recorded a 9.8 per cent unemployment rate, Halls Creek 8.8 per cent, Carnarvon 9.9 per cent, Wyndham-East Kimberley eight per cent and the Murchison and Murray Shires both 9.2 per cent for the June quarter. These figures are for the north-west of Western Australia, an area in which I have a particular interest. Although these figures are not seasonally adjusted, they indicate that there are far too many people unemployed in our country areas and it is a problem that should concern all Australians.

speech.para: The Howard government is helping to reduce unemployment in rural and regional areas in Western Australia through such initiatives as the Jobs Pathway Program and the New Apprenticeships program. During the last month's break I was in Derby to launch a Jobs Pathway Program, which will be delivered by the Derby-West Kimberley SkillShare to the benefit of the entire West Kimberley region.

Youth unemployment tends to be a problem in the less populated areas of Australia where training and educational facilities are not as readily available as they are in metropolitan or larger regional areas, so that job creation becomes more about equipping young people in the country with the necessary skills and knowledge to be employed.

The Jobs Pathway Program is specially targeted to help young people make a smooth transition from school to work and thereby hopefully avoid long periods of unemploy ment by getting them into the work force sooner than they other otherwise would be. The program works through the assistance of schools, industry and the local community all joining together to encourage young people to create better pathways for themselves in gaining employment, returning to further education or training or commencing in a school-based vocational program or school-based New Apprenticeshipsâall in the interest of the individual student so that a person can determine what area of work they would like to be involved in. These programs are there to help them achieve their goal in terms of the kind of work they would like to do.

Many young people, especially in regional areas, are leaving country towns because of the lack of employment opportunities, and many parents in regional Australia are concerned about the potential consequences of long-term unemployment for their children. Therefore, they do not discourage them from leaving the rural areas to go to the larger regional centres and to the capital cities.

One of the sad problems we face in Australia is the high incidence of youth suicide, particularly in country areas. One of the causes of the high incidence of youth suicide without any doubt is the fact that young people feel they have no future in regional areas and become depressed about the lack of opportunities for them and the fact that they do not see their lives going anywhere. That leads to depression, low self-esteem and drug and alcohol abuse, and these things invariably heighten the risk of suicide. The statistics are startling when we see that in 1995, 434 young people aged between 14 and 24 took their lives. Fifty of those were from Western Australia. Regional Western Australia has a much higher percentage rate of youth suicide than other areas of the state, and it amounts to something like 20 per cent of the total incidence in the whole state. It is also concerning that in the Kimberley in 1998, 12 indigenous young Australians took their lives. The increasing prevalence of youth suicide in Western Australia, and the north-west in particular, is a matter of great concern to me. It is because of these background issues that the government is working towards assisting young people, especially indigenous people, to find employment by providing them with job skill education.

The Kimberley youth project team identified six main issues which need to be addressed. These six issues involve the need to control and manage the distribution of drugs and alcohol; provide sufficient constructive and appropriate activities for young people; provide support to Aboriginal parents; reduce fighting and conflict between families and different groups; address and solve the prevalence of criminal activity and anti-social behaviour in these small Aboriginal communities; and replace boredom, lack of purpose and lack of education with positive opportunities for the future. There is no doubt that education does provide young people with a sense of purpose and accomplishment in gaining skills and self-dignity. It also teaches them about communication and helps them to interact with the rest of the community.

There are many schools served by the Jobs Pathway Program in Western Australia and across Australia. In fact, 153 high schools in Western Australia are currently involved in the program, of which at least 70 are in regional areas. That represents a significant commitment to our youth in preparing them for our work force. The continuing success of the government's Work for the Dole Program is also testament to the Howard government's persistence in addressing such social issues, which invariably determine how successful young people will be in addressing the problems which will prevent them from fitting into society in a broad way. Work for the Dole not only ensures personal development but also is of great benefit to the local communities where these programs exist and where local programs are facilitated.

I have been very pleased to hear about and see the success of a number of local Work for the Dole projects in the north of Western Australia. In particular, I have to congratulate the Shire of Derby-West Kimberley for the great support they have given to the Work for the Dole program because in the west Kimberley the level of unemployment, particularly among indigenous people, is very, very high. The Work for the Dole program, promoted through the local government authorities in the Kimberley, has done a lot to provide young indigenous people with work opportunities and give them a sense of achievement and dignity by being involved in these programs.

Another positive measure which has been promoted by the Howard government is the New Apprenticeships initiative, which boosts local training and job opportunities. New Apprenticeships are a combination of paid work and training recognised by various industries as being appropriate for those industries. The New Apprenticeships initiative provides a financial incentive to employers in regional areas who are prepared to provide these new apprenticeships to young people. The government has set up New Apprenticeships centres to facilitate this initiative. It is expected that 200 of these centres will be located in regional and rural areas from December of this year. Thirty-three of these will be located in Western Australia, made up of 19 in Perth, nine in the south-west, three in the central and south-eastern areas of WA and two in the north of Western Australia.

To add to the existing centres, new apprenticeship facilities will be located in Albany, Bunbury, Busselton, Mandurah, Manjimup, Narrogin, Geraldton, Kalgoorlie, Northam, Broome and Karratha. The New Apprenticeships centres will work closely with local area consultative committees which bring together key industry, employer and community representatives to identify priorities and opportunities for employment and economic development in the areas concerned. This synergy between the New Apprenticeships and the area consultative committees means that there will be a much greater focus on the job opportunities available in these areas.

I recently visited Broome and was given the opportunity to take part in an Aboriginal youth forum, representing the Minister for Immigration Multicultural Affairs, the Hon. Philip Ruddock, in promoting the highly successful Living in Harmony program, which was originally an initiative of the Western Australian state government and which has been taken up by the federal government. This forum was held at the Kimberley Camp School, which is adjacent to the Cable Beach Resort in Broome, and has a tropical ambience and is a very nice place indeed.

During the forum, which brought together young Aboriginal peopleâteenagers and people in their early 20s from all over the Kimberleyâa whole range of issues were discussed concerning the opportunities for young people in the Kimberley area and the problems that they faced. One of the major topics of discussion was employment opportunities for young people in the Kimberley. I was very pleased to hear of the positive work being done by youth advisory committees, in particular the one located in Halls Creek, which submitted their report, called Kick Back to Reality, at this event. The youth advisory councils have the potential to play a positive role in mobilising young people through ownership and management of their own ideas within local communities.

The government has taken positive steps to recognise the invaluable contribution young people have made to their own future through the establishment of the national youth round table. Young people play a role in deciding how projects are developed and delivered in terms of community involvement, employment and education. I think the lack of education, including simple literacy and job skills, makes it very difficult for young indigenous people to obtain jobs. A new action plan to help these young people in regional areas is currently being developed by the government to improve educational outcomes in terms of literacy, numeracy and school attendance. This is called the indigenous employment policy. It will generally improve outcomes for indigenous job seekers through the job network by helping them acquire the skills to obtain work.

While I was in Darwin recently I also attended a joint area consultative committee meeting of all the northern area consultative committees. I was very pleased with the success of this meeting since I had originally suggested that such a meeting be held at a meeting of the North-West Area Consultative Committee a couple of years ago, because I felt there were common issues to be faced in terms of providing employment opportunities for young people across the north of Australia and because I thought the solutions might also have much in common for the area across the north of Australia. I was very pleased with the success of that forum, which developed many ideas which will be useful in providing employment to indigenous people in the north of Australia.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak briefly on the history of the Australian Protective Services dispute regarding the terms and conditions of their employment. The current Australian Protective Services dispute has its origins in the commencement of the APS workplace certified agreement negotiations in 1997. The 1997 negotiations did not begin well and APS officers were advised that, due to pressures from cabinet, they would have to prepare themselves for significant change to the terms and conditions of their employment.

speech.para: The key elements of this change would include the following:
. A 20 per cent reduction in salary costs for operational staff;
. An absenteeism reduction scheme;
. A reduction in overtime as well as overtime payments;
. The use of casual labour; and
. A reduction in leave credits.

As you may well imagine, the APS officers were utterly astounded when they were confronted with this agenda. What was even more astounding was that they were offered no pay rise in conjunction with these demands. The Transport Workers Union began meeting with the APS management to attempt to establish a conciliatory approach to this certified agreement.

These negotiations followed the 1996 federal budget which allocated the APS $11.5 million for restructuring purposes. The union attempted to utilise these additional funds in negotiations to alleviate the pressure on the 20 per cent wage reduction. The position which the TWU took in these negotiations was that APS officers should not be forced to accept such drastic change, especially the 20 per cent reduction in wages, but that other changes were acceptable on the proviso that officers were not disadvantaged.

The reply by the APS managers was that these funds had already been used to close regional offices and to fund staff redundancies. At this time I questioned Senator Vanstone regarding the 20 per cent reduction in wages which APS staff were subjected to. It is interesting to note that not long after this the 20 per cent reduction in wages was reduced to `some' reduction in wages.

Negotiations continued, with some key elements shaping up into an agreement draft. These elements were: some level of salary increase; changes to the type of agreement rather than the individual agreements, which was the option management preferred; a reduction in overtime payment levels; an increase in working hours from a 38-hour week to 40 hours; loss of emergency duty payments; and the loss of rostered days off.

Contrary to recommendations by the union, the APS put this agreement to the vote and the document was rejected at a national level by a record 96.8 per cent of the staff. Following this mass rejection of the certified agreement, the APS, under a new director, decided to push an individual or station specific agreement with the hope that a divide and conquer approach to negotiations would be successful. The new director has frustrated the union's negotiations by changing the initial negotiating position at each meeting with workplace delegates and the union, and has effectively destroyed the good faith of APS employees in the negotiating process.

The current situation, coupled with industrial action by APS employees, has eventuated due to the inability of the director to negotiate honestly and fairly. In fact, requests by the Transport Workers Union for a meeting with management have most recently elicited no response at all.

At the APS rally on 29 October at West Block, the national headquarters of the APS, the director made public statements to appease the employees with respect to the status of the certified agreement negotiations. Not surprisingly, these statements were later reversed as part of an official statement in a bulletin to staff. At this point in the negotiation, the director agreed to meet with negotiators from the TWU on the proviso that action be postponed. When this did not occur, staff were refused permission to return to their work following the industrial action.

A new twist to the tale was the introduction last week of a physical and mental fitness test. All officers attempting promotion, all those going from casual to permanent positions, will now have to undergo a rigorous test similar to that used by SAS army officers. The test, which was introduced without consultation, calls for applicants to become fit within four weeks and to pass a urine drug analysis test as well. As you can imagine, to force the introduction of such a radical change to workplace conditions can only inflame the current industrial situation.

The position that the union and staff are currently seeking entails a global certified agreement with a four per cent pay rise each year and little change to conditions. They also demand that the agreement must pass the no disadvantage clause. APS officers have not had a pay rise since 1996. A four per cent across-the-board pay rise made available each year for the life of the agreement would equate to a two per cent rise per annum over the years 1996-2002. This is not a big ask in anyone's book. I believe this situation deserves the urgent attention of the government and warrants, in particular, the active interest of this parliament, especially given the critical services which the APS provides. Decent pay and working conditions are a fundamental right for all employees and the Director of the APS should take the negotiating process seriously.

In closing, I would just like to acknowledge that this situation, unfortunately, is so typical of the appalling industrial relations practices that have occurred since the coalition government came to power. Time and time again I see stories of workers stripped of their dignity in their attempt not just to fight for better wages and conditions but indeed to sustain those that have been won over the years and allocated through the industrial relations process on the basis of what is being fair and reasonable to many Australian workers.

I think this case exemplifies the great difficulty that both trade unions and their members, so many employees, have in establishing a fair and reasonable negotiating environment so they can work constructively to a positive outcome for all parties. I certainly urge the government's most immediate consideration of this matter.

talk.start.para: âThis afternoon I would like to speak about Western Sahara. As most honourable senators would know, Western Sahara is in north-west Africa and for the 100 years prior to 1975 it was a Spanish colony. At that time Spain announced, after several years of resisting UN demands to decolonise, that it would hold a referendum to determine whether the Saharawi people wanted to be independent. Morocco rejected this, as they claimed that Western Sahara was unequivocally part of Morocco. In fact, Morocco was so convinced of the legitimacy of their claim that in 1974 they took it to the International Court of Justice. The ICJ decided that Morocco did not have a legitimate claim to Western Sahara.

speech.para: The decision by the International Court of Justice had an interesting dimension for Australia many years later. This was highlighted recently by the Indigenous Law Centre which ran an article featuring the situation in Western Sahara in its journal. The decision of the ICJ that Morocco could not claim sovereignty over Western Sahara was pivotal in the High Court of Australia's decision in Mabo (No. 2). As the ICJ found that terra nullius did not exist in Western Sahara, it set a precedent for Australian law. It demonstrated, in the words of the ILC, that:
. . . institutional bonds are formed between diverse peoples as a direct result of the use of international norms and structures.

It is even more amazing that this decision came down in favour of the Saharawis, given that they were just about the only group not able to present a case to the ICJ, as that body only hears from legitimate states.

A month after the International Court of Justice ruled against Morocco, Spain handed over Western Sahara, in a secret agreement, to Morocco and Mauritania. There was clearly no legal basis for this secret agreement, but the situation still stands 25 years later. The occupation of Western Sahara was in violation of international law as well as resolutions of the United Nations, the Organisation of African Unity and the International Court of Justice. But despite the question of the decolonisation of Western Sahara being on the agenda of the UN for more than 25 years, the Saharawi people have yet to be given the opportunity to exercise their rights.

In addition, despite King Hassan organising a `green march' of 350,000 Moroccans to walk into the Western Sahara and reclaim their territory, there is evidence that in fact Morocco used particularly brutal tactics, including the use of cluster and napalm bombs. For those who remained in the territory there is documented evidence of imprisonment, intimidation and disappearance. Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch both have documented evidence of human rights abuses.

It strikes me that there are remarkable similarities between the situation in East Timor and that of Western Sahara. Apart from the obvious similarities in the method of annexationâor, more particularly, invasionâand subsequent brutalities, there are also similarities in the UN's attempt to establish a referendum and its push to give the Saharawis a say in their own future although, unlike East Timor, no country in the world, apart from Morocco itself, has formally recognised Moroccan sovereignty over Western Sahara. In fact, the Saharawi republic has been recognised by 76 countries and is a fully fledged member of the Organisation of African Unity.

Over the years the pro-independence movement called Polisario fought against the new colonisers and struggled for the independence and freedom of Western Sahara. Mauritania succumbed and signed a peace treaty in 1976. In 1988, Morocco and Polisario agreed to a United Nations and Organisation of African Unity peace plan. This plan included a ceasefire, identification of eligible voters, repatriation of refugees and the organisation of a fair and transparent referendum. The ceasefire was declared in September 1991 with the intention of holding a referendum in January 1992. Evidence from several sources indicates that Morocco has not participated in the plan as honestly or as sincerely as one would hope. In fact, there is clear evidence of intimidation and thuggery on the part of Morocco and clear indications it has tried to influence the ballot, particularly through trying to register thousands of Moroccans now resident in Western Sahara.

In 1997, UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan appointed James Baker as special representative for Western Sahara. His role was to move the issue on from the impasse it had reached. He enabled direct negotiations to take place between Polisario and Morocco. The result of those was the Houston Agreement, signed in September of 1997. As a result of this agreement the UN redeployed its mission, the identification commission resumed its work and a new ballot date was set for 7 December 1998. However, Morocco still stalled. The date has now been set for July of next year. But even this is not certain. Even in September of this year, demonstrations were forcibly broken up, people were injured and even killed. The Polisario representative in Australia, Kamal Fadel, also has information, confirmed by various media sources, that Morocco has been encouraging its settlers in the territory to kill Saharawis and loot and burn their houses and shops. This too has overtones of tactics recently used in East Timor.

There is also a massive refugee problem. There are hundreds and thousands of people living in refugee camps in Tindouf in Algeria. They live in almost uninhabitable terrain in searing heat, with virtually no shelter and totally reliant on aid waiting to return home. There are also 1,900 imprisoned Moroccans who were captured during the war and are now POWs in the camps. Like their exiled captors, some of these men have been there for 25 years. Polisario has recently released 200 of them who are old and sick, but Morocco refuses to take them back, reputedly in case they contradict its propaganda about Polisario. So they will remain there until Morocco frees Western Sahara.

Ironically, despite the awful and harsh conditions, these refugee camps are reported to be very well run. They are primarily run by the most liberated women of the Muslim world. As their men have had to go and fight in the resistance army, the women have stayed in the camps and run them. They have taken on leadership roles, they have set up an electoral system and there is a 95 per cent literacy rate. As well, thousands of children every year are sent overseas to Western countries at the expense of host families. They are sent to learn other languages, to be educated about other countries and to gain first-hand experience of Western countries so that they are able to decide for themselves whether the West is really the demon that Islamic extremists often say it is. These are truly remarkable achievements for a people cast out into the sand, terrorised and all but forgotten by the West. It is hoped that with the advent of a new king in Morocco following the death of King Hassan there will be a change in attitude.

Unfortunately, despite the UN efforts to date there are still no certainties that the ballot will go ahead. Despite UN involvement, far too many countries are unaware of the plight of the Saharawis. This is particularly unfortunate, because there are only a few months until the ballot and there is still much ground to be covered. It is only through the awareness of the international community and the pressure they might bring to bear on the Moroccan government that there is any hope that the ballot will go ahead.

Here in Australia, Polisario is ably represented and I hope that the Australian government will formally meet with Polisario representatives and take note of their concerns. I am also hopeful that the Australian government will bring influence to bear internationally to keep the UN focused on this task and to let the people of Western Sahara have their say in a free, fair and transparent election.

talk.start.para: âToday in the Northern Territory parliament the Northern Territory education minister, the Hon. Peter Adamson MLA, will give a ministerial statement regarding indigenous education in the territory. This statement follows the recent release of an important report entitled Learning Lessons: An Independent Review of Indigenous Education in the Northern Territory by our colleague the former senator for the Northern Territory, Bob Collins. Mr Adamson will demonstrate that the Northern Territory government is taking extremely seriously the problems in Aboriginal education and is looking at many ways to find solutions to this long-term difficult problem.

speech.para: I will comment on the Collins review later, but firstly I would like to address remarks made by Senator Crossin in the Senate on Monday. Senator Crossin has once again harped negatively about an issue and shown surprising ignorance. She has failed to present one solution or make one constructive comment, apart from a throwaway line at the end of her diatribe that may deprive Aboriginal people of assistance. The comparison in approach and attitude between Senator Crossin and her predecessor, Bob Collins, is a wide and obvious gap. Her speech was made in the second reading debate on the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 and consisted solely of an attack on the Northern Territory government. The administration of the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Programâwhich I will refer to as IESIPâby the Northern Territory government was the issue on which Senator Crossin vented her spleen, and I would like to address some of her more outlandish comments.

In July this year an internal review of IESIP commenced in the Territory. The terms of this review were to reorganise and rationalise the current collection of 32 initiatives to ensure maximum opportunity to enhance outcomes for indigenous students. By undertaking this series of reviews, the Northern Territory government is clearly demonstrating its commitment to addressing the educational concerns for all students, including Aboriginal students. The Collins and IESIP reviews have been undertaken with the support, knowledge and active involvement of the Commonwealth government. Senator Crossin would do well to be part of a bipartisan approach rather than be out of step, as appears to be her current direction.

Senator Crossin makes the statement that the current operational plan as negotiated with the Commonwealth from 1997 to 1999 will simply be extended to the year 2000. This is incorrect. As a result of the IESIP review and collaboration with officers from DETYA and the federal minister, Dr Kemp, the operational plan has substantially changed and there has been a revision of the performance indicators and targets. The Northern Territory Aboriginal Education Branch is currently restructuring. At the time of the IESIP review the newly formed Aboriginal Education Branch was made up of two-thirds IESIP funding because it simply pulled together all existing disparate and uncoordinated programs. As the branch establishes its business, increasing numbers of core-funded positions are being advertised and filled. Some of these positions are associated with the implementation of the Collins review and the new structure will reflect the key outcome areas as required to improve indigenous education in the Northern Territory.

As Senator Crossin is aware, a fully written response to issues raised by the Senate inquiry into Aboriginal education regarding the state of facilities at Papunya CEC has been provided by the Northern Territory Department of Education. While school principals, in association with school councils, are normally responsible for identifying needs and preparing submissions for minor or capital works, the acting director of schools in Alice Springs is actively assisting in this case. Senator Crossin says:
. . . 46.1 per cent of the total money coming from the Commonwealth is taken off under the guise of on-costs by the Northern Territory government.

This is untrue. As Senator Crossin herself admits, the on-costs are in relation to the employment of staff, and this amounts to approximately 15 per cent of the total funding. The Northern Territory Department of Education, with the knowledge, participation and support of the Commonwealth Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs, is currently reviewing the on-costs with the aim of reducing current levels. An external consultant has been engaged to assist in this process.

The IESIP review at no time suggested `a breach of contract', as Senator Crossin implies; nor did the Commonwealth. The monitoring of the IESIP program has been conducted jointly between the Northern Territory Department of Education and DETYA since the program commenced in 1990. The IESIP review team's interpretation of `supplementary' and `core' reflects stakeholder understandings of these terms and is based on a literal rather than a formal or legal definition of these terms.

The major purpose of the IESIP review was to realign resources to better support schools to deliver strong and effective programs and to enhance and accelerate improved educational outcomes for indigenous students. Providing funds directly to Aboriginal schools in the territory would mean that Aboriginal students in other than remote localities may receive no additional support. From 2000, the Aboriginal Education Branch will be the central coordinating body for all IESIP and core-funded programs for indigenous students. This will allow for more efficient, effective and appropriate support to enable accelerated achievement for indigenous students.

Senator Crossin also made mention of the Collins review of Aboriginal education in the Northern Territory. This independent investigation of Aboriginal education, which was commissioned by the Northern Territory government, was intended to provide a catalyst for a major refocus on Aboriginal education in the Territory. It has generated much debate and there is no doubt that the Collins recommendations will be turned into action. The Northern Territory Chief Minister, the Hon. Denis Burke MLA, met with the federal education minister, Dr David Kemp, last week in an indication of the seriousness with which the Northern Territory government takes this issue. A joint Commonwealth-state working party will be convened as a result of that meeting.

The Commonwealth has recognised the importance of finding a solution to many of the problems presented in the area of Aboriginal education. Bob Collins in his review discusses the importance to indigenous students in the Northern Territory of the English as a Second Language for Indigenous Language Speaking Students Program. It should be noted that this program is part of the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program that Senator Crossin so vigorously attacked in the Senate on Monday. Bob Collins recommends that the program be extended across all of the primary years of schools and states:
The review strongly supports the ESLILSS program and the outstandingly successful work that it is doing across schools in the Northern Territory for those students regularly attending classes.

Bob Collins also makes mention of the fact that the Commonwealth is working on a national indigenous literacy, numeracy and attendance strategy. The strategy is part of the plan the Commonwealth recently announced, which has five points, to improve educational outcomes for indigenous students and build on the strong foundations laid through the strategic results projects.

These Commonwealth initiatives, along with the review itself, will ensure that the problems outlined by Bob Collins will be addressed. The problems in Aboriginal education will not be solved overnight; it is important to remember that it is an issue that affects and involves many people, not just students.
The major problem in indigenous education described in the Collins review is poor attendance rates. It is described in the review as follows:

Complex as the task of education is, as a first requirement children must attend school consistently to progress. In relation to indigenous education, poor attendance is without doubt the primary cause of poor educational outcomes.

This is a fundamental commonsense statement. I am sure anyone who has had the benefit of gaining a good education would agree and see its obvious logic. Unfortunately, a generation of Aboriginal children, particularly in remote areas in the Northern Territory, are not realising their true potential. This unfortunate reality is mainly due to the simple fact that they are not attending school regularly enough to learn. This is a major problem for the whole community and will have devastating effects in years to come, not only on this generation, but also on future generations of Aboriginal people.

It is vitally important that standards be established in Aboriginal communities by parents, community leaders and elders reinforcing the necessity of students attending school and being on time for school. The goal of increasing student attendance level to satisfactory standards is a difficult one that cannot be achieved by the Department of Education, the Commonwealth government, individual teachers or principals alone, and whilst there are several outstanding success stories in the Northern Territory at various schools, it is paramount that these successes be achieved territory-wide and for the long term.

Parents must take responsibility for the education of their children and ensure that they attend school and attend on time. They must get involved in their children's education, take an interest in and participate at their school. Parental involvement and participation in schooling is important in any family, but I feel it is particularly so in Aboriginal families. It is only the parents who can bridge the gap between the two culturesâAboriginal heritage on one side and a relevant 21st century education system on the other.

There are many other issues that impact on attendance, in addition to the current lack of parental and community priorities emphasising the importance of attendance at school in order to gain a good education. These include health issues, such as poor nutrition; cultural issues of important ceremonial and historical significance; and housing problems. These issues are significant and must be addressed if Aboriginal education, particularly in remote communities, is ever to reach meaningful standards.

Again, I stress that the fundamental problem that must be addressed is attendance. This challenge faces us all but, in particular, the parents and relatives of Aboriginal children in remote communities. Governments must put in place the necessary facilities, tools and encouragement but it is paramount that Aboriginal parents recognise their responsi bilities to the younger generation and rise to the challenge.

On a more positive note, Bob Collins cites several examples of schools that have developed innovative schemes to encourage community participation and enhance attendance. A simple but highly effective scheme is that being used by the Alekerange School north-east of Alice Springs. The Alekerange School has developed a carrot and stick approach to encouraging attendance, with very good results. The initiative that has been developed has the support of the community, which is vital, and involves the senior primary school students' attendance figures being prominently displayed in the classroom. Attendance is linked to the end of semester excursion and those who have perfect attendance records get to go on the excursion for free. Those that do not have a perfect record pay a fine of $1 for every day of school missed that cannot be explained. This simple but effective approach has raised attendance levels to approximately 90 per cent, an outcome that must be congratulated. Similarly, on a visit to Warburton in remote Western Australia earlier this year, I was informed that swimming pool access was given only to students attending school. Harsh maybe, but certainly effective.

In conclusion, I would like to remind senators that the Northern Territory government instituted this review out of a desire to refocus the Northern Territory Department of Education's activities in Aboriginal education. It is worth noting that Bob Collins's recommendations relating to the need to form partnerships between Aboriginal people and government agencies is consistent with a vision for the Northern Territory outlined by the Chief Minister, the Hon. Denis Burke, in his recently released policy document Foundations for our Future.
Sitting suspended from 1.53 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. I refer to the minister's statement in the Senate yesterday when he said:

question.para: In August of 1998, the then Department of Industry, Science and Tourism sponsored the proposal to secure APEC badging and invited other APEC economies to cosponsor the event.

Is it not true that APEC's Industry, Science and Technology Working Group, of which Australia was at the time `lead shepherd' or chair, gave approval to Australia's proposal for APEC endorsement of the event? Did this not enable the government and in fact the minister's own department to strongly influence the working group's work program, including the decision to grant APEC approval to the government's own proposal for official endorsement?

talk.start.para: âI am not sure that I can add much to what I said yesterday. The facts are all on the table and were all on the public record at the time the matter was being handled by Minister Moore. In August 1998, the then Department of Industry, Science and Tourism, having been approached by the private sector managers, initiators and overseers of the proposed Technomart seeking its supportâ
âIt wasn't Technomart then.

âIt was a Technomart; it was not badged. They sought APEC badging and the department's sponsorship of that matter at that time back in August 1998. The department invited other APEC economies to cosponsor that event. That went through the normal APEC channels and APEC badging was secured. That was welcomed by the then minister, by the Queensland government and, of course, by the sponsors themselves.

answer.para: It was all above board, as I said yesterday. It was always presented to the APEC working group on the basis that it was an initiative of the private sector to have a Technomart and that it would help and be good if the thing had APEC badging. That was done through the normal channels and was all above board. It was always on the basis that it was private sector managed but that the governments, both the Queensland and the federal governments, would hopefully provide financial sponsorship to what was a private sector initiative.

talk.start.para: âI do not know why the minister could not answer my previous question when his own department's annual report for 1998-99, released just last week, states:

question.para: . . . through the year . . . Australia took the role of Lead Shepherd for the Industry, Science and Technology Working Group, which enabled the Government to strongly influence the Working Group's direction and program.

I have a supplementary question: Is the minister simply incompetent or is he trying to hide the fact that his own department strongly influenced APEC's decision to give APEC approval to a conference which disastrously failed and which was run by a company that is now in liquidation?

talk.start.para: âI have no idea where this is really going. We have never hidden the fact that the department, through the officials who attended these APEC working group meetings, did strongly urge and support the proposition that APEC badging be given to this event. There is nothing hidden about that whatsoever. It is a perfectly proper thing for the department to have done.

answer.para: This event did offer the opportunity for very significant promotion and showcasing of Australian technology. My department and the Queensland government did place considerable store in the professionalism and experience of the people in PacRim. They had good reason to do that and had every reason to believe there was every prospect this would be a successful conference. It is regrettable that it was not, but there is nothing wrong whatsoever with the departmental officials strongly supporting APEC endorsement of the event.

talk.start.para: âOrder! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the Papua New Guinea Constitutional Development Commission, led by the Hon. Yauwe Riyong. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be informative and enjoyable.
âHear, hear!

âMy question without notice is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Will the Assistant Treasurer inform the Senate of evidence of the continuing strength of the Australian economy? How will tax reform further help Australian families?

âI thank Senator Gibson for that important question. Senator Gibson is well known for his particular concern and interest in the economy and for the important role he played in the tax reform program. There are a number of factors which underlie the current strength of the Australian economy. Unemployment has fallen by 0.3 per cent to 7.1 per cent. Since coming to government, we have created just under 600,000 jobs. We have continuing low inflation. We have interest rates at dramatically lower levels than the record highs under Labor, and we are seeing continuing strong growth.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Would Labor senators who are consistently shouting please cease doing so.

âLast night I went to the ACCI dinner with a number of colleagues, including Senator Conroy and Senator Collins. Senator Conroy, I might say, was in his black tie clobber, looking very bourgeois indeedânot the typical clobber you would wear to a TWU function!

answer.para: Yesterday saw the release of the ACCI's survey of small business which showed that general business conditions in the small business sector improved over the most recent quarter. The survey also showed that the small business sector is optimistic, with the index for the next period at almost 66 indicating that business conditions should continue to improve.

However, while the economy is in good shape, it is important that we now put in place the measures which will ensure that the Australian economy is on a sound footing for the next century. We need to ensure that the benefits of reforms flow through to Australian families and Australian workers. That is why on 1 July next year the government will deliver the largest tax cut in Australian history. Many families will benefit in the order of $40 to $50 per week. I think I am right in saying that Labor opposed tax reform; Labor opposed the tax cuts. Our business tax reforms are also an absolutely essential element of the reform process, and we are going to give Australia an internationally competitive company tax rate and also an internationally competitive capital gains tax regime.

The Labor Party is all over the place on this reform, as on others. Mark Latham was opposed to the very important capital gains tax changes that were debated in the caucus yesterday. Frankly, Madam President, if you had heard some of the debates in the other place this morning, you would know that the Labor Party on this issue, as on so many other issues, is all over the place. Where does Labor stand on any major issue? That is the hardest question anyone can ask in this parliament, because we do not know and the Labor Party does not know either. This government is presiding over clear policies for Australia which are helping to create a very sound economy which is delivering real benefits to Australian families and Australian workers.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. I refer to the minister's statement in the Senate yesterday:

question.para: . . . the formal written proposal put to APEC did say in its opening paragraph:
The proposal is for Australia to host the next APEC Technomart . . . as a commercially sponsored, managed and administered event.

Once APEC had approved Australia's proposal to host APEC Technomart III as a commercially managed and administered event, did the government put out a tender for companies interested in commercially managing and administering the event? What investigations did the minister's department carry out into PacRim Technomart, including as to their experience and financial situation, before promoting them as the commercial managers and administrators of Australia's APEC Technomart? What investigations did the minister's department carry out into Judith Maestracci before advising APEC she would be the project manager and Australian contact for APEC Technomart III?

talk.start.para: âThese rather tedious questions, which I would have thought were more appropriate for some estimates monologue, really are based on a false premise. One should understand that departments like mine get approached for sponsorships on a regular basis, and the department itself, not me, makes decisions in relation to sponsorships on a regular basis, as I guess do other departments.

answer.para: The organisers of this Technomart approached the department before my timeâthis was during 1998âand sought the department's support for their proposal for a Technomart to be held in Australia and run by the private sector, by them. That proposal came along with lots of other proposals that are put to my department by various private sector organisations seeking sponsorship of that kind from my department.

My department, through the course of 1998, examined their request for the sponsorship of this as a private sector initiativeâit was not initiated by my department but came from the private sectorâand, as history records, and as I have been saying today and yesterday, my department agreed that it would support this private sector initiative before this APEC working group on the basis that it was worthy of receiving APEC badging. It is not unusual, as I understand it, for APEC badging to be given to private sector initiatives in this or any other field and to involve private sector people.

So you have the whole thing upside down. This was not a case of the Australian government deciding it was going to hold an APEC Technomart and then putting some tender out. This was a private sector initiativeâand good on themâto hold this Technomart. They approached the Queensland government and the Commonwealth government seeking support for it. My department would have gone through all the normal checks in relation to the principles behind it, as did the Queensland government. Premier Beattie said to me personally when I was on the Gold Coast for this thing that Judith Maestracci was incredibly well qualified and a very high profile person in Queensland. I have her CV here and I am happy to table it. She is highly regarded in Queensland. She has had a number of appointments on government boards in Queensland and is a very significant professional organiser of major events. This was all available to my department in 1998, as it was to the Queensland government.

As I said, it was not a matter of this being put out to tender. These people approached the government, as do many others, seeking support for their event. The department, having gone through all its checks, as did the Queensland government, decided that it would provide support to these private sector organisers and initiators of this event. The Queensland government was as convinced as my department was that this was a professionally organised and approached event and it was worthy of the sponsorship which my department gave to it.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. If, as the minister repeatedly says, APEC Technomart III was a private sector initiative and that, `At no time was it ever presented as anything other than a private sector initiative,' can he explain why, when in 1998 the government announced APEC's endorsement of Australia's proposal to host APEC Technomart III, it was portrayed as an Australian initiative with no mention of it being a private sector initiative? Can he explain why there was no mention of PacRim Technomart and no mention of Judith Maestracci in that announcement?

âSenator Conroy is asking me about a press statement made by the then Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism in the previous government before the last election in October 1998. I have not got that press release before me but the whole way through this it was always on the basis, as was the proposal put to APEC, that this was a private sector initiative. Obviously it is Australian because PacRim and Judith Maestracci and her colleagues are Australian, as it happens, and this event was going to be held in Australia. So of course it was Australian, and I cannot see anything wrong with that.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. The coalition government has pursued an active social agenda which has, contrary to opposition claims, increased payments to families and older Australians in particular whilst maintaining the integrity of the social security system. Minister, could you please explain to the Senate current developments in social security reform?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Knowles, who is the Chair of the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, for her question on this important public policy issue. As the Senate would know, I released recently a discussion paper on long-term welfare dependency and the future of welfare into the 21st century. Yesterday I announced the release of a further discussion paper outlining the government's proposals to change how trusts and companies are treated under the social security means test. The Labor Party in government had failed to deal with this clear abuse of the social security system. I am alarmed at the equivocal Labor Party response to the announcement yesterday. The Labor Party family and community services spokesman, Wayne Swan, responds by questioning the estimated level of savings and responds with a partisan banter about trusts. The Labor Party should give unequivocal support to such a measure. Mr Swan comes across as a typical naysayerâknee-jerk and partisan opposition to everything, opportunism incarnate.

answer.para: The discussion paper proposes that, where a person controls or has contributed to a private company or private trust, the income and assets of that company or trust may be taken into account when assessing that person's entitlement to income support. It is estimated that less than 40,000 Centrelink and Veterans' Affairs customers will be affected by this measure, but savings to taxpayers are expected to be over $100 million a year. The measure could take effect from 1 July 2001. There is a growing body of evidence that some financial planners are using this currently legal loophole to undermine the integrity of our taxpayer funded social security system. Between 1993 and 1994 and 1996 and 1997 the number of trusts lodging tax returns increased by nearly 30 per cent. Seminars openly advocating the use of trusts and other vehicles to avoid social security means tests are increasingly prevalent. Clearly a network of information is growing. The government has a responsibility to all Australians to shut the barn door before the horse bolts.

A key objective of the Howard government is to ensure that only those Australians who need financial support receive social security payments, thus maintaining the integrity of the social security system. I am concerned that a number of well-off and even wealthy people are using private trusts and private companies to get payments when they are clearly able to support themselves. This equity measure will address this situation. We need to ensure that all people are treated fairly and that taxpayers' money is being paid only to those Australians who genuinely need help. Most of the savings are expected to occur through the application of the assets test, and it does not come into play until significant assets are available. For example, a home owner couple can currently have more than $387,000 in assets, excluding their home, before losing all entitlement. Non-home owners have even more generous allowable levels of assets.

It is expected that many of the people who are affected by this measure will have assets and income significantly greater than the maximum limits allowed. Of course there will be exceptions to the rules where the application of a means test would be unreasonable. Centrelink and the Department of Veterans' Affairs assessors would have the capacity to remedy any unreasonable application of the means test. There will be a further discretion available to the secretary to disregard attribution under the means test in certain circumstances. There is an opportunity for individu als and organisations to comment on the proposals before the details are finalised. Written submissions are welcome, and I encourage anyone with comments on the proposal to provide a written submission to my department by 31 December this year.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. While I appreciate the minister has taken the question on notice, I am disappointed he does not know the answer, given this has been subject to considerable parliamentary questioning in this sitting week of the Senate. answer.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The level of noise is unacceptable. People are shouting across the chamber and ought not to be.

âI am frankly very disappointed that the opposition is being so critical of their colleagues in Queensland, who sponsored this event to the same tune as we did, who supported the event on exactly the same basis as we did.
