âMy question is directed to Senator Minchin, the Minister representing the Minister for Sport and Tourism. Could the minister please outline the procedure followed by the government to determine appointments to the board of the Australian Tourist Commission and what degree of consultation with the tourism industry is involved? Could the minister also explain why the government again did not use the recent opportunity to appoint a respected representative of the Australian hotels industry to the ATC board, when the industry has been providing the minister with nominees who enjoy the support of the industry since 1996?

âSenator Ridgeway's question seems to be prompted by complaints from the Australian Hotels Association about the recent appointment of former Tasmanian tourism minister, Mr Nicholas Evers, as the new Chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission, an appointment which was welcomed by the Tourism Council of Australia in a press release of Tuesday, 19 October 1999, which stated:

answer.para: Managing Director of the leading industry body, the Tourism Council of Australia, Phil Young, today welcomed the appointment of Nicholas Evers as Chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission.

The minister responsible for sport and tourism, Jackie Kelly, wrote to Mr Richard Mulcahy, the National Executive Director of the Australian Hotels Association, on 23 November in response to the sorts of questions which I guess prompt Senator Ridgeway's question. In her letter, she states:

I fully agree the most qualified person should be appointed to the ATC board and that this person should have expertise relevant to the tourism industry. In making recent appointments to the ATC board, the government considered several potential candidates, including representatives from the Australian hotels industry. The recent appointees best met the criteria as prescribed in the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987. You indicate in your letter that the ATC would benefit from industry input into their plans at the highest level. I am happy to raise this matter with the ATC board.

Inevitably, when you are making appointments of these kinds, various sectors will be unhappy with the appointments that are made. That is inevitable with every board to which the government appointments members. Obviously, we regret that the Hotels Association is not happy with the current situation. But we do go through a careful process of consultation in making these appointments. As I said, Jackie Kelly has written to the Hotels Association explaining the procedures and how the appointments were made.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the appointment does not enjoy the full support of the industry, will the government develop guidelines or a code of practice for public appointments similar to those established by the Nolan committee in the United Kingdom, and will they appoint a commissioner for public appointments to ensure that the compositions of boards like the ATC are above reproach and are able to gain full industry support and cooperation?

âThe government has well-established and very good procedures for appointing members to boards and those will continue to be followed. We do make very good appointments. As I said, the recent appointment of the chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission has been welcomed by the premier bodyâthe Tourism Council of Australia.

âMy question is to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Is the minister aware that the partnering of an established Australian company, Wizard Computer Training, in the Group 5 bid counted towards the `Australian component' and therefore assisted the Telstra-IBM-LendLease consortium Advantra to win the Group 5 tender? Can the minister confirm that a letter from his department to Wizard Computer Training dated September 1999 said:

question.para: The provision of services by Wizard Computer Training was documented in quantitative form under the Industry Development Schedule of the Group 5 contract.

Is it not the case that Advantra waited until after their successful bid was announced before delivering an ultimatum to Wizard to accept a lower price or they would lose the contract? Given the appalling conduct of Advantra, what action has the minister taken to ensure that this or any other Australian IT company has a fair go?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI do not know the circumstances surrounding that particular matter. I am happy to make some inquiries about it. All I can say is that it is only the industry development plans that are part of my responsibility. I can understand Senator Lundy's obsession with this issue. As was pointed out in the Canberra Times recently, she is basically here as the mouthpiece of the CPSU on this subject. And, as she told the Senate herself, IT outsourcing has occupied a significant proportion of her time throughout her period here in the Senate. Then what did she say in April this year? She said, `I don't have the answer. I am gravely worried.' So, in other words, she has no idea what the proper approach is to IT outsourcing. She is basically waging an ideological war against the government. She says, from Labor's point of view, they are not opposed to outsourcing. But any objective critic would conclude that Senator Lundy is certainly passionately opposed in every aspect. So I will see what additional information I can obtain in relation to the specific matter raised by Senator Lundy. Beyond that, I have nothing further to add.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not true that the minister's department `saw no reason for opposing the variation'âthat is, ditching Wizardâ`as an equivalent industry development outcome is expected'? Given that Advantra subsequently replaced Wizard Computer Training with their own contractors, how does this qualify as an equivalent industry development outcome? Why doesn't this government admit that the IT outsourcing program is allowing Aussie companies like Wizard to get nailed to the wall as a result of the appalling conduct of Advantra? Minister, will you go into bat for this Aussie IT company, or are you just going to sit back and watch them go to the wall?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe last thing we want is to see Australian companies go to the wall. The tragedy is that Senator Lundy really does not know what side of the fence to come down on in this area. Clearly, IT outsourcing has a significant capacity to substantially reduce the cost to government of providing these services. As long as there are reasonable opportunities for Australian companies to be involved and to tender and as long as the process is aboveboard, I would have thought that you get a satisfactory outcome all round. Unfortunately, Senator Lundy is simply passionately opposed to all forms of outsourcing, despite the fact that her party does not have the same view, and that really colours her thinking on the issue. I have every interest in ensuring that Wizard got a fair go and that the assessment made by my department was completely aboveboard. Beyond that, I certainly do not share the obsessions that Senator Lundy has with denigrating this process. (Time expired)

âMy question is directed to Minister Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. In June this year, Medibank Private changed its rules by amending its tables and introducing various waiting periods on ancillary health benefits. Did Medibank Private notify affected contributors as required by the ministerial directions issued in September 1996? Will Medibank Private waive these waiting periods for any affected contributors who were not notified? If so, will Medibank Private notify affected contributors to this effect and reimburse those whose claims were rejected on the basis of the unnotified waiting periods?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Harradine for the question. Yes, it is correct that in June this year a new range of extra products was introduced to more specifically target members' life stages and budgets. These product changes were made as a result of feedback from members which highlighted the need for Medibank Private to simplify its product range, introduce a national product range and make its products more competitive in the marketplace. It is important to note that, while Medibank Private has developed new products, it recognises that many existing members will choose to remain on the old products. Medibank Private has not forcibly transferred members to new products, as we believe it is a decision that each member needs to make in light of their personal circumstances. An information campaign has been developed by Medibank Private Ltd to encourage take-up of the new products.

answer.para: The official launch of the new productsâinvolving a new advertising campaign, which included a new television commercial, newspaper advertising and supporting merchandise materialâcommenced in July. At the same time, an extensive mailing campaign for Medibank Private Ltd members was undertak en. This campaign took the form of a four-page special edition of its Enjoy magazine. Even though this publicity occurred, there seem to have been some Medibank Private members who do not know how these new products operate. Ministers Wooldridge and Fahey expect Medibank Private to deliver a high standard of service to their members.

In the case that Senator Harradine referred to, Medibank Private appears to have dropped the ball with some of its members. Minister Wooldridge's office has had discussions with Medibank Private with regard to this issue. Medibank Private has indicated that a personalised letter to select Medibank Private members who have super extras and special extras will be distributed in December, inviting members to change to one of the new extra products.

In addition, Medibank Private Ltd members who are scheduled to receive a renewal notice during the next 13 weeks will also be advised of the new products. Discussions will continue to ensure that Medibank Private members are not disadvantaged by not being aware of these new products. The government and the Senate encourage private health insurance funds to develop a simpler and better range of private health insurance products, some of which include no-gaps cover. âMy question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Will the minister please inform the Senate of the government's ongoing efforts to tackle the tragedy of indigenous family violence in our communities?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Ferris for the question, for her continued interest in this problem and for the initiatives she has taken in her own state. Indigenous family violence is an issue of enormous concern to the Commonwealth government. The distress, the heartache and the despair of family violence touches the lives of so many people in the wider community. It should be of grave concern to the nation that some women and children continue to experience appalling levels of physical and psychological abuse.

answer.para: The incidence of violence in indigenous communities is disproportionately high and must be given priority and attention by indigenous communities themselves and by all levels of government. The most recent reported incident occurred only last weekend, where media reports indicate alcohol related violence forced 12 medical staff to evacuate a community. It is absolutely unacceptable for women and children, in particular, to live their lives in such threatening and dangerous circumstances.

That is why, in collaboration with ATSIC, I proposed at the Ministerial Council on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs meeting in September that governments around Australia commit themselves to a national coordinated strategy to address the problem. I got that commitment from the states and territories, and I congratulate them for their support. As a follow-up to that agreement, on Friday I will convene a working group with representatives from each state and territory, ATSIC, the Torres Strait Regional Authority and communities themselves. This meeting is the first step in progressing and implementing a national strategy aimed at putting a stop to the abuses suffered by indigenous women and children.

The states and territories are primarily responsible for addressing family violence. However, the federal government is so concerned about the problem that I am pleased to announce today that the Commonwealth will devote $6 million from the $25 million Partnership Against Domestic Violence program to target family violence in indigenous communities. I would like to acknowledge the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Jocelyn Newman, for her support in making this initiative possible and for her own interest in this particular aspect of her portfolio.

Since 1990, indigenous deaths from family violence have been almost 30 per cent higher nationally than indigenous deaths in custody for the same period. Almost halfâ46 per centâof all hospital separations among females for intentional injury are indigenous women. Among indigenous women, intentional injury accounts for more hospital separations than does diabetes or cancer and almost as many for infections and parasitic diseases. A recent Australian Bureau of Statistics and Australian Institute of Health and Welfare study highlighted that, in 1998, indigenous children constituted 17.4 per cent of the total national number of children on care and protection orders. In other words, depending on which state or territory they lived in, indigenous children were five to eight times more likely than other children to be subject to abuse and neglect. It is a very shameful story.

In order to get a firmer understanding of the many factors involved from a community perspective, I held a roundtable in July this year, bringing people who live and work with this problem on a daily basisâall indigenous people who are concerned about this problemâtogether. This discussion highlighted the need for community ownership of the problem and community involvement in solutions. The Commonwealth has taken a leading role in this issue and has demonstrated its commitment to addressing this serious problem. It is important that this issue be not politicised. It is a very important action that we have taken, and I believe it will lead to a solution, or at least an attempt at a solution, based on community involvement.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, representing the Minister for Trade. What is Australia's position on the establishment of a working party on biotechnology under the WTO in the upcoming meeting in Seattle? What would the impact of that working party be on the international biosafety protocol currently under negotiation, which is aimed at preventing indiscriminate exporting of genetically modified organisms? Will the working party undermine responsible regulation of genetically modified organisms under the guise of free trade?
âHave you got notice of this question?
âOrder! It is not your turn to ask a question, Senator Carr.
âYou've been given a copy of this.
âOrder!

âBut the trouble is that she changed it during question time. I am sure that it was not a deliberate plot, although I have to say the question on WTO and biodiversity is easier than the question on WTO and biosafety. Nevertheless, we will give it a go.

answer.para: As the honourable senator will know, negotiations are continuing towards development of a protocol on biosafety that will allow the transmission of LMOs, living modified organisms, across state borders in a way that is designed to be beneficial whilst at the same time providing proper notice to recipient states so that they can make their own responsible decisions in relation to importation. Negotiations have been protracted but are ongoing and we hope will be concluded in the not too distant future. Certainly, as I said, implicit within that is a belief that, at least in some circumstances, this transmission can be beneficial to recipient statesâit might be in terms of improving agricultural production or in a number of other waysâand, therefore, there should not be unnecessary inhibitions in the trade.

Is that consistent with WTO? As far as I am concerned, it is because the recipient state is entitled to make its own laws and set its own standards in relation to importation, provided that those rules are for purposes that are not simply trade related. They may be, for example, the rules that AQIS applies in this country in relation to quarantine; they might be other legitimate environmental considerations or health considerations. If they are a disguised trade barrier, they would, of course, fall foul of the WTO rules. But the purpose in concluding the biosafety protocol is not to provide for an opportunity to avoid WTO obligations but for the purposes that I have just stated.

In relation to the question as to whether a biotechnology working group within the WTO would assist any of these or other related questions, I am not sure what position the Minister for Trade has taken in that regard but I will find out and let the honourable senator know. I hope that answers all of her question. I was rudely interrupted by the opposition during the asking of it so I might have missed something, but no doubt that will be picked up in the supplementary.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I recognise that the minister is representing the Minister for Trade and the Democrats were anxious to have an answer, and that is why we advised him. I thank the minister for his response and I look forward to the response from the Minister for Trade as to whether or not this country supports a working party on biotechnology. But I ask the minister: can he guarantee, and can he get a guarantee from the Minister for Trade, that such a working party, if we support it, will not constrain national labelling schemes for products that contain genetically modified organisms?

question.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Conroy and Senator Faulkner asked me some questions yesterday regarding APEC Technomart III, which I took on notice. I now seek leave to table and incorporate the responses to the honourable senators' questions.

answer.para: Leave granted.
The responses read as followsâ
Senator Faulkner and Senator Conroy asked me some questions yesterday regarding APEC Technomart III which I took on notice.
I now seek leave to table the response to the Honourable senators questions
Did the Federal Government give any other support to PacRim Technomart in relation to APEC Technomart III before the June 1999 contract was signed?
What other support, financial or in-kind, did the Federal Government give to Ms Maestracci or PacRim Technomart in organising APEC Technomart III?

For more than a year, beginning at least with my predecessor's media statement of 9 October 1998 welcoming APEC badging, the Federal Government has been completely open about its sponsorship of APEC Technomart III. The Government supported APEC endorsement and continued to support the event within APEC economies. This was an important part of sponsorship of the event and this has never been denied.
Following the Commonwealth securing APEC badging, the Queensland Government also welcomed APEC endorsement.

The former Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism and the Current Minister for Industry, Science and Resources filmed promotional videos for the event, the Prime Minister wrote a letter of support for Technomart, and the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources wrote a letter of support for the Venture Capital Forum.
As part of its sponsorship of Technomart to APEC economies, the Department of Industry, Science and Resources assisted PacRim in three ways;
. helping to arrange information briefings through Australian posts, both before and after the contract was signed;
. raising Technomart, through Australia's Senior Official, at APEC's second Senior Officials' Meeting held in New Zealand in May 1999; and
. facilitating the promotion of APEC Technomart at other expositions, for example Oztech 99 held in Chinese Taipei in April 1999.

1. When the Federal Government proposed to APEC that Australia should host APEC Technomart III and when Australia subsequently provided progress reports to APEC, was Ms Maestracci nominated as the project overseer?
2. Did she not represent Australia and the Federal Government in that capacity?

3. Can the Minister confirm that, while Australia's nominated APEC Contact for APEC Technomart III was Ms Judith Maestracci from PacRim Technomart Inc. the nominated contacts for all other participating APEC economies were government officials from each country's respective industry department?
1. Ms Maestracci was nominated Project Overseer of the APEC Technomart III project because she was the Project Manager for the organisers for the event.

Each APEC project has a Project Overseer. The Project Overseer is defined within APEC as a "person, institution, corporation or executing agent who is responsible for supervising the project and reporting on its progress to the relevant APEC fora" It is by no means unusual in the APEC Industrial Science and Technology Working Group for a Project Overseer to be from the non-government sector.

Each APEC economy has nominated contact points within the working group. This contact point is the general point of contact for all projects within that economy and for other matters relating to working group activities. Contact Points from all economies are government officials.
2 Ms Maestracci represented PacRim, not Australia and not the Federal Government.
3. The Australian contact point for the relevant working group was and still is, an official from my Department.

Each APEC project has a Project Overseer. The Project Overseer is defined within APEC as a "person, institution, corporation or executing agent who is responsible for supervising the project and reporting on its progress to the relevant APEC fora". It is by no means unusual in the APEC Industrial Science and Technology Working Group for a Project Overseer to be from the private sector.

Ms Judith Maestracci was the private sector Project Overseer for the private sector APEC Technomart III project. The role of Project Overseer includes acting as the contact for technical aspects of the particular project and Ms Judith Maestracci was the technical contact for this project.

In her capacity as Project Overseer, Ms Maestracci was a member of the Australian delegation to the March and August 1999 Working Group meetings, where she promoted Technomart to APEC officials, and she presented a progress report at the August 1999 meeting.
At all times Ms Maestracci represented PacRim and not the Federal Government.
It is common in APEC for a Project Overseer to be from the non-government sector.
For instance:
. the Project Overseer for Thailand's "Gender Stocktaking of IST WG Projects" Project is from the Women's Action and Research Institute, and
. the Project overseer for Australia's "Gonococcal Antibiotic Susceptibility" project is from the WHO Collaborative Centre for STD and HIV, which is based at the Prince of Wales Hospital in Sydney.

Regarding the 16th APEC Industrial Science and Technology Working Group meeting in Hong Kong in March 1999: Did the Australian Delegate list include four senior officials from the Department of Industry Science and Resources, including one senior official acting as `Lead Shepherd' using APEC terminology. Did the Australian delegate list also include Ms Judith Maestracci from PacRim Technomart?

The Australian delegate list to the 16th Industrial Science and Technology Working Group meeting comprised four officials from the Department of Industry, Science and Resources, including one senior official acting as "Lead Shepherd". It also included an official from the Department of Health and Aged Care.
In addition to government officials, delegations to the Working Group include individuals from academia and the private sector. These delegates do not represent the government of their economies.

The Australian delegation to the 16th Industrial Science and Technology Working Group meeting included two such non-government delegatesâMs Maestracci of PacRim Technomart and the Chairman of the International Relations Committee of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Industry Science and Resources (Senator Minchin), to questions without notice asked by Senators Cook and Conroy and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) today, relating to government sponsorship of the industry and technology exhibition, APEC Technomart III.

The answers given by Senator Minchin in question time today and earlier this week show a pattern of failure at the very worst or an abdication of responsibility at the very best by this government in its obligations to the information technology industry in this nation. The biggest industry in the world these days is information technology and telecommunications. It now outranks the automotive industry as the biggest single industry, well ahead of the next placed industriesâHollywood and the music industryâtaken together. It is growing faster than any other industry in the history of the industrialised world, and in the next five years is going to triple in size from what we know now.

One of the reasons why the trade deficit in Australia is blowing out to a record level is because we are a massive importer of information technology. Look at the labels on every PC in this country, and you will see they are made somewhere else. We import that technology. Therefore, when this country decides to try to promote information and telecommunications technology manufactured in Australia in order to promote an Australian presence in this multi-trillion dollar industry, it is to try to get the Australian label up there, to create jobs in this nation and to put us in the forefront of brain based industry for the next millennium.

The focus on doing that was Technomart III, an APEC initiativeâsuccessful in Technomart I, very successful in Technomart II, supported by the host governments in those countries, asked for by Australia within APEC and granted. Australia was in fact made the chair of Technomart III, to guide the development of this promotion on the Gold Coast in Australia earlier this month. With that background, you would have expected this to be an outstanding success, that the government would have encouraged Australian producers to make sure that they used this international APEC forum to showcase their wares and pick up markets in the high growth industries of Asia.

This was on our doorstep. This was a chance for Australian information technology and telecommunications industries to pick up a slice of the biggest and fastest growing market in the world in the biggest and fastest growing market area in the worldâinformation technology. But it failed. The whole thing collapsed. And that is why it is an absolute failure at the door of this government. The best you can say is they abdicated their responsibility. None of the answers given by this minister can persuade anyone that anything else is the truth. They have let down this nation, the youth of this nation who aspire to jobs in this industry sector in the future and Australian participants in the information technology industry.

Technomart III collapsed, and the government's excuse is, `We farmed it out to the private sector and the private sector failed.' That says three things about this government: they do not care about the information technology industry, they have never made an effort to ensure that it succeeds and, when they did farm it out, they did not do the necessary checks to see that they gave it to someone who would look after this industry and protect our growth in this area. To now blame them for the failure is to overlook their own abdication of responsibility. This industry is so important to the jobs future of this nation that they should have got it right. They did not.

The Australian government chaired the APEC committee. The Prime Minister wrote the foreword to the publication inviting companies to participate. The government then outsourced it and the private company collapsed. The government has now distanced itself from Judith Maestracci who was the Australian delegate to APEC at the Hong Kong meeting that made these decisions. That is what the APEC web site says. This minister, in the face of that abject failure, should now, under the Westminster parliamentary system, take the responsibility, not blame his public servants. Certainly he should not blame the private sector. He should resign. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhat a lot of nonsense. Senator Richard Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, is a minister who is on top of his portfolio. He has an absolutely committed approach to developing information technology and is leading Australia and this government into the future with his support of information technology. I remind the Senate that recently a world e-commerce conference was held in Perth at the Burswood Island Resort Casino. Why was that held in Australia?
âSenator Eggleston, you are speaking in response to the answers given by Senator Minchin.

âThat is all very wellâI will be addressing that. Why was this e-commerce conference held in Australia? It was held here because Australia is regarded as a leader in information technology development, and the Australian and West Australian governments are recognised as being governments which are very committed to supporting information technology and the development of e-commerce and all that goes with it.

speech.para: Let us now look at this Technomart conference. First of all, the point has been made that the Technomart conference was a private sector run conference; that it was not a government conference. It was supported and endorsed by the government but it was not run by the government. The opposition are saying the event's financial difficulties are somehow the fault of the federal government. That is, I must say, an absurd accusation. Even Senator Cook knows that that is absolute and utter nonsense.

Let us go to the history of this, shall we? Back in 1997 a private associationâthe Licensing Executive Society of Australia and New Zealandâdeveloped the concept of having a major technology conference on the Gold Coast this year. In March 1998 they approached the then Department of Industry, Science and Tourism to explore the possibility of the Australian government providing some financial support for this conference. A departmental officer at that meeting noted the similarity between their concept and technomarts sponsored by APEC that had been held in Korea in 1995 and in Taiwan in 1998. The department agreed that, as part of its possible support, the department would consider obtaining APEC badging so that the event would become an APEC Technomart. The organisers sought some $236,000 in funding through the technology diffusion program. The department rejected that application at that time as it did not fit within the guidelines for that program. But the department recognised that the Technomart would be useful in promoting Australian innovation, so an in principle decision was made that some support would be provided without any dollar figure being agreed upon. In August 1998 the department sought APEC's approval for the conference to be called a Technomart, and that approval was given.

As with previous Technomart conferences, it was agreed that the conference would largely be funded by the private sector. Major sponsors had been found and the exhibitors at the conference were required to pay for space. Both the Australian and the Queensland governments offered some financial support, but they did not put together the finance to hold this conference. I emphasise that it was a private conference. The Australian government held the view that sponsorship of this event was appropriate and entirely consistent with APEC values and that it would, being privately funded, provide an opportunity for the organisers to maximise commercial participation. So there we are. This was a privately supported conference.

I come back to the point I made at the beginning: Senator Cook's accusation that the Australian government is in some way responsible for this privately funded conference collapsing, as it did after a couple of days, is absurd. It reflects not on the government but on the organisers of the conference. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âSenator Minchin has characteristically spent the past month curling himself up into the smallest possible target over the failure of APEC Technomart III. He wanted to avoid being a target for this Commonwealth government sponsored, APEC badged, international technology expo. No wonder he did not want to be in the firing line. This is the same Senator Minchin who spent the Republic campaign saying, `You can't trust politicians.' Well, he is right on one count: you cannot trust Senator Minchin. He has shown his form on this particular issue. He has failed to accept his responsibility for this international humiliation.

speech.para: His answers to questions surrounding the relationship of the private sector organisers of the technology expo on the Gold Coast have been as vague and as disingenuous as you could possibly get. Senator Minchin repeats the mantra that the Commonwealth was merely a sponsorâlike Boeing or the Gold Coast City Council or the Queensland government. What is becoming more and more obvious is that Senator Minchin and his department had a huge part in setting the scene for this disaster and then did absolutely nothing about it when APEC Technomart III fell in a heap.

Let us not ignore the implications of this. Two other APEC countriesâKorea and Taiwanâran technology expos for APEC member countries. They were run by the respective industry departments of those countries. They attracted 30,000 delegates each, through governments, universities and private sector companies. Australia's attempt to host a technomart just fell apart. It folded on day two of an eight-day expo. It left delegates stranded and bills unpaid, and it delivered an international humiliation to Australia and Senator Minchin. That is what we are facing here. Of course, in the eyes of the Pacific Rim countries, no doubt we must have appeared as second rate and incompetent, as does Senator Minchin.

It is not really until the failure of APEC Technomart that Senator Minchin starts the distancing exercise that he has been involved in. It was a very different matter last yearâvery different. What about 9 October last year, when the then industry minister, Mr Moore, issued a press release trumpeting the APEC badging of Technomart, under the heading `APEC endorses major Australian technology expo' and saying in the first paragraph:
APEC has endorsed Australia's proposalâ
let me say that again: `Australia's proposal'â
to host a major technology exposition on the Gold Coast in October 1999.
The second paragraph says:
Mr Moore said gaining APEC endorsement for the event Technomart III was a great achievement for Australia.
I repeat: `Australia'.

What Senator Minchin is trying to do is to say that the Australian government was not really involved at all: we are going to duck-shove it to poor old Ms Judith Maestracci and poor old PacRim Technomart Inc. There is no mention of PacRim Technomart Inc. in this press releaseânone. There is no mention of Judith Maestracci in this particular press release. In fact, in this press release there is no mention of private sector involvement at all. It is an `Australian' exerciseâimplying an Australian government exerciseâin this press release.

So that is the problem for Senator Minchin and this government. This has been a humiliation for Senator Minchin, for Australia, and Senator Minchin should front up to his responsibility and admit in large part the responsibility he has for the failure of Technomart III. He ought to do something about repairing the extraordinary damage that is being done to Australia's and his own department's reputation in this fiasco and debacle that he was responsible for. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWe have the opposition getting up here today, trying to make something out of something that has happened that is unfortunate, and trying to blame the federal government and, in particular, Senator Minchin for it. There are a lot of issues around. We have our troops in East Timor trying to do the right thing and control the peace there and doing a great job; we have an economy that is bubbling along very well; and we have unemployment coming down in this country. But what of the so-called constructive opposition, as Mr Beazley would like to paint them as being? What have they got to say? What have they got to do? All they can do is come in here and try to pick out a conference that had part-sponsorship from the Commonwealth government and part-sponsorship from Boeing.

speech.para: We have a press release from Mr Jim Elder, who is the Deputy Premier and Minister for State Development of the Queensland Labor government, and they were part-sponsors of this event on the Gold Coast. Prior to the Technomart III, there were two very successful Technomart conferences held in Korea and another place that I have forgotten. The group here tried to organise a conference, a showcase of technology. And why wouldn't they want do something like this in Australia?

talk.start.para: âHow many people went to the Taiwan one? Thirty thousand.
âI can do without the interjections, Senator Conroy.
âHow many came to Australia? Two hundred.

âOkay. There might have been 30,000 go to the Taiwan conference but, unfortunately, for one reason or another this particular conference failed. As the minister pointed out, it was a private sector run conference on the Gold Coast. It closed after two days, due to financial problems. We get the opposition coming in here and trying to make a big deal out of it and trying to pin it on the Commonwealth government and, in particular, on the minister, when in fact it was a joint concept put together by a private company and sponsored by a lot of people. Why shouldn't the Commonwealth want to put money into something like this to promote information technology when, as has been pointed out by Senator Eggleston, we have a very strong background in IT and are one of the leading IT countries in the world?

speech.para: The Commonwealth government is not responsible for this falling apart. They provided finance towards it. There have been other well-known failures over the years at all sorts of conferences held around Australia. I do not recall in the 12 years that I have been in this place coming in here and attacking the then Labor government over massive failures of things that they sponsored. I do recall when I was in charge of Waste Watch drawing attention to some of the huge amounts of largess that the previous government indulged in. I recall that they spent money on heated dog kennels for the Prime Minister's dog and on sponsoring programs for left-footed lesbian surfboard riders and things like that. They were wastes of money, but in this particular case in good faith the department partly sponsored what was mooted to be a very successful technology expo. Unfortunately, for one reason or another, it did not work.

I do not believe anything will be gained from the point of view of Australia by coming in here and publicly bagging people for trying to organise something that would benefit private enterprise and our IT producers in this country. I cannot see any reason why any constructive opposition would do this; an opposition which supposedly has all these great policies which we have not seen yet. Where are their policies on unemployment? People are asking where their policies are on unemployment. Where are their policies on jobs? All we can get out of Mr Beazley is that they will put it off until next year.

I do not know how much it is costing to run the Senate today, but I believe it would be quite a substantial amount. Yet here we are spending half an hour talking about a conference that went wrong; a conference that the Commonwealth partly sponsored in good faith. We have the opposition coming in here trying to denigrate what seemed at the time to be a very good idea. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhat we have seen here today is more and more dissembling by the minister. Senator Hill is now walking away. It is nice of you to leap to Senator Minchin's defence so readily. It is now 45 minutes, and I am glad you have decided to leap to the minister's defence. He certainly sticks it in your back whenever he gets a chance, so I am glad you have taken the chance.
âAddress the chair please, Senator Conroy.
âThank you, Madam Deputy President. Today we have the press release from John Moore dated Friday, 9 October 1998:

speech.para: APEC endorses major Australian technology expo. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, John Moore, today confirmed that the APEC group had endorsed Australia's proposal to host a major technology exposition on the Gold Coast in October 1999. Mr Moore said, `Gaining APEC endorsement for the event Technomart III was a great achievement for Australia.' The APEC Technomart III will be the centrepiece of technology 1999, a comprehensive program of seminars, workshops, business matching programs and new technology demonstra tions. At least 30,000 Australian and international visitors are expected to participate.

What happened? As we have already heard, it collapsed on day two of an eight-day seminar. Delegates were left stranded in their hotels. Hotels were told that bills could not be paid, and delegates were turfed out. The minister for industry, Senator Minchin, turned around and made the following statements: `The Commonwealth was neither the instigator nor organiser of the event. The only role that the Commonwealth played in the event was providing $200,000 of sponsorship'.

This is where we see the minister taking a little walk away from the involvement of his own department. In the answers to questions on notice which we were given not 20 minutes ago by the minister it begins to become clear why he wants to walk away. We asked questions like, `Did the government put out a tender for companies for this?' The answer was, `No, they came to us.'

The next question was, `If a company walks up to you with a proposal and says "Hey, we have this great idea," what does the department do to investigate the bona fides?' What investigations did the minister of the department carry out into this PacRim Technomart, including their experience and financial situation, before promoting them? What investigations did the minister of the department carry out into Judith Maestracci? What was the government doing?

The government want to say that they had no involvement, but even these answers which we have received verbally and on notice today lead to more questions. They do not provide us with answers. The answers given lead to more questions. It begins to become clear that the minister's own department helped to arrange information briefings through Australia Post, to raise Technomart through Australia's senior official at APEC's second senior officials meeting held in New Zealand and to facilitate its promotion of APEC at other expositions.

Ms Maestracci attended a number of APEC forums to deal with this. She attended the delegation. The question is: who paid for Ms Maestracci to attend the delegation? Who paid her air fares and her accommodation? Was it paid for by Technomart? Was it paid for under the sponsorship agreement? We want to know what is in the sponsorship agreement. Why will the minister not table the sponsorship agreement in the chamber so we can see where Australian taxpayers' dollars went to? We will then see where the management and misuse of funds has gone to, because proper controls have not been put on its supervision. We have seen the minister try to run away. We know that Technomart, as a concept, is a winner. Some 30,000 went to Korea and some 30,000 went to Taiwan, yet 200 came to Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhat a waste of time we have had here in the Senate both yesterday and today on this issue. It really shows the paucity of this opposition in terms of bringing up issues that take the fight right up to the government. Let us look at the issues they have brought up here in the last two days. This opposition is all over the place. There is no strategy. There is no consistency in its attack.

speech.para: Senator Calvert interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âAnd there is no leadership. The basic reason underlying all of that is that they do not have a vision or a policy direction for Australia. I am almost lost for words on what they are doing, but it isn't very much, and it isn't very much in terms of being an effective opposition.
âIf you're lost for words, sit down and stop talking.
âOrder! Senator Faulkner!

âYou are not an effective opposition. You keep coming in here with totally trivial issues, issues of no great import to the direction of this country. That is compared to this government and its success after success with the economy, foreign policy and a whole range of issues that are setting the right direction for this country as we head into the new millennium.

speech.para: Let us have a look at this issue of Technomart, which we are talking about today. We are talking about a loss of federal funding of $200,000. I would have thought this was a much more appropriate subject for the estimates, not for this chamber. You wasted a quarter of an hour yesterday, a quarter of an hour today in question time and another half an hour nowâwe are up to an hour. If you apportion that as a cost to the Senate, we are probably over $200,000 already. It would be more appropriate perhaps as a question on notice to the Senate through the estimates process.

talk.start.para: âYou're a complete failure. The party you're a member of hates your guts. You'll never amount to anything in politics. Get out!
âOrder! Senator Faulkner!

âOf course Senator Faulkner is in here sledging again. That is his claim to fame. All he can do is sit there and sledge. He would not have a policy idea in his head, and his line of questioning over the last two days certainly shows that.

speech.para: As I have listened to the questions and answers and to the debate on the motion to take note of answers, I have been waiting for the real in-depth issue to come out. The answer is: there is no in-depth issue at all. This is a conference that has been held three times now internationally. It did not succeed as a conference in Australia. It was backed by broad sponsorshipâby the federal government, the state Labor government, the Gold Coast City Council, Qantas and Boeing, Griffith and Bond universities and the Royal Pines Resort. They were all sponsors for this event. This was done by the government because APEC required this sort of backing.

We did that, and we as a government were approached by Judith Maestracci and her organisation to actually set this up and run it. Having looked at it, this government, the state government and all those sponsors agreed that that was a very good thing to run. We cannot guarantee commercial success in these sorts of things, just as the Labor government before this government could not guarantee these things.

I recall very clearly an estimates when we were in opposition. There was a conference in Wollongong towards which DEETYA had put $1 million. The conference failed and the money was wasted. There was no accountability in that process. These sorts of things have tended to happen through government over time, and it is total humbug for this opposition to come in here on this issue. I cannot recall in the case of the Wollongong conference that we ever brought it up in this chamber. We did it in the right place. We did it in estimates.

I would invite the opposition to go back to the estimates process, raise the questions with the appropriate officers and get the detailed answers they are after, and then light will be shed on this thing. The opposition should not come in and waste the time of the Senate, as they have done now for one hour, and cost the Senate far more than the amount lost through the failure of this conference.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I have been misrepresented.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI wish to make a personal explanation on the outrageous page 1 article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Margo Kingston entitled `Labor sells out minorities', and it is that particular part of the article which describes Labor's efforts to revise the Senate standing orders on the pecuniary interests of gay and lesbian partners as `pathetic'.

speech.para: Late yesterday afternoon, I was told by a third party in Parliament House that Ms Kingston was preparing a `bucket job' on the way that Labor had approached changes to the Senate standing orders surrounding the pecuniary interests register. I found it extraordinary that Ms Kingston did not contact me prior to writing the `bucket job' to assess the facts of the situation, given that Senator Greig and I were the only senators to make substantive speeches on this issue in the chamber. In fact, having heard from this third party, I had to phone Ms Kingston late in the day to explain to her what prompted Labor to assist Senator Greig in getting these rules changed. It was painfully obvious to me, I might say, that Ms Kingston had already written what was an entirely misleading newspaper article.

I made the following points to Ms Kingston but, as they went unreported, I will make them here. Democrat Senator Greig correctly identified the deficiency in the Senate standing orders in relation to couples in a same sex relationship but put forward an amendment which was legally flawed. I want to say, and I mentioned this in the chamber, that I encouraged Senator Greig to take his proposed standing order and his concerns to the Senate Procedure Committee, where changes to the Senate standing and sessional orders are sorted out in the presence of all parties.

The committee's recommendation on the rule change for the declaration of pecuniary interests of same sex partners was supported by all parties at that Procedure Committee meeting, including the representative of the Australian Democrats on the Procedure Committee. However, as it turned out, Senator Greig was not satisfied with the wording and he proposed another form of words in a letter that he circulated to all senators.

Having received that, I sought legal advice on behalf of the opposition to see if Senator Greig's proposal was watertight and worthy of support. The advice that I received was that it was not watertight. My motivation in proposing an amendment to the Procedure Committee report to significantly improve the proposalâand it certainly embraced much of what Senator Greig had argued forâwas to try to make sure that same sex couples were covered by our Senate standing orders in an inclusive gender and sexuality neutral form of words, and that was eventually adopted by the Senate unanimously. There was no voice against that. There was no division called. The only speakers in a substantive sense were Senator Greig and myself. I think a government minister made a one-sentence contribution only. This was explained, as I indicated, to the journalist concerned.

For some reason, the journalist, Ms Kingston, is unhappy with clear, unambiguous and non-discriminatory legal language. I think most people in the community, whether they are heterosexual or gay, would prefer their laws to be clear rather than symbolic if we face a risk of symbolic language weakening the rules. That was the legal advice on which I operated, and I did explain this to Ms Kingston.

I want to make it absolutely clear that the opposition was not running an appeasement case, as Ms Kingston indicates on page 1 of the Sydney Morning Herald. I was endeavouring on behalf of the opposition as a member of the Procedure Committee to make the standing orders of this chamber legally watertight and to ensure that it recognised properly all forms of relationships. I happen to think this is not only a victory for people in same sex relationships, but it is a victory for fairness and it is a victory for proper accountability in this place and within the Senate's pecuniary interests register. For the journalist concerned, Ms Kingston, to write this article and state baldly that Labor has sold out the gay community when Labor worked very hard to sort out this discrimination in the Senate standing orders and when my colleague the member for Grayndler, Mr Anthony Albanese, is attempting to fix the problem of superannuation arrangements for same sex couples, I think, is absolutely outrageous. The Labor Party has been at the forefront of progressive legal reform for gays and lesbians, and I think we are still there.

I do not say these things lightly. Madam Deputy President, you and other senators in the chamber would know that I rarely make a personal explanation and almost never, in the more than 10 years I have been in this place, have I complained either in the chamber or outside about things written in the press about me or about my party. I tend to have a pretty good record of copping it sweet, but I am not going to cop sweet this outrageous slur on myself and my colleagues under any circumstances.

Let me also make a point about Mr Albanese's billâthe Superannuation (Entitlements of Same Sex Couples) Bill 1999âwhich has been linked into the same article and which was reintroduced into the House of Representatives by Mr Albanese on Monday, 22 November this year. This is the third time the bill has been introduced into the House of Representatives. It has lapsed twice due to the government not listing it for debate.

The Federal Parliamentary Labor Party remains unanimous in its support for Mr Albanese's private member's bill. This bill was not on the agenda for debate at yesterday's caucus meeting, if that is an implication anyone might draw. As it turns outâand this is a political pointâit is the Howard government that do not support this bill. That is their right. This is not the time to debate that issue.

talk.start.para: âNeither did the Hawke or Keating governments, to be fair about it.

âAlthough several members of the coalition, Senator Campbell, have stated publicly that they do. So let us be fair about it. The personal explanation I am making is not about the role of the government in relation to this.

speech.para: The amendments to the Senate standing orders have no relation to this bill. I think the confusion caused by this article by Ms Kingston that I have been speaking about in relation to the bill should forthwith be rectified by the Sydney Morning Herald, and I hope they do that. In relation to the other matters that are contained within my personal explanation, I have written to the Editor of the Sydney Morning Herald. I hope the Editor publishes my letter. As I said to you and the chamber, Madam Deputy President, I do not do this lightly. You know I do not do it often. But I am not going to cop what is an outrageous and unfair slur on not only myself but on all my colleagues in the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to make a brief personal explanation on the same matter.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âThe first sentence of Ms Margo Kingston's article in today's Sydney Morning Herald reads:

speech.para: Labor has virtually abandoned its minority rights agenda, leaving refugees, gays, children of migrants and just about any other minority with only Australian Democrats support.

That is patently untrue. The Leader of the Opposition has just given a very cogent defence of Labor's position in this matter. Let me put the Greens' position. I have throughout my four years in this place assiduously defended the rights of refugees, gays, children of migrants and just about any other minority that is defenceless. I am sure the house will recognise that has been the case. At no time did Margo Kingston approach me about this matter at all. At no time in this period of parliament has she approached me on any matter at all. I have rung the Editor of the Sydney Morning Herald today and failed to get through, but I am awaiting a return call.

Like Senator Faulkner, I cop it sweet in most matters which you read in the newspapersâyou have to. You are in public life; you expect that. But when on the front page of what is recognised as one of the leading newspapers in this country, if not in the world, a story begins with a patently false statementâand it is a news story, not an opinion pieceâthen there is something very, very wrong about that reportage.

In effect, it traduces the Greens' long and honourable role in this place defending minorities that sometimes even the Democrats have not stood up to defend. We will find in the debate later this afternoon that the Greens' position in defending refugees, for example, and children of migrants is second to none. I am not going to get into an exposition on the policies of the Greens. What is at stake here is the veracity of a very prominent political commentator: she is dead wrong. She is factually wrong, and she has failed her profession by not checking with me or, as far as I know, any other Green in this country before she made this bald assertion and went on to compound it with further statements.

On the issue of ending discrimination against the gay and lesbian community let me say this: the aim must be to get gender neutral language because that is non-discriminatory. Senator Faulkner, I believe, is right when he says that she is using a terminological device to give a totally false impression to the community about Labor's position in ensuring there was a change to the rules earlier this week, and that change to the rules does benefit a minority group in the community by getting rid of a patently discriminatory clause in the rules.

What are parliamentarians to do if when you act in that fashion you get clobbered and misrepresented on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald? As Senator Faulkner has cogently said, there does need to be a rectification. My door is open to Margo Kingston. My door is open to the Sydney Morning Herald and, as does the Labor Party, I would expect a statement of correction to be given by the Sydney Morning Herald.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to make a very brief statement on this matter.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI am very happy with the explanation given by Senator Faulkner, but I would need to draw it to the attention of Senator Greig in case he wants to say anything on the matter. I think perhaps the two statements went a little bit beyond personal explanations but because of the gravity of the matter I think it was a good thing that the Senate gave indulgence in that way. Certainly in the future we would seek that this matter be taken up in the way which has been suggested.

debateinfo.title: CHILD CARE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (HIGH NEED REGIONS) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Chris Evans) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to continue a system of child care planning and allocation of resources for regions of high need, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Chris Evans) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ
Child care in Australia is in desperate need of stability. More than 280 child-care centres have closed over the last couple of years disrupting children, families, businesses and staff.
The Commonwealth's needs based planning controls have made a contribution to stabilising a sector undergoing enormous dislocation and change.
The announcement by Minister Newman in July this year that she was to abandon needs based planning control left the whole sector shocked and dumbfounded.
Child care in Australia has suffered grievously under the policies of the Howard Government.
The child-care sector cares for and nurtures the youngest and most vulnerable members of our community.
We as a community must ensure that the care of our children occurs in a secure, stable and professional environment.
Planning for the development of the child-care sector can contribute to promoting that stable, professional and caring environment.
Abandonment of any planning controls will expose child care and the children it serves to further dislocation and turmoil, to the detriment of all.

The Childcare Legislation Amendment (High Need Regions) Bill 1999 is an attempt to force the Government to accept its responsibilities to Australian children and families and continue a national planning regime.
We would not accept the Commonwealth abandoning their responsibilities in education, health or aged care, so why should we accept such irresponsibility in childcare ?

When the Coalition won office March 1996, they inherited a child care system that was acknowledged to be one of the best in the world. Unfortunately for the families who rely on this service, or would like to if they could afford it, child care has been disrupted and damaged by the government's determination to cut back heavily on public support for family's child care needs. The sector is now in a state of turmoil.

Since 1996 the Howard government has cut $850 million out of the child care systems with disastrous results for families. About $100 million was taken out of the system by the abolition of the operational subsidy to community-based child care. For the most part, however, the spending cuts have been to Child Care Assistance, and as such have impacted equally on families who use private child care centres and community centres.

The Government froze the indexation of Child Care Assistance and Rebate for two years (1997-98), restricted the number of hours that can be funded, and reduced income test concessions for larger families. Not surprisingly, average parents' out of pocket costs have risen by more than twenty dollars per week as a result.

Substantial evidence is coming to light that these cost pressures are forcing parents to pull children out of regulated child care and that lower income families are having to withdraw from the regulated child care system altogether. Child care professionals report that children are being `churned' through care, as parents reduce their hours of care (many centres are now catering for twice as many children, each of whom are staying for shorter periods of care) and that families are resorting to stressful `patchwork' care arrangements, where children are cared for by several different people in one week.

The Minister has insisted that parents have other resources to fall back on. Earlier this year she was interviewed for an ABC television report on childcare. Her comments are revealing of the attitudes underlying the Government's child care policies and are worth repeating here. Senator Newman explained: `If the parents decide this is too expensive and we are not going to do it, they will find other alternatives. It may be family day care, it may be sharing the care between family members.' Asked by the reporter, `They may not have other alternatives?', the Minister insisted, `Well they do. They do. They do.' The Labor party has news for the Minister: many parents don't have families who can fill the gap or enough money to pay a nanny, and these are the people who are being forced out of high quality regulated care altogether. The government's clampdown on child care fee relief makes a mockery of its supposed interest in reducing welfare dependency and promoting women's participation in the paid work force.

As child care has become harder for low and middle income families to afford, centres have struggled to stay in business, except in more well to do areas. There have been at least 282 closures since 1996, with centres closing in areas where average family income is $32 per week lower than the average in those areas where new centres have opened. Between June and December 1998 the total number of centres fell from 4,170 to 4,120: with the community sector falling from 1,118 to 1,098; and the private sector declining from 3,052 to 3,022. Labor is greatly concerned that child care centres are disappearing from the communities which need them most.

Since 1996 there have been over 282 closures provoked by the Government's reckless indifference to child care. Too many centres have closed and too many are in danger of closing. In typical style the Minister does not seem to care about the social impact. Her comments suggest that she regards these shut-downs as nothing more than the normal hazards of the market. Labor believes that this attitude to child care is unacceptable. These centres care for our youngest and most vulnerable. Child care is a valuable community service, which helps children to develop in a safe and happy environment and assists parents to balance their work and family responsibilities. We all have an interest in the success of child care. Labor believes that there is a public interest in promoting stability and certainty in child care, and that needs-based planning remains an effective way of achieving this goal.

We should remember the human cost of closures. When centres shut down, children who have grown to be comfortable and happy with trusted carers and in familiar surroundings are forced to make that difficult adjustment again. Parents are compelled to find a new centre, which may be too far away from home, and less suitable than the first. Workers lose their jobs, and all too often their accrued entitlements such as superannuation and long service leave. Owner-operators of private centres lose the businesses they have worked very hard to establish, and sometimes lose their homes as well. Parents on the management committees of community based centres may be sued for the centre's debts, and years of hard work by volunteers goes down the drain. For all these reasons there is strong public interest in promoting the stability of existing neighbourhood centres. That is not to say that no newcomers should be allowed into the market, or that there will never be closures. It is a question of balance. Labor believes that there has been enough rapid turnover in the sector and that more stability is needed.

It is now widely admitted that needs-based planning can help to stabilise the sector. Since the early 1970s there has always been some degree of planning in child care. Labor in government had needs-based planning for community Long Day Care, and when we lost office in 1996 we were considering proposals to extend planning controls to private child care. Labor acknowledges that the present government introduced a new system of needs-based planning for private and community Long Day Care. Between April 1998 and December 1999 new places were restricted to a maximum of 7,000 each year, to be created in areas of high need for work-related care. In July the Minister announced that she would not extend needs-based planning controls after the current allocation period finishes on 31 December this year. Characteristically, the announcement that needs-based planning would be scrapped was made in a media release entitled `Government strengthens national planning system for child care' (7 July 1999). Having strengthened government support for child care by taking $850 million dollars out of its budget, the Minister is now proposing to strengthen child care planning by abolishing it. It is the Opposition's view that of all the substantial changes made by the Government since 1996, the introduction of the planning system has been the only beneficial initiative. The Minister own report, Child Care in Australia (July 1999) insisted that ". . . the planning system has ensured that growth is matched to areas of high needs for child care." Labor believes that we need to do more, not less, to target spending to areas of greatest need, and to counteract the trend for overdevelopment in some areas. We consider that needs based planning has a positive role to play for at least the next two years, and want the system to be maintained and refined.

The Minister, however, claims that the sector has settled down and there is no further need for planning. The market, and information campaigns, will take care of the problem of oversupply in local areas. Her claims are not backed up by the facts. Despite the overall depression of the child care sector there are still many areas where over-development is a serious problem. The Minister has recognised that there is a tendency for property developers to build new centres in over-supplied areas and then sell them to investors such as retirees, who may not necessarily have much experience of the industry, yet she insists that the problem is very limited. The Opposition and the childcare sector know that over-development is a more common and serious problem than the Minister admits.

The planning system is strongly supported by both the private and community-based sectors of the industry who are totally mystified by the Minister's decision to abolish planning controls. Private and community-based child care groups have tried without success to convince the Minister that the Commonwealth's proposed remedies are unlikely to be effective, and that needs-based planning can and should continue to play a useful role in minimising closures. In particular, the Minister has been warned by the sector that even if regulations are re-imposed after July 2000 when the Child Care Benefit legislation is introduced it, will be too late, as centres will have already been established in over-supplied areas; and that the decision is likely to lead to a new round of closures. The Queensland Government has also strongly supported the retention of needs-based planning and has warned Senator Newman that her decision is likely to contribute to destabilisation and closures in that state. The Opposition agrees that needs-based allocation of new Child Care Assistance places a useful tool in minimising the closures caused by oversupply, and directing public funds to areas of most need.

The Bill would require the Minister to continue to make determinations and guidelines to implement needs-based planning of new Child Care Assistance places in the calendar years 2000 and 2001. I acknowledge that the Bill may not be technically perfect and is not the best way of achieving our objective. The Opposition is proposing this Bill because we have no alternative and we want to send a strong message to the government that it should use its powers to continue needs-based planning. Specialist advice from the state-based Planning Advisory Committees is needed to ascertain high needs areas, and only the Commonwealth can draw on this advice. Likewise, only the Government can appropriate the funds to provide new places in such areas. My objective in introducing this Bill is to remind the Minister of her responsibilities and pressure her to meet them.

So far the Minister has refused to listen to the warnings from people who know the child care sector that her decision to abolish planning controls is likely to push more centres over the edge. The child care sector's need for stability will not disappear on 1 January next year, when the current allocation period finishes. Nor will needs-based planning cease to be an effective means of countering the problem of local over-development. Senator Newman has failed to justify her decision to terminate the planning system.

Australian families need more support for their childcare needs than the current government has provided. We have a responsibility to provide a stable, caring and professional environment for our children. The passage of this Bill would provide one measure to promote first class childcare in Australia.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.
