debateinfo.title: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS: STOLEN GENERATIONS CASE

talk.start.para: âI ask that general business notice of motion No. 291, standing in my name and relating to compensation for the stolen generations, be taken as formal.

speech.para: Leave not granted.

subdebate.1.para: Contingent motion (by Senator Bolkus, at the request of Senator Faulkner) agreed to:

That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Faulkner moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 291.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus, at the request of Senator Faulkner) agreed to:
That general business notice of motion No. 291 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day until determined.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate, noting the desire of the Australian community to satisfactorily resolve outstanding issues concerning the stolen generations referred to in the recommendations of the report by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Bringing Them Home , calls on the Government:
(a) to settle the stolen generation case currently before the Federal Court in the Northern Territory; and
(b) after consultation and agreement with appropriate representatives of the stolen generations, to:

(i) establish an alternative dispute resolution tribunal to assist members of the stolen generations by resolving claims for compensation through consultation, conciliation and negotiation, rather than adversarial litigation and, where appropriate and agreed to, deliver alternative forms of restitution, and
(ii) set up processes and mechanisms, which are adequately funded, to:
(a) provide counselling,
(b) record the testimonies of members of the stolen generations,
(c) educate Australians about their history and current plight,
(d) help them to establish their ancestry and to access family reunion services, and
(e) help them to re-establish or rebuild their links to their culture, language and history.

In moving this motion, I note the presence in the gallery of representatives of the stolen generations; people who have been here over the last few days from all over Australia and people who are in the gallery this afternoon for this debate.

We visit again the Bringing them home report. This report was a watershed in this nation's history. It unveiled for many of us aspects of this nation's history that some had felt had been better left untold. It told us of the shameful dispossession and the suffering of thousands of our fellow Australians. It is not an exaggeration to say that it shocked us and moved us. I am sure that, like many others, I will carry its stories with me for the rest of my life. These stories are part of the shared history of this nation.

We come to this motion at another significant point in the history of this nation, at the end of the millennium and on the eve of the centenary of our Federation. Let us start by taking the opportunity, in the first instance, to step back in time to another historic year. The year was 1937, a year in which Jewish men and women began to arrive on our shores as refugees from emerging Nazism in Germany and Austria. An ideology founded on lies and false history was seeking to eradicate a group of people on the basis of racial difference. It preyed on the prejudices of ordinary people, pandering to their darkest fears and feeding them lies. It was an infamous period in history and was soon to result in a world war. Australia and the allies it joined prosecuted a just war dedicated to ridding the world of such evil. It has to be remembered that this was not all that long ago.

In April 1937, the Commonwealth government convened in Canberra the initial conference of Commonwealth and state Aboriginal authorities. The Senate, in considering a resolution that goes to the exercise of the Commonwealth responsibilities towards indigenous Australians, should take some time to consider some of what was said at that conference, to consider its historical context and to relate it to the issues we confront today. Some who have contributed to the debate that has followed on from the Bringing them home report have sought to absolve authorities of those days past on the grounds that they were acting on honest and honourable motives. I will get back to that later, but first I would like to spend some time on that 1937 conference.

Some of the characters may be unknown to many of those here today, so I will spend a little time introducing some of them. Dr C.E. Cook, Chief Protector of Aborigines in the Northern Territory, was there on behalf of the Commonwealth. Others were Mr B.S. Harkness of the Aborigines Protection Board of New South Wales; Mr A.O. Neville, Commissioner of Native Affairs in Western Australia, who was infamous in some circles; and Professor J.B. Cleland, who was Chairman of the Advisory Council on Aborigines in South Australia.
It is worth reading into the record some representative verbatim extracts from their observations at that meeting. Professor Cleland said:

The number of half-castes in certain parts of Australia is increasing . . . This may be the start of a possible problem of the future. A very unfortunate situation would arise if a large half-caste population breeding within themselves eventually arose in any of the Australian states.
Mr Neville said:

In order that the existing state of affairs in Western Australia shall continue, and in order to prevent those half-castes who are nearly white from returning to the black, the state parliament has enacted legislation including giving control over the marriage of half-castes.
Dr Cook took matters even further. He was quite explicit in the fear he wished to share, when he said:

If aborigines are protected physically and morally, before long there will be in the Northern Territory, a black race, already numbering about 19,000, and multiplying at a rate far in excess of that of the whites.
If we leave them alone, they will die, and we will have no problem, apart from the pangs of conscience that must attend the passing of a neglected race.

If, on the other hand we protect them . . . we shall raise another problem which may become a serious one from a national viewpoint, for we shall have in the Northern Territory, and possibly in north-western Australia also, a large black population which may drive out the white.
The white population of the Northern Territory will be absorbed into the black. I suggest that we first decide what our ultimate objective should be, and then discuss means to that end.

I would not be so flippant or unkind as to suggest that, if this man was alive today, he could easily slip unnoticed into any Territory CLP government in my memory. He certainly stirred a few of his colleagues.
Mr Harkness had this to say. He started off well when he said:

I was appalled by what Dr Cook had to say in the course of his very lucid speech. It is awful to think that the white race in the Northern Territory is liable to be submerged . . . There is an historic appeal in preserving a vanishing race, but I think we should seek to assimilate these people.
I think we can all see where he was coming from, and I think we all know what he meant by `assimilate'. Mr Neville was reassuring on this point when he said:

If we adopt the policy agreed to at this conference, the danger referred to by Dr Cook should not arise, because the absorption of the natives into the white race will take place before trouble is likely to occur.

The transcript of that meeting, charting as it does the entry of the Commonwealth into the solving of the so-called danger, should be required reading for every legislator trying to deal with the consequences of the racially inspired legislative stupidity that both led to and followed the conference.

There is no one true recounting of history. But what I have attempted to capture is the clear and unequivocal evidence that the fathers of the stolen generation policy and the supporting ideology and deliberate public deception that followed were not inspired by lofty or misguided motives. They were driven, at least in part, by notions of racial superiority feeding racist fears. They consciously or unconsciously mirrored the same attitudes and goals as those of the Nazis they were soon to fight.
The late Ron Castan QC, one of the greatest Australians of modern times and a leading member of the Australian Jewish community, had this to say earlier this year:

There is a chilling similarity to the proceedings of the 1941 Wannsee conference which planned the genocide of the entire Jewish people, and the record of proceedings of the so-called Commonwealth Conference on Aboriginal Welfare of 1937.
In that same speech, this distinguished Australian jurist and humanitarian warned:
The experience of Auschwitz tells us what happens when the law turns citizens into non-citizens and then non-citizens into non-people.

I should conclude my reflections on that meeting by raising just two more comments steeped in the attitudes in this country at that time. It was strange and confusing to these gentlemen that Aborigines would not cooperate wholeheartedly in their schemes. Mr Neville astonished those present by revealing:

You cannot change a native after he has reached the age of puberty, but before that it is possible to mould him. When the quarter-caste home was started . . . we had some trouble with the mothers. Although the children were illegitimate, the mothers were greatly attached to them, and did not wish to be parted from them.
It is unbelievable that these sorts of attitudes reflected official thinking in this country just over 60 years ago.

Finally, I think I should share with the Senate the views of the redoubtable Dr Cook when he feared that his wimpish colleagues might go too far in modifying the policies of locking Aborigines in chains. He said:
If the conference is not willing to say that the neck chain is preferable to the handcuff when natives have to travel long distances under escort, we may as well leave the subject alone.

These were the men and those were the policies that the Commonwealth agreed at that conference to fund into the future. The shame, lies and infamous conduct that was to follow for more than a generation after this were to be the subject of the landmark Bringing them home report. The inaction, denial and historical revisionism of the Howard government in their response to that report have combined to provide the impetus for the motion that we have before us today. They have sneered at the stories, disparaged the report's authors and punished the victims whose stories it told.

Is it a blind refusal to accept the validity of the stories in that report? Is it a refusal to read the informed, researched and enlightened works of contemporary historians? Is it some other voice of darkness that drives our Prime Minister? Will he continue to force every individual and every family that has been scarred by, and is seeking redress for, the policies of successive state, territory and federal governments to a horrendous inquisition in the intimidating and alienating confines of a court? How many lives need be broken and how many dollars spent in his quest to prove that none of this really happened and that he has nothing to be sorry for? Importantly for all of us, how can the process of reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians, one of the most fundamental of the social issues confronting this nation, survive this assault on history?

My generation was largely kept ignorant of the total picture of the shared history of this nation. The great, rich and living culture and heritage of indigenous Australians was invisible in the curriculum of our schools. Indigenous people were largely absent from our ethnically cleansed suburbs. We were not fully exposed to the truths of war of conquest, dispossession, desecration and genocide. These sins of commission and omission were visited on tens of thousands of indigenous Australians over generations. People were torn from their families, denied their mother tongues and deprived of their living cultureâthey are the stolen generations.

Nearly all indigenous Australians lost their land, but the stolen generations lost everything else that brings richness and meaning to human society. They were thus in many cases dehumanised, ripped from their families and thrown into institutions or servitude or both. They were brutalised. In the face of all this, no student of humankind can feign surprise at the poor physical and mental health, dysfunctional social behaviour, alcoholism and suicide that was to characterise and blight the lives of many.

It is an obscenity to what we understand as truth for some people, including some in government, to point to the remarkable, courageous and gifted men and women who transcended all of this to lead successful and fulfilling lives and then to cite them as proof that the institutionalised barbarism either did not happen or happened to good effect. It is now up to us here today to pursue the truth and to pursue social justice. We must have the courage to confront our history and its consequences with courage and firm purpose.

As a parliament, we must fulfil our sworn duty and call the executive to account. It is fitting and proper that we should scrutinise the government's performance in framing their response to the clear and far-sighted challenges set down by Sir Ronald Wilson's report. It is our responsibility to see that a historic opportunity is not lost. If the government's performance in failing to address more than half of the report's recommendations and their incompetent inability to satisfactorily deliver on even those that they have agreed to pursue is left unchallenged, we must and we will share the blame. The government's failure to adequately and compassionately respond to the hopes, needs and aspirations of the surviving members of the stolen generations and their families dishonours us all.

As we move into the new millennium and, need I say, the Olympic year, we will be condemned by most of the nation and most of the world unless we pick up the ball. To those of you unmoved by any of this, can I say that, apart from these moral considerations, the government's approach also represents bad public policy and poor use of the public purse. The government has already declared contingent liabilities in the order of a billion dollars to fight a litigious war with claimants seeking redress, help and compensation. They want to fight every one of the hundreds of probable claims, and they want to fight them in the courts.

At recent Senate estimate hearings, Commonwealth officers estimated the potential cost in the Northern Territory alone would run to hundreds of millions of dollars. A non-litigious and less formal approach, such as the reparations tribunal recommended in the report, would cost infinitely less. The Public Interest Advocacy Centre in New South Wales has already articulated principles upon which such a system could be based.

In addition, it has also placed on the record that there are a number of working models to be looked at in Canada and the United States. The gateway to access any such scheme would be a demanding prima facie test against publicly known guidelines. These guidelines would be established in the inquiry that I understand Senator Ridgeway will move today that we establish. Those unable to meet this standard who still wish to proceed with compensation claims would still need to go through a formal judicial process.

In its fight to destroy the credibility and lives of Lorna Cubillo and Peter Gunner in the test case currently before a court in the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth has already spent over $4 million. Whatever that judge's decision, this case seems destined to go all the way to the High Court. Costs alone will be tens of millions of dollars, before any question of damages. It is an obscenity that John Howard has skimmed $2 million of the money needed for costs already incurred in this case from a program for the benefit of indigenous people entitled `A better future for indigenous Australians'. The gall of it!

The government's motives are as transparent as its methods are brutal. Lorna Cubillo and Peter Gunner are to be made an example of. The Commonwealth's conduct of its case has stunned observers in its callous disregard of cultural sensitivity and its relentless harassment of the plaintiffs. The Commonwealth wants to send a very clear message: any plaintiff must accept that no aspect of their life, no family secret and no youthful indiscretion will be safe from savage public scrutiny. Days in a witness box in front of hardened court performers will be used to destroy your credibility, question your motives and bully you into uncertain testimony.

The strategy is very clear-cut. The objective is that they will frighten off claimants. The prohibitive costs, driven up by the Commonwealth's capacity to hire the best and largest teams of legal dobermans in this country and to dip into the public purse to fund as many appeals as necessary, is intended to frighten off community legal centres and the like that might be considering putting up test cases. We should not tolerate such brutality in public policy. We should not tolerate this ruin of our national honour.

I believe this parliament, this Senate, must challenge the government in the explicit terms of this motion. We must seek to restore the national honour and decent national leadership through the inquiry we propose. Sir William Deane, our Governor-General, has termed the history of government policies that gave rise to the stolen generations our `legacy of unutterable shame'. Let us not today compound and perpetuate that shame. Let us, as a Senate, stand with our fellow Australians in their struggle for justice. Let us translate the compassion that this nation felt on the publication of that report into action. I commend this motion to the Senate.

talk.start.para: âI speak this afternoon on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats welcome this motion by Senator Bolkus on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. I also take this opportunity to move this Democrat amendment, as circulated in this chamber, to notice of motion No. 291:

speech.para: At the end of the motion, add:
"and resolves that the following matters be referred to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee for inquiry and report by the last sitting day of the first sitting week in October 2000:
(c) the adequacy and effectiveness of the government's response to the recommendations of the Bringing Them Home report;
(d) appropriate ways for governments to implement paragraph (b) of this resolution;
(e) effective ways of implementing recommendations of the Bringing Them Home report including an examination of existing funding arrangements;

(f) the impact of the government's response to recommendations of the Bringing Them Home report with particular reference to the consistency of this response with the aims of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation; and
(g) the consistency of the government's response to recommendations of the Bringing Them Home report with the hopes, aspirations and needs of members of the stolen generation and their descendants".

Last but not least, I acknowledge the stolen generations members from the Northern Territory in the gallery. We sincerely hope that the commitments for action which are contained in this motion will be embraced by all the parties represented in the Australian parliament. The pain that has been inflicted on the stolen generations is a national issue that requires a national response. It is also an issue that requires each of us to put aside our political rivalries and recognise that, as senators, we have a responsibility to both current and future generations.

The Australian Democrats believe this motion reflects the wishes of many Australians who want to see the Australian parliament take action to repair some of the wounds that are borne by the stolen generations and their families. Many Australians, both indigenous and non-indigenous, do not want to see Australia enter another century still exercising a collective `willing blindness' in relation to the unfinished business of the past. Many Australians have called upon us as parliamentarians to act decisively and with compassion to alleviate the suffering of the stolen generations.

Over one million Australians added their names to the sorry books that were open for signature and comment around the country. This was their personal way of acknowledging the wrongs of the past and of articulating their own apology to those affected.

The Bringing them home report, as it is now commonly known, of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families, and the recent parliamentary motion on reconciliation are, I believe, two critical steps that Australia has taken in its effort to deal with the enormity of the hurt suffered by so many of the stolen generations. We must now ask ourselves what needs to be done to make a real difference in the lives of indigenous Australians who have been irreparably damaged by past policies and actions of governments, churches or other institutional bodies.

I am perhaps the first to admit that we cannot change the past and right all of the wrongs, but we can and we must make sure that this type of pain, suffering and trauma is not experienced by any Australian person in the future. Our responsibilities in relation to the stolen generations are clearly outlined in the final report of the national inquiry, which I will refer to shortly.

Before I do so, it is important to listen to what members of the stolen generations have been saying themselves about what they want to see happen if governments are serious about responding in a meaningful way to the Bringing them home report. The comments of an anonymous Victorian woman to the national inquiry provide us with some insight into how indigenous people are feeling and why the government's response needs to be very considered and heartfelt. They give some indication of the human scale of this tragedy and suggest that many of the members of the stolen generations are simply looking for answers. She states:

The Government has to explain why it happened. What was the intention? I have to know why I was taken. I have to know why I was given the life I was given and why I'm scarred today. Why was my Mum meant to suffer? Why was I made to suffer with no Aboriginality and no identity, no culture? Why did they think that the life they gave me was better than the one my Mum would give me?

In the last few weeks, and particularly in recent days, I have met with representatives for and members of the stolen generations to discuss what the next step should be, and how that step should be taken. The resounding answer is that the recommendations of the Bringing them home report must be implemented in the near future and the outcomes of its implementation must be monitored to ensure that those most in need of assistance receive it.

One of the other messages that I have consistently received relates to the need for any government response to offer alternatives to court litigation. I think we are all aware of how inappropriate it is leaving members of the stolen generations only one option for redress when that option is adversarial and often beyond the financial means of most of those concerned. We need look no further than the recent decision on the Joy Williams case as to why the stolen generations need to be offered alternative dispute resolution options. Not only was Mrs Williams's case unsuccessful but she was forced to relive the trauma of her experience on public display only to be told that she had not been able to prove she was even a member of the stolen generations.

So the cost in further suffering that litigation guarantees for members of the stolen generations is something that no government should advocate as an appropriate solution. Furthermore, the $63 million that the government has set aside to implement the recommendations of the Bringing them home report will not go far if it is to fund the backlog of the 2,500 stolen generation cases that have already been lodged in my home state. We are already hearing figures of individual cases costing upwards of $6 millionâeven before a decision is handed down.

Surely these amounts of money would be better directed at responses that will deliver real outcomes to members of the stolen generations. There is a need to look beyond litigation and to offer the stolen generations a range of options for redress. Redress is a lesson that I think we can draw from the experience in South Africa through its Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

This approach is also timely, perhapsâin putting forward and supporting this motionâwith the impending arrival of Archbishop Desmond Tutu to this land to talk about his experiences in relation to truth and reconciliation. Such an approach is also the advice of one of the subcommittees of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, which developed the van Boven principles in 1996, after a three-year process of consultation and refinement. These principles were developed for states that are grappling with these types of issuesâwith the violations of human rights of the magnitude of the stolen generation. They have received strong support from a number of the submissions made to the Bringing them home inquiry.
I particularly want to draw the Senate's attention to what the van Boven principles advise on reparations:

In accordance with international law, States have the duty to adopt special measures, where necessary, to permit expeditious and fully effective reparations. Reparation shall render justice by removing or addressing the consequences of the wrongful acts and by preventing and deterring violations. Reparations shall be proportionate to the gravity of the violations and the resulting damage and shall include restitution, compensation, rehabilitation, satisfaction and guarantees of non-repetition.
I think it is also important to look closely at the word `reparations' and to make sure that we all grasp the same meaning.

My understanding of this word comes from the definitions provided in the Bringing them home report and the van Boven principles. Both point out that `reparation' is the most appropriate concept to use as it is a collective term for a whole range of responses, only one of which relates to monetary compensation. When the word `reparation' is used we are not talking about war reparations, which were lumbered on Weimar Germany as a punishment for its defeat after World War I with the intention of bankrupting it.

I think indigenous people and people like Sir Ronald Wilson use the term `reparations' to refer to responses that include: public acknowledgment of the harm inflicted and an apology; guarantees against repetition, including educating Australians about the history of the stolen generations and the current plight of many indigenous peoples today as a result of that history; measures of restitution, such as family reunions and re-establishments of links to culture, language and country; measures of rehabilitation, like counselling; and, finally, monetary compensation. The Bringing them home report is very clear about the place of monetary compensation in this debate. It advised that reparation should be:
Material, in-kind and non-material and should include, but not be confined to, monetary compensation.

That particular view was shared by the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission. The South African commission recommended, and the government accepted, that there could be no healing and reconciliation without adequate reparation and rehabilitation measuresâat either an individual or a community level. Consequently, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission has made some monetary compensation payments to individualsâthat amount being commensurate with the harm they have suffered.

I implore the Senate, on this occasion, to support the motion moved today by Senator Bolkus and the amendment that I have made to it. We need to listen to the stories of the stolen generations about what they regard as the next appropriate steps for the government take. For this reason, I consider it appropriate to refer to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee the question of how the government should respond. We need to look at other models for reparation, such as the model put forward by the Public Interest Advocacy Centre about a reparations tribunal which could make orders relating to compensation, take oral submissions and deal with the entire issue of reparations beyond just financial compensation.

We also need to grapple with a range of questions, including the following. Does Australia need a truth and reconciliation commission like the one that has been established in South Africa? What would it look like? How would it assist in the healing process and how would it operate? Who would preside over it and how long would it operate for? What is an appropriate range for monetary compensation payments, and should they be payable to individuals and communities? Would a national reparations tribunal be helpful? Would legislation be required to establish such a tribunal? What type of evidence would be required before it could make a decision, and how long would it operate for?
These are vital questions that I believe not one of us has the answers for, and I think there is no-one who on this occasion could honestly say they do.

So I approach this matter in the sense of aspiring to the things possible rather than never trying at all, because I think this is an issue that is too important to be limited to more comforting words. Any motion must contain a commitment to appropriate action in the near future. We need to take the time to listen to the stories of the stolen generations. We need to take the time to make sure that our response is the most considered and culturally appropriate one for those who have suffered for so long.

I believe that referring these questions to the committee for its deliberation is the least that we owe the stolen generations. The motion, as amended, is the beginning of a human response that is required on this occasion.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âIt would be entirely inappropriate for the Senate to canvass the issue of compensation to indigenous people while the Commonwealth is defending litigation on this very issue. The Cubillo and Gunner cases, currently before the Federal Court, are close to conclusion. The Commonwealth's evidence is expected to finish in two to three days, and I understand that the court will sit for two to three weeks to conclude the case in February next year. Because the matter is before the court, I am not going to discuss that case.

speech.para: However, I will reiterate our position, although it should be well known: the government does not support the payment of compensation unless a legal liability is established in individual cases, because it does not believe that cash compensation is the answer to this issue. The establishment of some sort of tribunal is no guarantee that the costs and stress associated with litigation would magically disappear.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report itself said: `Assisting family reunions is the most significant and urgent need of separated families.' That is why family reunion is the cornerstone of the government's $63 million response to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report. That response includes a family reunion program administered through ATSIC and separate funding for access to records, personal and family counselling, oral history recording and culture and language maintenance.

The current court case is not, of course, the first action in relation to indigenous family separation. The previous federal Labor government defended the case of Kruger and Bray, the very first brought against the Commonwealth. So the federal Labor Party has to acknowledge its own actions in this case. The New South Wales Labor government recently defended the Williams case. I also note that no state or territory government has set up a compensation scheme. Following the outcome in the Williams case, Premier Bob Carr said that he did not support cash payments to compensate for past injustices. It was reported in the press last week that Premier Carr has also rejected the establishment of a state reparations tribunal.

I think it is unfair and opportunistic of the opposition to raise unrealistic expectations in the indigenous community. Let me be quite clear again: the government are opposed to cash compensation. What we are in favour of is practical and realistic measures that go directly to addressing the consequences of past actions and policies. The opposition motion refers to the need to set up various counselling and support programs for separated children and mechanisms to assist family reunion, the need to record the testimonies of separated children and the need to educate Australians about their experience.

Precisely such processes have already been set in place by the Commonwealth government in its response, announced in December 1997, to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's Bringing them home report. I am surprised that the opposition does not recall that on 30 June this year, in response to a question from Senator Harradine, I tabled a detailed progress report on these Commonwealth initiatives. I am happy to make that report available to interested senators, and it will, of course, be updated regularly.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report contains a vast range of recommendations aimed at all the agencies involved in indigenous child separation practicesâand that means state and territory governments and religious and non-government organisations as well as the Commonwealth. Of the 54 recommendations, very few apply solely to the Commonwealth; the great majority apply equally or primarily to the states and territories. However, it is only the Commonwealth that has developed a dedicated significant package of measures in responseâa package totalling $63 million over four years.

By contrast with the Commonwealth, most states and territories have been much slower to respond, with New South Wales finalising its response only in May this year. In the main, state and territory responses have concentrated on utilising and adapting existing programs in areas such as policing practices, educational materials, mental health, family support, records management or collection of oral histories. Where new funds have been allocated by the states and territories, they have been minimal by comparison. For example, Victoria has allocated a total of $700,000 over three years, whereas New South Walesâwhere I understand the majority of child removals occurredâhas only provided a one-off grant of $150,000.

The starting point for the comprehensive Commonwealth package is the fundamental finding of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report itself which I quoted earlier, and I will quote again: `Assisting family reunions is the most significant and urgent need of separated families.' That is on page 347. The government is unequivocally of the same view.

Accordingly, the Commonwealth response is concentrated on funding a significant expansion of a network of Link Up services to assist people affected by indigenous child separations to trace their families. ATSIC has received $11.25 million to establish a soundly functioning and truly national network of Link Up services. Following an evaluation of the already established services, such as those in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland, some of this money has already been used to employ additional caseworkers and upgrade their training and resources. In addition, the Commonwealth funds are being used to establish new Link Up services in South Australia and Western Australia, and the services in the Northern Territory are being reorganised and enhanced.

By contrast, the states and territories have offered little tangible assistance in this. I noted previously the New South Wales government contribution of $150,000 to Link Up services. I remind the Senate that the Commonwealth's financial contribution to Link Up services is $11.25 million.

Another major set of recommendations in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report related to the importance of recording and making known the experience of those involved in and affected by indigenous child separations through the use of oral history and educational materials. While all states and territories agreed that this is an important area for further work, only the Commonwealth has taken it on seriously, by allocating $1.6 million to the National Library to undertake a major national oral history project collecting the testimonies of separated children and other individuals and organisations involved in various aspects of indigenous family separation. After the completion of a pilot project during 1998-99, the full-scale project is proceeding. This project will also be the basis of a book to be published by the National Library, which will allow all Australians to be better informed about the issue.

Access to records is often crucial to the ability to trace families affected by indigenous child separations. Here too the Commonwealth has been very proactive, allocating $2 million to the National Archives to index government records relating to separated children. To date, 50,000 names have been indexed and 29,000 have been entered onto an electronic database. The National Archives are actively publicising their work and encouraging individuals to use this previously much less accessible resource.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report was much concerned with the ongoing effects of child separation practices on the emotional and mental health of individuals and the wellbeing of families and communities. The Commonwealth response to the report includes an additional $17 million for initiatives to support indigenous emotional and social wellbeingâfor example, by expanding the current network of 11 regional training and support centres for indigenous health workers and counsellors and expanding health programs supporting good practice in indigenous family parenting and family wellbeing.

An amount of $16 million has been given to the Department of Health and Aged Care to employ 59 additional indigenous counsellors to work specifically to address mental health issues. These positions have now been filled, with the majority of new workers placed within community controlled Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community health care organisations. Almost $6 million has been allocated to the development of indigenous family support and parenting programs.

Further, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report signalled the importance of language and culture maintenance support in order to assist indigenous communities and families to overcome the effects of previous practices. ATSIC responded with an additional $9 million for projects in this area, mainly allocated to indigenous community organisations themselves.

The above measures are incontrovertible evidence of the Commonwealth's serious commitment to addressing the main issues and findings of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report, a degree of commitment not paralleled by the other parties which were involved in indigenous child separation practices.

The opposition has tried to characterise the government as harsh and uncaring in relation to indigenous family separation. Nothing could be further from the truth. We do care deeply that indigenous people are still suffering hurt and distress as a result of past policies. We reaffirmed this in the motion of reconciliation on 26 August, a motion passed with the support of the Labor Party and the Democrats. That motion reaffirmed the central importance of practical measures to address disadvantage.

Our response to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report encompasses practical and effective measures to address the legacy of the past. In this light it is hard to see why the opposition has brought forward in this motion any exhortations to the government to address family reunion, counselling and other needs of indigenous separated children and their families. In fact, the Commonwealth announced its commitment to do so almost two years ago and has been following through on that commitment ever since. In light of the evidence that I have presented, and for that reason, we will be opposing the motion and the amendment proposed.

talk.start.para: âI rise in response to both speakers. Can I say to Senator Ridgeway that his amendmentâthe idea that he has proposedâis very constructive, and the opposition will clearly support it. It keeps this issue under surveillance by the Senate, and I think that is an appropriate and desirable outcome. So we could very readily agree to that.

speech.para: Senator Herron, I have to sayâwith sorrow, more than anything elseâthat your contribution over the last 15 minutes or so only really showed us one thing, and that was that you can read. There was no real understanding, I must say, of the holistic nature of the re sponse that is required in this area, no real understanding of where people are being frustrated at the moment, no real understanding that there is a feeling in the communityâquite rightlyâthat the response to this area is, in essence, on autopilot.

Senator Herron, you tell us that it is inappropriate to discuss compensation whilst that Federal Court is hearing the issue. But one of the major objectives of bringing this matter up today is to try to establish an understanding that this matter should not be left to the Federal Court. The Federal Court will continue to hear these cases for a long timeâlong after all of us in this place have goneâunless we find some alternative way of proceeding with them. It is not inappropriate; it is totally appropriate for this parliament to be trying to address alternative solutions to this most fundamental of issues.

Senator Herron, you also say that the government's view is that cash compensation is not the answer. In saying that, you are really arguing for this motion. Without the sort of tribunal we are talking about here today, people are only left with one avenue to pursue, and that is the avenue of the courts and, through that, only compensation. If you honestly believed that there are alternative ways to healing the past in this respect, then you would be looking at a tribunal like this. To do otherwiseâto insist on people being pursued through aggressive examination in courts; to insist that that is their only optionâmeans that they only have the option of compensation to pursue. So, Senator Herron, I think you argued for us.

The other point that needs to be placed on the record in response to Senator Herron's comments is that the evidence shows quite clearly that the government is not in control of the response to the Bringing them home report. We found that out quite clearly just a few months ago in the estimates committee hearings. We talked the minister through the issue of how the government was responding to the report and what was happening. The evidence shows quite clearly that, on the fundamental question of who was coordinating the response, the minister could not answer the question. In terms of who was on the coordinating committee, the minister could not answer the question. In terms of whether the committee had met, the minister had no idea. In terms of what was on the committee's agenda, the minister still could not answer the question. In terms of any specific project the committee had commissioned, the minister could not answer the question.

What we established was that, at that stage, Victoria was in charge of coordination, but the committee had not met. We further established that not only the minister was ignorant of what was not happening but also the most senior officials in the Prime Minister's department were just as ignorant. This is not an indication of a government serious about healing this problem. This is not an indication of a government that knows what was happening. This is an indication of a government that does not care whether the senior minister and the senior bureaucrats had no idea of who was responsible for coordinating a response to the Bringing them home report. That is why we say it is the role of this Senate to put heat on the government to pressure it to get serious. This issue should not be left on autopilot. Governments and parliaments should get serious about this issue.

The other thing that needs to be said is that we need some leadership in the debate, Senator Herron. You have at the moment Paddy McGuinness, lazy as he might be, self-indulgent as he might be, highly paid as he might be, spewing out rhetoric about denial that this ever happened. He gets paid big money for that. He does not do any research but simplistic lines keep spewing out. No-one from the government has confronted him. No-one from the government has said, `Listen, we have history, we have records, we have documentation all on the side of the stolen generations.' This failure of leadership from the government is something that we, not just as a parliament but as a nation, should be concerned about.

The point I made in my earlier contribution is that we are in the lead-up to the new millennium and the lead-up to the Olympics in Sydney. We will not be able to hide this issue as Australia goes through the next 12 months. So I think it is important for the Senate to adopt the motion moved by the Labor Party and amended by the Democrats today.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Ridgeway's ) be agreed to.

debateinfo.title: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

debate.para: Messages received from the House of Representatives agreeing to the amendments made by the Senate to the following bills:
Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (1999 Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1999

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Migration Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 12), as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No. 243 and made under the Migration Act 1958 , be disallowed.

This regulation, as I imagine honourable senators would be aware, has received a fair degree of publicity of late. It relates to a government action to introduce a new form of temporary visa for people who are accessing Australia's protection obligationâthat is, people who are recognised by Australia's legal system as genuine refugees in need of asylum and protection from persecution but who will now only receive temporary three-year visas, if those people come into the country without initial authorisation or a valid visa of some form.

This issue is not, as has been indicated in many media reports and public commentary, about giving visas to illegal immigrants. The Democrats oppose giving any visa to illegal migrants. We do support giving adequate protection for genuine refugees. By definition, genuine refugees cannot be illegal migrants. That is not a matter of splitting hairs or a bit of linguistic sophistry; it is a matter of basic justice and humanity and a proper understanding of what constitutes a refugee.

A refugee is someone who is fleeing persecution and who has a genuine fear of persecution in their country of origin. If they are on Australian soil, we have both a legal obligation and, more importantly, a moral and humanitarian obligation to offer them asylum and to offer them protection. If they do not meet the definition of a refugee, then they do not get a visa. They have never been given a visa: they are illegal migrants without any authority to be in Australia and so they are returned. That is as it has always been and that is as it will continue to be.

This regulation deals with people who are recognised by Australia's system as genuine refugees. If they were not, they would not be getting a visa of any type, temporary or otherwise. This particular regulation now creates a second- class citizen, if you like, or a second- class category of refugees within Australia: those that are seen to have not played by the rules, to use a phrase that was repeated a couple of times by departmental officials at a committee hearing the other day. Somehow or other, people who are fleeing persecution, torture, and potential death are meant to play by some nice rule book. It is astonishing to suggest that somehow or other we can paint these people as some form of queue jumpers, as though refugees around the world are sitting patiently and calmly in some orderly queue. It might be nice if the world operated that way but, unfortunately, it does not.

The issue of providing genuine refugees with only a temporary visa is not just a matter of saying to them, `You can stay here for three years and then we will assess your claim again at the end of that time and, if you are still deemed to be in need of protection, then we will issue you with a permanent visa at that time.' That is one component of it. What we really need to look at is what those people experience for that three-year period. These people have already, by definition, experienced a hell of a lot more trauma and suffering than most of us are ever likely to see. I hope none of us in this chamber ever do see it.

On top of that, people arriving by boat have endured a very dangerous tripâindeed, a fatal trip for someâto arrive on Australia's shores; and look at what happens to them when they get here. People who by our own definition, by any humane definition, are genuine refugees get put in detention; and it is worth emphasising that Australia is the only country in the world that insists on putting all people who arrive here without authorisation in immigration detention. These people, who may have undergone any amount of unspeakable trauma already, are put in detention.

Once they are recognised as refugees, under this new regime that has been put in place, it is not just a matter of their being certain of getting only a three-year stay in Australia; a lot of other items attach to that change. Currently, people who are recognised as refugeesâand this will continue to apply to those who come here under a valid visa, whether it is a study visa, a tourist visa, a business visa or whatever that enables them to get into the country validly and then seek protectionâwill continue to receive permanent visas at this stage.

As part of the temporary visa, those people will not have access to a range of areas of assistance that is applied to other refugees. We will have two quite distinct classes of recognised refugees in Australia. Those without a permanent visa will not have access to the full range of social security entitlements. They will have access only to special benefits, a very tight and constrained payment, with a range of eligibility criteria that do not apply to any other payment. It is worth drawing to the Senate's attention the research that has been done and released by welfare agencies around the countryâby the Welfare Rights Centre in South Australia in particularâabout the poverty and suffering of a number of people who have come to this country and not been able to access adequate social security payments because of the new two-year waiting period. It gives a small indication of the sort of hardship that can apply there.

They also may have restricted access to school education. Depending on the policies of various states, they may have to pay. They are effectively precluded from any form of tertiary education or training due to having to pay full fees, the overseas student rate, unless they can afford it. According to information provided by the department officials on Monday, they will not have access to the refugee settlement support services that are provided to those with permanent visas. They will have some access to some migrant support services, but they will not have access to the full range of settlement support services provided to refugees.

Perhaps most cruelly, they will be separated from their immediate familyâfrom their spouse and their childrenâfor that three-year period. The family will be left alone, possibly in countries such as Iraq and Afghanistanâthe very countries where we recognise there is genuine fear of persecution. The spouses, most often the wives, will be left unaccompanied in a country such as Afghanistan. People need to think about what the reality of that may mean. They will have work rights, but they will have the difficulty of having only a temporary visa. Particularly as they get toward the tail end of that visa, they will be unable to guarantee to employers that they will even be able to stay in the country beyond a certain period of time. They will have no right to leave Australia without jeopardising their visa. All of those changes will also accompany this change to a temporary visa.

I defy anyone who wishes to try to have a commonsense interpretation of the spirit of the refugee convention to suggest that that does not constitute a very real and significant penalty on these people. It is worth emphasising the contents of the refugee convention, with which Australia likes to hold itself up as a proud complier. I will note a few articles from that convention. Article 31 says that statesâand Australia is a signatory to thatâshall not impose penalties on refugees coming directly from a territory where their life or freedom was threatened simply on account of their illegal entry, which is recognition of the principle that, when you are fleeing persecution, you do not necessarily have time to fill out all the appropriate application forms. Indeed, having documentation on you at all may well pose a greater threat.

The refugee convention also indicates that countries shall accord to refugees lawfully staying in their territory, which these people clearly are, the same treatment with respect to public relief and assistance as is accorded to their own nationals. It is hard to see how that is being complied with. It also states that a country shall issue to refugees lawfully staying in their territory travel documents for the purpose of travel outside their territory. I am sure we will do that, but of course there is a bit of a catch thereâwe will give you the documents to go, but we might not let you back in. That clearly contravenes the spirit and intention of those particular components of the refugee convention.

It is worth looking at the cause of some of this. As everybody listening to this debate would know, the government has justified this as a measure to address the increase in the number of boat people arriving in Australia. Firstly, it is worth emphasising this measure will also apply to people arriving by air without a valid visa, so it is not specific to boat people. It will apply to others who arrive without appropriate documentation.

The rationale the government have put forward is that this will diminish the trade in people smuggling. They will run around the country, as they have been already, saying those who oppose these measures are aiding and abetting the people smugglers, supporting these people in their cruel and inhuman trade. The Democrats certainly do not support or give any comfort to people smugglers. Part of the reason why their trade is cruel and inhuman is the suffering of the people who are the cargo, the genuine refugees. But this measure does not target the people smugglers at all. It penalises in an extremely cruel way those people who have already suffered enormously.

This is not a measure that will have any significant impact on the number of boat people arriving, and that has been clearly acknowledged and recognised by the opposition. It has been stated frequentlyâboth before and after the opposition made their decision to back the government's move in this regardâthat this new visa will not be effective in countering people smuggling operations. As I have stated repeatedly, the Democrats have supported some of the other measures the government have put forward that do target people smugglers. The prosecutions that occurred in Darwin recently involved the new extra penalties that were put on people involved in the carrying out of people smuggling operations. They got through this Senate at very short notice, very quickly, because of the cooperation of all parties, including the Democrats.

So I hope we will not hear suggestions as part of this debate that somehow or other the Democrats are happy to support people smuggling operations. We are not. But we do not believe that genuine refugees should be penalised and made to suffer further because of the government's need to seem like they are being tough on boat people. It is not very tough to kick people when they are down, and you do not get people who are further down than some of the refugees who are going to be affected by this measure.

What this measure also does more broadly, which is potentially more damaging socially, is send this message to all refugees already in the country, those who have permanent visas and those who perhaps are now Australian citizens: `Australia really does not want you people anymore. We'll give you protection but only because we have to. We'll do it begrudgingly because we have signed this convention and we'd better look like we're trying to uphold it. But it is pretty clear from all the messages that have gone out from the government in recent times that, if you're a genuine refugee but you haven't played by the rules'âto use that offensive phrase againâ`then we really wish you weren't here. We wish you'd go away. We'll only let you stay a little while. We'll make life difficult for you while you're here. We'll keep you separated from your wife and your kids. Hopefully, you'll get the message that you're just someone who has snuck through the system, you've jumped the queue, you've exploited a loophole.' What sort of message is that to send to people who are escaping persecution?

The government likes to portray Australia as this great humanitarian nation. I hear repeatedly the minister saying that we have accepted more refugees per capita than any other country in the world. I do not know, but perhaps we have if you go back to the Second World War. I will give you a few figures from the last 10 years, which is when conditions changed quite dramatically. According to the statistics from the UNHCRâthe body the government likes to use as a cloak of respectability for some of the things it doesâthe number of people Australia has recognised as asylum seekers under the 1951 convention from 1989 to 1998 total 8,550. The number of people Canada has recognised as asylum seekers under the 1951 convention over the same period is 123,700. I do not know precisely what Canada's population is compared to Australia, but I do not think they have 15 times more people than we do.

talk.start.para: âIt is 25 million.

âThat is not even double, and they have allowed 15 times the number we accepted. In the last 10 years, France has accepted 82,000; Germany, 152,000; the Netherlands, 50,000; Sweden, 11,000; Switzerland, 20,000; the United Kingdom, 20,000; and the United States, 76,000. Maybe we had a good record in the past, but in recent times it has not been so flash and measures such as this make it a hell of a lot worse.

speech.para: It is worth acknowledging that this is predominantly about politics. Nobody can deny that there has been quite an organised attempt to generate concern amongst the Australian community. The Democrats are not saying that we should not address this issue, but again let us keep these things in perspective. We have to recognise, in the same way as we might be concerned about drug smuggling, that you cannot do a few `gee, look, I'm being tough' measures and expect the problem to disappear overnight. It is the same with this issue. It is not going to disappear overnight, and to try to introduce a few knee-jerk, punish-the-victim measures is not going to address the issue. It is not going to go away. Let us recognise it and try to deal with it in a more organised, civilised and logical fashion. Let us have the debate occur in the Australian community on that level, not react out of fear and loathing about some so-called invasion, a phrase I have heard many times on talkback radio in recent weeks.

Again, I will quote some figures from the UNHCR. We are concerned about a couple of thousand boat people appearing, but the number of people indicated as being refugees in 1998 under the UNHCR definition was 11Â½ million. There are a lot of them out thereâthat is the tragedyâand it needs a lot of work and cooperation throughout the international community to address it.

But let us not suggest that somehow or other Australia is being besieged and that every other country is not having to deal with this issue. We get told constantly that Australia is a soft touch, that all these people are flocking here because we make it easy for them. Yet the numbers I have quoted before give some indications. Let us look at the number of people who put in applications to other countries: in the Netherlands last year, 45,000 people applied, as opposed to 8,000 in Australia.

Let us get this in perspective. The number of people crossing the border in the US every day is the same as what Australia has to deal with every year. That does not mean we should not try to address it, but let us not suggest that somehow or other Australia is copping it more than anybody else. We are copping it a lot less than anybody else. If we were the soft touch the government likes to portray Australia as being, those figures would be reversed. We would have the millions coming here. Germany has had two million asylum applications in the last 10 years; Australia has had 80,000. So let us get a bit of perspective in the debate.

I firmly believe the Australian people are humanitarian people and they have shown that in their response to the suffering that has been portrayed to them in Kosovo and East Timor. The only reason they are not responding similarly to this situation is that there has been a deliberate and orchestrated campaign to try to generate community concern rather than portray individual real human suffering.

I do wish and hope that senators reconsider their positions on this issue. I know Labor has announced it will support the government, despite recognising that the measure will not work. To quote from Margo Kingston's article in the Sydney Morning Herald today, `Labor and the coalition combined', along with the Democrats, `to defeat One Nation at the federal election by putting the party last; yet on a crucial policy issue that One Nation is so renowned for, they have now combined to give One Nation victory.'

talk.start.para: âI do not even think that last comment of Senator Bartlett's was worth responding to. These laws set up new arrangements for dealing with people who arrive in Australia unlawfully and they will enable us to tackle the problem of unlawful arrivals who are being trafficked to Australia. You do not need to be a rocket scientist or to read the news paper every single day to know that the unauthorised boat arrivals are increasing significantly. There have been over 2,000 arrivals so far this year. Most of these have been Iraqis, Afghans and Turks. There are further reports that up to 10,000 more people are paying to enter Australia through people smuggling operations.

speech.para: I have heard people say that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has been alarmist, that the minister is making claims that are totally outrageous. Last year we had 2,000 people just about to board one boat to come here illegally. Through the innovative efforts of the department and the minister and cooperation with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that boat was stopped in its tracks before the people left. There was evidence or some suggestion that other boats had set out and had not made it. We ought to remember that any comfort we give to people smugglers or `snakeheads' means that there are people who are in rickety boats, unseaworthy boats, in open oceans who die and have died risking their lives at the hands of these unscrupulous people.

The minister was not being alarmist. He is not given to being alarmist. People give credit where credit is due. He has been recognised as knowing his portfolio very, very well. He is not the sort of person that makes rash statements. He is a very measured person. That statement was not rash. It was based on information that he has. As I said, in one episode last year one-fifth of that number were literally on the docks ready to board the boat. There was a riot on the docks when they were stopped. Many of these people have travelled halfway around the world to come to Australia and bypass or leave other countries that may be able to provide them with protection. Irrespective of whether these people are refugees or whether they are seeking to migrate to Australia as their destination of choice, some of them are forum shopping for their preferred country of residence.

I would like to remind senators that unauthorised arrivals undermine the coordinated system of international burden sharing. They also undermine the integrity of and public confidence in Australia's refugee and humanitarian program. The government is determined to protect refugees in genuine need. People who are bypassing the offshore humanitarian program, whether it be through the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees program or through Australia's resettlement program, have either no claim or a claim that is no greater than the claim of those who have been waiting or who have applied through UNHCR or through our resettlement program. So what these people are in effect doing is bypassing those people who are attempting to come to Australia through appropriate and recognised means. As I said, there are people in those queues who are being bypassed by those people who can obtain funding or who can arrange to come through illegal means by paying people smugglers to assist them.

The laws and regulations we are discussing today introduce a new class of protection visa with two visa subclassesâone permanent and one temporary. Asylum seekers who are unauthorised will be eligible on arrival only for a three-year temporary protection visa.

talk.start.para: âFirst class and second class.

âTo be granted a visa, the visa applicants will still have to satisfy the minister that Australia owes them protection obligations under the refugee convention. Senator Bartlett had his say but now he interjects on me to say that you have two classes of citizens. Yes, there are two classes of citizensâthe ones who try to come using the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees program and the Australian resettlement program and those who try to bypass them. There are two groups of people.

speech.para: Senator Bartlett said that it contravened article 31 of the international obligations where it says the `contracting states shall not impose penalties'. We have had legal advice that it is not a penalty to treat these two different groups differentially. This article also refers to people coming directly from a territory where their life or freedom was threatened. These people are coming indirectly from a second country of settlement or a country of settlement other than the one from which they have fled.

I want to read into the record part of a press release that was issued by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on 19 November regarding these regulations. The press release entitled `Recent Australian Immigration Regulations and the Refugee Convention' states:

Some recent media reports have misrepresented the position of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on recently promulgated regulations under the Migration Act 1958 dealing with unauthorised arrivals.

Signatories to the 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees (the Refugee Convention) undertake the obligation not to return refugees to the countries in which they face persecution under the principle of "non-refoulement" set out in Article 33 of the Convention. This is a fundamental legal obligation.
This next sentence is very important:
The Refugee Convention does not stipulate what kind of visa sovereign States should issue to refugees in fulfilling this obligation.
It goes on to say:

The Australian Government has consulted and continues to consult UNHCR closely on recent and proposed changes to Australian immigration legislation insofar as they engage Australia's international obligations under the Refugee Convention. UNHCR appreciates the process of consultation and is following developments closely.

Refugees are particularly vulnerable to "migration networks", organised criminal rings which have made of human trafficking a most lucrative transnational activity. This people trafficking has taken on enormous proportions. UNHCR is supportive of measures which are designed to minimise such activity while maintaining and strengthening the international refugee protection regime.
As the UNHCR said, they have been watching the regulations very carefully.

To be granted a visa, applicants will still have to satisfy the minister that Australia owes them protection obligations under the refugee convention. The new laws will remove incentives for those people who are forum shopping to select Australia as their preferred place to live. The new arrangements do not allow immediate access to family reunion or unrestricted international movement. Australia will still comply with its international obligations, as asylum seekers will either be offered safe haven or assessed against the refugee convention. Therefore, protection against return to country of persecution is available to all those who need protection.

The refugee convention does not require signatory countries to provide immediate permanent residency to refugees. That has been clearly underlined and reiterated by the press release from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. These amendments bring Australia into line with others in the international community who offer temporary protection to refugees. We meet our obligations to refugees at the standard required by the convention. For people who follow the process of applying through the United Nations High Commissioner or through the appropriate meansâboth in terms of domestic migration legislation and the broader system of international protectionâAustralia is more generous than it is required to be.

Some have claimed that refugees who have been granted a temporary protection visa will be sent home to persecution after three years. This is patently misleading. Holders of the new temporary protection visa may be granted a permanent protection visa if they still have a need for protection after 30 months. Similarly, there are claims that the new temporary protection arrangements for unauthorised arrivals are a penalty for their mode of arrival. This is not correct. Asylum seekers who arrive without authorisation will be able to seek Australia's protection if they are found to be genuine refugees. However, the differential treatment of unauthorised arrivals in comparison to the more than generous treatment of lawful arrivals reduces the attractiveness of the `package' that a people smuggler can sell to an asylum seeker. That is what is happening.

Australia's borders should be controlled by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and by this parliament. They should not be controlled by the `snakeheads' and the unscrupulous people traffickers. These changes deserve the support of the Senate, and I ask senators to vote against Senator Bartlett's motion.

talk.start.para: âI rise on behalf of the opposition to firstly indicate that we will not support the motion to disallow these regulations. It is true that this matter has been discussed at great length in the Labor Party, both outside this parliament and inside this parliament, over the last few days since the issue was raised by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, and this government.

speech.para: The opposition make it quite clear that we do not believe that this policy will work and that it has many holes and flaws, but it is what the government want to do. Therefore, it is on the government's head; they have to take full responsibility for this policy with all its flaws, with all its nasty politics, which the minister and the Prime Minister have been more than happy to promote in the Australian media and out in the Australian public to create a level of minor hysteria about what is going on with boat people arriving illegally in Australia. It is very unfortunate that we have had a government that have attempted to get some political advantage in the Australian community by putting this measure forward in the way in which they have.

We as an opposition in no way support people smuggling. When we were in government we opposed it strongly and strenuously. We still do. We still want those people responsible to be caught, apprehended, taken to the courts in Australia if we catch them in Australia, and to get severe penalties. We would also like this government to have better negotiations with countries in our region from where these people smugglers are operating to have them dealt with to stop them carrying out their infamous trade.

Nobody in this parliament supports people smuggling and nobody in the Australian community supports people smuggling. The people responsible for it make money out of the misery of othersâparticularly refugees who, for whatever reason, believe they have a well-founded fear of persecution and believe that they are at risk in the country from which they come. Therefore we believe that, with respect to the people trade, every measure has to be taken.

One of the unfortunate things about this government is that it has not taken all the broad measures that should have been taken to stop the people smuggling racket. In particular, where have the negotiations with Indonesia been? We have previously had problems with boat people in this country, and the previous government had lengthy discussions and negotiations with Indonesia, which helped stop the smuggling of boat people at various times in the past. This minister has shown no inclination to go to Indonesia and talk directly to the Indonesian authorities. The Prime Minister apparently has shown no inclination to do it, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs has shown no inclination to do it. Though we have the difficulty of repairing our relations with Indonesia post the East Timor episode, this is one reason why we need good relations with Indonesia. This is one way we can stop the people smugglers operating through the Indonesian archipelago. But this government has shown no initiative in that area.

talk.start.para: âBill Farmer went there a few months ago.

âThe parliamentary secretary interjects about Bill Farmer. Bill Farmer is not the minister. At this level, you need ministers to go. When we had the difficulty in government of the illegal smuggling of boat people from China, our minister at the time, Senator Bolkus, went to China and discussed it in detail with the Chinese ministers and officials. We have not seen any inclination from the minister to do anything other than keep issuing statements, backed up by the Prime Minister, that we are about to be flooded with refugees in this illegal boat people trade.

speech.para: The minister has said that he thinks there are 10,000 to come. That is a nice round figure. Next week it will probably be 20,000. It is all done for a political purpose. We make it quite clear in the opposition that we are not falling for the political trick and the political hypocrisy of the government on this issue. We will give you your regulation. We will give it to you, and it is on your head how it works. It will not work. The minister has said, `Give me this regulation, and I will stop the boat people coming and the people smugglers operating. We will limit the boat people to three years as refugees in Australia.' He has indicated to the public, to the Pauline Hanson supporters, to the rednecks out there, to that small minority in our community that is susceptible to this sort of prejudice and is up in arms about this, `Give me this regulation and I will stop it. We will send them home.'

Nobody believes that. If you give a refugee even a three-year visa to stay in Australia, does anyone believe that at the end of the three years we are going to send them home? I believe we would be lucky to send a handful home. They will be given an extension in one form or another. If the government had to send someone in three years to say, `We don't believe you're a political refugee from Iraq, Iran or Afghanistan; we're going to send you back,' imagine the publicity and the scenes at the airport as the immigration officials forcibly put that person on an aeroplane to fly back to Iraq to be arrested by Saddam Hussein. Not even the government will do that. They know they will not do it. This is a political trick to convince people that they will be doing it. In three years time, they will not be sending anybody back; they will be extending their visa in one form or another.

talk.start.para: âWhy are you supporting this then?

âSenator Harradine, the very simple reason is that we want to expose their hypocrisy about the political tactics they are trying on this issue. They are trying a political stunt on this issue. I can imagine this minister, particularly with his Prime Minister, sitting down with his research advisers, doing market research and saying, `Actually, we can run this as a pretty good campaign. We can trap the Labor Party, the Democrats and everybody else into looking like they are soft on refugees and on illegal immigrants, like we might try to trap somebody into looking like they are soft on crime.' I bet there is market research right at this moment on the Prime Minister's desk in his office saying, `This is a good little political stunt to pull.'

speech.para: We are not going to fall for that. The government claim they have a mandate to govern for three years. Let them have their regulation and introduce it, but do not come back and say to us, `This is not working. We want to do something further.' We will say, `You tried it. We told you it wouldn't work. We told you it was a political stunt.' In three years time when all these three-year visas start running out, the public of Australia, the Pauline Hanson supporters, who the government is sucking up to, will say, `Hang on. You're not sending any of them back. They're all staying.' We will say, `Of course. That was the trick in what they did in November 1999. It was a trick. You fell for it, you rednecks, you Pauline Hanson supporters.' Let the government explain at that time.
