As I said before, we believe that there are a wider range of measures that, if the government were proactive in international diplomacy, particularly with Indonesia, you could put in place to stop the people smugglers operating. But the government are not interested in doing that; they are interested only in the political stunt which they can pull.

We in Australia have a proud history of handling refugees. For decades we have been a consistent taker of refugees, of people who are suffering and have a well-founded fear of persecution. At times, people smugglers and others have tried to abuse it. We have dealt with that, not at all times with 100 per cent success but we have consistently maintained, as a Western democracy, that we accept our obligation and that there has to be acceptance of refugees from the UNHCR.

We also accept that we do not like the idea of queuejumping. That is a legitimate part of the debate, and we have made it clear in the past when in government that we do not like queuejumping. We want people to come here in a proper and orderly manner, assessed by the UNHCR under proper documentation. It seems to us that is not a matter the government are particularly keen to worry about now. They are more keen to make a political point. It is very distressing that, as a result of the way the government have handled this issue, our longstanding reputation as a place that has taken political refugees for over 50 years, since the time of the Second World War, is now being tarnished. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs cannot separate their political deviousness from the standing of Australia internationally.

When I came into this parliament, like many others I immediately joined the parliamentary group on Amnesty International. One of the most active members of the parliamentary group on Amnesty International was Mr Philip Ruddock. All those years he was in opposition, he was a very active member of Amnesty International. I went on private delegations with him to such places as Cambodia. Mr Ruddock was impeccable in arguing for human rights, arguing for Amnesty's position et cetera.

It is unfortunate that, since he has become the minister, he has allowed the Prime Minister's political agenda to make every pointâno matter how sleazy it is or how awful it isâsome minor political advantage. For a long time, as I understand it, Mr Ruddock was a political opponent of the Prime Minister in the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party. I give him credit for that. But, since he has become minister, he has had to toe the Prime Minister's political line of how you play politics for a narrow advantage in the Australian community.

I would not mind if Mr Ruddock believed genuinely in putting this policy up for the three-year visa for refugees. I would not mind if he believed that was absolutely the best way to handle it. My suspicion is that, and I think the evidence is now very strong, this has been run as a political agenda. Philip Ruddock has to review his position as a strong supporter of Amnesty International in Australia and in the parliamentary group when he is willing to put politics ahead of an issue such as this. That is how he has played it. He has been trapped by the Prime Minister. In the years ahead, I suspect he will be disappointed in himself for being trapped into doing this.

That is the position he has taken. By his statements in recent times on the televisionâwhen, in my view, instead of trying to be rational about this issue he has encouraged the view that there is a massive number of people about to be smuggled into this countryâhe has not enhanced the debate. It is very easy to go to the lowest common de nominator in Australian politics and to be a Pauline Hanson variation playing to the fears of people, particularly at a time when large numbers of citizens in the Australian community who are under economic stress and uncertainty fall unfortunate prey to the populism of One Nation, which is willing to blame everybody else and which looks to minority groups as a way of apportioning blame.

That is what I find despicable about the government. It is not that they believe this is the best measure for handling refugees; they believe this is the best politics. The opposition will not fall for the politics. We will give them the regulation, and we will watch as it unravels. We will watch when, in three years time or even before that, they have to explain to the rednecks that they have been duped. None of these people will be sent home; they will all be left in Australia. They will be granted an extension and further extensions. They will not be sent home once they are granted refugee status for three years.

Is this going to stop people smugglers? They will be in the camps in Iraq, in the Middle East and in South-East Asia. They will still be saying to these people, `Look, you'll get into Australia for three years. Once you've been there for three years, you'll be there forever.' That will be the line of the people smugglers: `No-one will be sent home once you've been there for three years.' If you are a refugee from Iraqâfrom Saddam Husseinâfrom Iran or from Afghanistan, where your life is really under threat, three years in Australia is a better offer than three years in a refugee camp on the border of Afghanistan or in one of those countries.

This option is not going to stop the people smugglers putting out their poisonous, distorted view. They will be saying that three years is better than none and that, once you are there, they will not kick you out in the end. The government will not have the courage to kick them out. They will not be able to do it in front of the media. Imagine the scene: someone being sent back on the plane by the good officers of Immigration with Customs and the Federal Police physically forcing them onto the Qantas jet to fly back via Singapore to Iraq. That is not going to hap pen. Not even Philip Ruddock would be as politically mad as to be photographed saying, `This is what we're doing to people.'

If the government did send somebody back and they were executed, that would be the end of itâgame, set and match. So we know it is a political stunt. It always has been in the last three weeks and will be for the next three years. We ain't falling for the stunt at all. You can have your regulation, you can live with it and you will take the consequences. In another year or so, I suspect you will be back here with another regulation to say, `Actually, that didn't work. What are we going to do now? We'll put handcuffs on them. We'll keep them in a detention camp. We'll cut off certain benefits.' The benefits that have now been reduced will be further reduced.

The government will come back, and they will put it up in terms of: `This is the way to stop the people smugglers.' But the undercurrent will be appealing to that section of the Australian community of which the Prime Minister, in particular, believes he has a particular understanding. He will play the venal political role all the time on immigration and on boat people. That is the disgraceful thing about this Prime Minister in particular. He has suborned his immigration minister, who, until he assumed that role, had a proud record in this parliament of being a member of Amnesty International and supporting political human rights around the world. Unfortunately, he has lost that reputation because he has been forced by the Prime Minister to toe the line.

I conclude that this policy has been driven by the Prime Minister and by his spin doctors with their market research. They have suborned the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. We will let them have their regulationâbe it on their headsâand let them explain in the future why it has not worked. The politics of the government on this are disgraceful, but the opposition have said, `So be it. If you want to run a disgraceful political campaign on this issue, we will let you. But we warn you that it will not work. A policy like this will never work, but that is what you want. You are the govern ment, so you have your policy.' Unfortunately, however, Australia will suffer.

talk.start.para: âYou cannot have a disgraceful policy with a disgraceful outcome and support it without becoming part of the problem. The Labor Party cannot support these repugnant new regulations and the bill that we are to see later onâand the consequences that these are going to have for people who are in perilous situationsâand say that there is a political reason for this; that is, that you want the government to be shown up for what it is. That is not good enough. The consequences of both Labor and the government providing the numbers for the passage of these changes are going to be life shattering for many people coming to the country of the fair go.

speech.para: These regulations ought to be disallowed. The arguments for that are cogent and they have been put forward very clearly, particularly by Amnesty International Australia. It points out, firstly, that under the refugee convention, a refugee is any person who:

. . . owing to a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality and is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country; or who, not having a nationality and being outside the country of his former habitual residence as a result of such events, is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to return to it.
In other words, they are in fear for their lives. Amnesty International goes on to comment that:

Under Australian law, a distinction is made between people who are seeking asylum (asylum-seekers) and people have been granted asylum (refugees). Asylum-seekers who arrive in Australia without documentation are placed into mandatory detentionâ
that is, jail. Amnesty International continues:

This practice is unique to Australia. If asylum-seekers successfully apply for refugee status, they are granted a Protection Visa that allows them permanent residency. Last month, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock proposed changes to Australia's Migration Act.
I would comment here that this is the latest in a long series of such proposed changes, all of them against the interests of asylum seekers and/or refugees.
Amnesty International goes on to say:

The Government's proposals make a distinction between refugees who arrive with proper documentation and those who arrive without proper documentation. Under the new scheme, asylum-seekers who are granted asylumâbut arrived without proper documentationâwill now be limited to a temporary protection visa valid for three years. During this three year periodâ
and listen to thisâ
the refugee is not allowed to leave Australia and his or her family is not allowed to come to Australia.
Under this provision, there is enforced separation for the refugees from their loved ones. Amnesty continues:
After three years, the refugee re-applies to the Government in order to obtain a permanent Protection Visa.

Amnesty International is seriously concerned about these amendments to Australia's refugee determination process. These changes directly contravene Australia's international obligations under article 31 of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, which states:
"The Contracting Statesâ
that is Australiaâ

shall not impose penalties, on account of their illegal entry or presence, on refugees who, coming directly from a territory where their life or freedom was threatened in the sense of article (1), enter or are present in their territory without authorisation, provided they present themselves without delay to the authorities and show good cause for their illegal entry or presence."
That is the important phrase in this international convention, which Australia has signed: that Australia `shall not impose penalties' on people `on account of their illegal entry or presence'.
Amnesty International notes that:
The Government's proposed changesâ
which are now before the chamberâ
which limit genuine refugees who arrive without proper documentation to three years' temporary protectionâ
and, I add, enforced separation from their loved onesâ
discriminate against genuine refugees and clearly violate our obligations under the Refugee Convention.

What is the background to this situation? The Australian public might be interested to know that the largest group of illegal immigrants in Australia is from Britain and the second largest group is from the United States. Together they form 20 per cent of the illegal immigrants in this country. Where are the detention centres and the get-tough policies for them?

During the last federal election campaign, as we have heard before, Pauline Hanson proposed a temporary protection regime for refugees and was condemned by both the coalition and Labor, including the present Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Philip Ruddock. How is it then that, on 20 October, the government introduced new regulations mirroring Pauline Hanson's policies, with barely a murmur from the opposition or, for that matter, large sections of the press?

The minister constantly speaks of Australia's pull factor for refugees. What he totally ignores is the push factor that explains these people's presence in Australia, like the fact that the Iraqi and Afghan refugees have often fled the most serious human rights abuses imaginableâmuch like the Kosovars and the East Timorese, whom Australia has welcomed. The genuineness of the Iraqis' and Afghans' fears is recognised by the fact that, in 1988-89, 97 per cent of Iraqi and 92 per cent Afghan refugee claimants met the convention's definition of `refugee'.

The minister emphasises the cost to the taxpayer. Why is Australia spending money on detaining genuine refugees in expensive detention centres, a policy also at odds with Australia's obligations, rather than exploring cheaper and more humane alternatives to detention, like release on reporting conditions?

Afghans and Iraqis are coming not because they see Australia as a soft target and are queuejumpers but because Iran, the country of first asylum which has hosted large groups of refugees for a long time, has tired of the failure of the international community and the UN High Commissioner for Refugees to provide funds or organise resettlement of refugees and has passed laws to expel these people by March.

Some Iraqis and Afghans have already been forcibly sent home to face likely torture and death. How can refugees be blamed for taking matters into their own hands when their lives are at risk and when regular channels are closed to them? Would you or Iâand it is Carolyn Graydon from Amnesty International who is putting these questions, but I would ask them of this chamberâbehave any differently when faced with the same lack of options? It is the push factor and not the pull factor that is clearly relevant here.

Even with the recent boat arrivals and the possibility of more following, Australia simply does not have a refugee problem of the order of other places in the world. We have very small numbers of people seeking asylum compared with other countries. For example, there were 8,257 refugee claimants here last year compared with 98,644 in Germany, 427,000 in North America and, all up, 417,000 in Europe.

These regulations breach Australia's international commitments. They breach Australia's national ethic of a fair go. They breach basic human tenets that you should harbour people whose lives are threatened and who are in fear for their lives if sent back to their place of origin. I think it is a clear sign of the inhumanity of these regulations that built into them is a catch-22 for refugees: the regulations do not just leave refugees in total doubt for three years about what is going to happen to them if they have been granted temporary asylum here but also say, `During those three years, you are divorced from your family and loved onesâthey cannot come here and you cannot go there.' A good many people who are not well informed on this matter might like to think about the ramifications of that situation alone. The Greens oppose these regulations. We believe that they should be rejected.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to oppose the proposal put forward by Senator Bartlett on behalf of the Australian Democrats. Australia, I believe, is on the horns of a dilemma because of a recent increase in the influx of boats and boat people illegally to Australia. The proposition by the minister is a reaction to that, and I think Senator Bartlett's motion is a reaction to the minister's reaction.

speech.para: I have weighed up what Senator Bartlett is proposing and come down against it because I do not think, if implemented, it would do any good in alleviating the problems and difficulties that are currently besetting Australia. That is one of the factors that motivated me in arriving at my decision, a personal decision which is now a Labor Party parliamentary position, on this issue to support or not support this particular motion.

Australia has seen, in this current financial yearâand we are only 4Â½ months into itâsomething like 1,700 people enter onto our shores illegally and enter, I might say, by what seem to be very organised means and methods. They have come here seeking from us protection; they have come here to test our compassion for refugees. And it is right that they do that in some ways, because Australia has a very proud record of looking after those who need looking after.

Our record stands up against any other Western nation. It is a record that I am proud of. It is a record that I helped to sustain when Labor were in government, when we were cutting back on numbers in our total immigration program. I think I have made some contribution to the maintaining of the program even while Labor have not been in office, when different political parties are in government.

Our current refugee and humanitarian program totals some 12,000 people. It is a number that has been maintained now for a number of years, despite enormous pressures being placed on the program. The total of 12,000 people to whom we give sanctuary, to whom we give protection and to whom we give assistance in building new lives is something that indeed we can be justly proud of. Not all of the people to whom we give protection arrive here legally or are chosen by Australia to enter our shores; some of them have actually breached our borders and, while in our country, claim protection and, indeed, are granted protection.

So I will make the point that, out of those 12,000 places that we have, 2,000 are reserved for onshore claimants. Last year Australia granted protection on shore to 1,834 peopleâvery, very close to the number that was allocated. So far this year, just by boat alone, we have got 1,700. If the trend we are experiencing at the moment from boats alone continuesânot to mention those who come in by aircraftâit is estimated that number will be something like 4,000. Unfortunately, some of the intelligence and predictions coming forward are that the number of those who are planning to get here, and who currently have proposals on foot and measures on foot in order to arrive illegally in Australia, is vastly larger than that.

In the refugee and humanitarian program there is an ability for the government to swap onshore places for offshore places and offshore places for onshore places. That is my greatest concern. The staff in my office back in Perth do an enormous amount of work on behalf of refugees and the reunification of families under the refugee and humanitarian program. In very recent times we have been successful in assisting a Somali woman and her five childrenâwhom I think are actually on their way as I speakâwho were in a camp in Norway, to be reunited with her husband and four other children who reside just north of my electorate office in Balga in Western Australia. A Somali family.

We have worked long and hard to get the approval and then to get the travel documents and to get some identity documents for those people so they can be reunited. We have done that over a long and quite extended period. If this familyâwho are actually destituteâhad the money to pay the people smugglers, they could have come here illegally and been processed in a matter of months. They do not have the money to do that, so they have had to depend on people like meâand St Vincent de Paul and other organisations from Perth when they arriveâfor assistance.

My office has also been successful in recent weeks in getting the brother of a former Iraqi diplomat granted refugee status from Greece. The former Iraqi diplomatâand I make this point strongly, because I want to come back to it later when I talk about the comments another senator has madeâwas actually in Port Hedland a couple of weeks ago when members of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration were at the Port Hedland detention centre on an inspection tour investigating the conditions in the camp. He was there as an interpreter on behalf of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. He has settled in our community. His brother was in Greece, again in absolute destitution. He had no money to pay people smugglers to come here illegally and to get priority in the processing for refugee status.

We are not successful in all of our cases. There is only a limited number of places available. Many senators and members of parliament, like me, work on these cases, as do many other organisations. We are fighting for a very limited number of places. When we record three successes in recent weeks, we really are pleased. It is worthwhile talking about them in a debate such as this in the parliament of Australia.

The third case I want to briefly mention concerns a Kurd woman who is living in Perth's northern suburbs. Generally, I go to her home to meet her when she has some more news of her brothersâone of whom is in Greece. She does not have the money to come down to my electorate office, because such a journey requires two changes of buses. Her husband is working. She has two young children. She does not have the money to do this because she is sending what she has to her brothers. Her brothers do not have the money to pay the people smugglers to come here. But people in offices like mine work on behalf of these people. We work to the regulations. We work for years and years and, finally, we record some success. We are very pleased on behalf of those families. We are very embarrassed when those families then come in to thank us and give us gifts that we know they cannot afford.

So when I looked, as I did the other week, at the people coming off the boat in Willie Creek just north of Broome, I saw people who actually were quite well-dressed. I cast no aspersions on their claims for refugee status, but they come in with possessions and valuables that I know the relatives of my constituents do not have and are never going to haveârelatives from separated families like the Somali family who were separated from each other.

I listened very carefully to the comments of my colleague Senator Schacht in the debate. I endorse the views that he put on the record. As people would know, I normally say things quite differently in the chamberâI do not have the same drive and force as Senator Schacht doesâbut I agree with the comments that he made. I do not actually think this provision is going to stop the incursions on our border. It might have some impact on them. I believe it will have some impact on the numbers coming in.

I believe that it will make Australia a less attractive place for the people smugglers to sell their awful wares. As they are flogging fares or residency to the United States, to Germany, to other parts of Europe, they will now not be able to say that when you get to Australia you will get permanent residency immediately, which was one of the sale factors that they could use in the past. That was not available to them when they were selling fares to the United States of America. It was not available when they were selling fares or passage to Germany or to the United Kingdom. It certainly was when they were selling fares to Australia, but it is not now. That just might work. I think we will, as Senator Schacht says, have to come back here to look at this matter again in the future.

When we were in government we had a problem with China. As Senator Schacht said, Senator Bolkus went to China with the secretary of the department and with the chair of the Joint Standing Committee of Migration and negotiated with the Chinese and put an agreement in place. That did not stop the exodus immediately from China, but it certainly did over time for the Vietnamese who had already got the protection. It was a waste of time them coming. The problem is not yet completely solved.

I do have some sympathy for the minister in this debate, apart from the criticisms that I have joined Senator Schacht on. I do not think Minister Ruddock was helped by the comments of Premier Richard Court from Western Australia, whose initial response to the matter was, `Send them back.' You would expect that sort of comment from perhaps people who are in Senator Harris's party and from other uninformed sections of the community, but for a premier of a state to make a stupid statement like that really begs one to look at it.

How would you be if you loaded the boat people onto RAAF Hercules and sent them to their port of disembarkation? How do you think the Indonesians would take to a squadron of RAAF Hercules aircraft with no permission to land bringing people into their territory and dumping them there because they said that that is where they came from? All of the claims made by the people who arrive here are not necessarily truthful. We do know that some of those who disembarked came from Lombok and places like that. This whole issue has changed.

Some of my colleagues made the comment to me the other day that people are risking their lives in rickety boats which undertake long and hazardous sea voyages. The Adelong boat, which was in Darwin harbour the other week and which some of us from the Joint Standing Committee on Migration boarded, is actually quite a substantial vessel. It did not have to undertake a long and hazardous voyage. It actually had to do quite a short trip. I do not think there are many of us in this parliamentâthere probably are someâwho could afford to purchase a vessel of that size. It was a former ferry. It is only a short skip and jump from Lombok to the territorial waters of Australia at Ashmore Reef, especially with the vessels that are available to people.

Let me talk about some of my other colleagues. I do not think Senator Eggleston helped the minister when he commented that we should process the illegals in Jordan because that was allegedly where they came from. Carolyn Graydon said in an article in today's paper, which I will mention later, that they came from somewhere else. Some of them came from Jordan. Senator Eggleston's suggestion is that we process them in Jordan. You can imagine the scenario if these boats came in and unloaded at Willie Creekâpeople being ferried off to the airport at Broome, put on jumbo jets and sent off to Amman in Jordan for processing. How silly can you get.

Senator Eggleston has forgotten that Australia actually processes people in these overseas ports. We have people in places like Amman who can process claims in Amman if a person claims protection in Australia. The unfortunate part about making a claim for protection in a place like Amman or Athens is that you have to wait years to get your claim processed. If you have the resources, if you have the money you can buy your way to Australia and can be processed here. They come and are prepared for time in detention. The know their claim can be processed in a matter of six or eight weeks. I did alert Senator Eggleston that I was going to quote him in this speech. I will do the same to my colleague Senator Lightfoot.

Senator Lightfoot made the loopy suggestion of putting the people on the islands off the coast of Western Australia. Christmas Island, Cockatoo Island and Koolan Island were mentioned by the good senator. He has not mentioned Rottnest Island but he probably will.

talk.start.para: âWhat about Alcatraz?

âNo, I did not say that. Senator Lightfoot failed to take into consideration the problems with a place like Christmas Island. The president of the council on Christmas Islandâwho will probably soon be the president of Christmas Islandâhas made the comment that if they want food it has to be ferried in to them from Australia. What would the cost be to the Australian community were we to accept Senator Lightfoot's loopy suggestion?

speech.para: It gets worse. I draw your attention to a letter to the editor in today's Australian newspaper from good Senator Ross Lightfoot from Canberra, not Western Australia. He said:

Illegal immigration to Australia is just that. It is a crime to enter Australia by boat or any other means other than with the permission of our government. Therefore, these people are criminalsâworse, if they bring with them . . . diseases . . .

You are wrong, Senator Lightfoot. It is not a crime. If you read the criminal code you will see that it is not a crime. It is certainly not a crimeâand I will never support it being a crimeâfor a person to come to this country to claim protection. We have to maintain that. This is part of the danger of where this debate is going.

I move on to Carolyn Graydon's article in today's paper, which Senator Brown quoted. I am very disappointed with Carolyn Graydon's article because she knows better. She is a learned person who has made a great contribution to many of the debates on migration in this country and, in particular, on refugee matters. Unfortunately, she has a number of things wrong today. Senator Brown quoted:

During the last Federal election campaign, Pauline Hanson proposed a temporary protection regime for refugees and was condemned by both the Coalition and Labor. How is it that on October 20, the Government introduced new regulations mirroring Hanson's policies, with barely a murmur from the Opposition and the press?

I can say on behalf of the opposition, not on behalf of the press, that I do not believe that what the government has put in here mirrors what Hanson put forward before the last election. I do not believe that is what we are doing. There is a provision for three years temporary residency. At the end of the temporary residency if that person is still entitled to protection in Australia they will get it. That brings me to the first part of Graydon's article, which I quote in part:
. . . but all Australian people who do not want to be a part of sending back to face possible torture and death.

If those people are genuine refugees and granted temporary protection in Australia for a period of three years, at the end of the three-year periodâas I understand the regulationsâthey will still be entitled to protection in Australia. I understand that the minister has said that they will be granted protection in Australia and protection will be continued. I probably will not be in the chamber at that time, but if Labor is in office at that time we will honour the commitments and not send people back to face torture or death in another country.

Senator Brown also mentioned the problem of overstayersâthe illegals that were mentioned. I make the point that, in the last financial year, 13,472 overstayers were located here, and most of them were removed. When overstayers come to my office looking for help, I listen to their arguments, but the chances are that I do not support them in their quest to remain here, if they have breached our laws. I know of many other organisations, including some that have made representations on the matters that are before us, who do not hold to the same standards that I impose on myself.

I make the point that I am very proud of my heritage and my former nationality and birthright from Ireland but, even when people from the land of my birth come to see me, they do not get favoured treatment with regard to that. You have to be really consistent on this, and I think that what we are doing with these regulations, tough as they are, has a consistency about itâa consistency that is not matched by every other party or party representative in this place.
Debate (on motion by Senator Patterson) adjourned.
Ordered that the debate be made an order of the day for a later hour this day.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Patterson)âby leaveâagreed to:
That consideration of government documents not be proceeded with today and that business continue till 7.20 p.m.

talk.start.para: âI would like to comment on some of the issues that have been raised here this evening in the disallowance motion moved by the Democrats on Migration Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.12). I believe that this typifies the old adage that you should believe very little that you hear and only half of what you read in the newspapersâbecause there are some glaring inaccuracies that have been stated here today, and I would like to clear up and clarify some of them.

speech.para: Pauline Hanson's policy on refugees is very clearly that One Nation believes in providing temporary refugees with refuge in Australia until the danger in the refugee's country is resolved. But we also believe that, in doing that, there should be no assumption of permanent residency in Australia. Australia can stand very tall in relation to our acceptance of refugeesâapproximately 12,000 per annum. This figure has been clarified by other speakers this afternoon. What has not been raised, I believe, is the fact that when you look at countries around the world and you compare that figure of 12,000 on a per capita basis of the residents of those countries, Australia clearly has one of the highest per capita acceptance rates of refugees.

I believe that where some of the misunderstanding arises is in relation to our policy on temporary visas or temporary entry. I would like to clarify that we believe that there are three general categories for temporary entry into Australia which allow entry visas for between three months and four years. Those areas are for temporary resident programs, for people with skills, and for people with certain business conducted here in Australia. The longest period would be available to a self-sponsoring business executive, and that would be only for four years.

Where the uncertainty has crept in and the period of five years is being quoted from is, in actuality, part of our policy on citizenship. The five-year permanent residency before being eligible for citizenship is where the five-year period comes in. Also part of that policy is that a person who has been here for five years can only have, during that period of time, 18 months outside Australia. I hope that that to a large degree clarifies some of the inaccuracies that have actually been spoken of Pauline Hanson's One Nation here this afternoon and this evening.

I do believe that illegal immigrants are exactly that. My reasoning for saying that is that, if we agree to automatically accepting illegal immigrants for permanent residency in Australia, we are putting in jeopardy the whole human relations program for those people who are waiting in temporary camps while their positions are being assessed for legal entry into Australia.

It is clearly an area that covers many aspects. I believe that the government is largely correct in issuing only a temporary visa and that it is an improvement on the situation that we have at the present moment where a person can enter this country illegally, be processed in a short period of time and then be eligible for all of the welfare benefits available to the Australian people. I come back to my earlier point that this nation, with a population of approximately 19 million, accepts 12,000 refugees on an annual basis. So the cost per capita to Australia is enormous.

In conclusion, I believe that illegal immigrants are exactly that. They should not have the rights of refugees who have come through the correct procedure. I believe that it is fit and proper for the temporary visa to be exactly that: temporary.

talk.start.para: âI have listened carefully to every word of this debate on the motion to disallow Migration Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 12). It is a debate which is of considerable interest in the community. My real concern is that there is a xenophobic atmosphere being created in order to have this parliament accept a regulation which will discriminate against the genuine refugeeâthat person who is fleeing from torture, persecution and great pain inflicted by the country of originâand no amount of xenophobia can justify that.

speech.para: I listened very carefully to the comments that have been made by other honourable senators. If I may just deal with Senator Harris's remarks when he was talking about illegal immigrants. We are not talking about illegal immigrants; we are talking about asylum seekers, which is a different matter altogether, with due respect. I think the comments made on this disallowance motion by two senators were quite remarkable. It would be interesting for the party that they represent in this chamber to have a look at the Hansard when it comes out. I am referring to the contributions that were made by Senator Schacht and Senator McKiernan. Senator Schacht seemed to be saying that this is a dreadful regulation.

talk.start.para: âIt won't work.
âThat is right. Senator Schacht was saying, `It is a dreadful regulation in principle and it won't work; nevertheless, we will vote for it anyhow.'
âThey are the government. It is their responsibility.

âIt is very interesting that Senator Schacht should abandon his party's responsibilities in a very important matter just because the coalition is the government and Labor is the opposition. That is an extraordinary statement to make. I know that Senator Schacht would have to be embarrassed by the decision that has been taken.

speech.para: But not so Senator McKiernanâhe is not embarrassed at all by the decision that has been taken by the Labor Party. In fact, he has indicated to us that he shares some responsibility for that decision. I was very upset to hear some of the comments by Senator McKiernan because they seemed to be supporting the panic that is currently being promoted by the federal government in order to impose this unfair regulation. I was disappointed, frankly. Senator McKiernan appeared to be setting up a division and a conflict between those asylum seekers and those who have been acknowledged by UNHCR as being refugees and who would then be given the necessary papers to come to Australia.

Senator McKiernan talked about the work that he and his office do for certain of these peoples. However, I think every other member of parliament is involved in those processes. Throughout the period of 24 years that I have been in the parliamentâin fact, I think one of my first acts as a member of parliament was to contact the then minister about a refugeeâI have been constantly involved in that particular area.

But to suggest that those people fleeing by reason of a well-founded fear of persecution in their own country, even though they have come through another country, are deliberately setting out to take the place of the other group is a nonsense. And why only 2,000 onshore? That is a decision by government. It is not a decision by anybody else. Senator Bartlett has dealt with this very well and given you the figures. Australia has not been overgenerous in this particular regard in recent years.

This regulation tars all asylum seekers with the one brush. It does not enable a quick settlement of a claim for refugee status. It provides for a temporary resident visa for three years, during which time a person would not be able to do a number of things. In her article in the Financial Review on 18 November, Dr Mary Crock wrote:

The Government wishes to downgrade the protection we offer people recognised as refugees. While the asylum seekers who came as tourists and students gained permanent residence upon having their refugee claims accepted, unauthorised arrivals will get no more than three-year temporary permits.
The entitlements of the second group will be considerably less than those of the first, with truncated welfare payments, no family reunion rights,â
and I might say that is a disgrace considering this is a government that prides itself on being pro familyâ

no automatic right to Medicare or to travel. Access to the workforce is hampered by the constraints of a temporary visa. And access to tertiary education is all but barred thanks to the requirement that temporary visa holders pay full (foreign student) fees.

Senator Brown quoted profusely from Amnesty International's document entitled New regulations to the Migration Act , which shows that Amnesty is opposed to this particular regulation. One of the most cogent statements which I think should be borne in mind by the Labor Party is this:
Under the Government's new scheme, genuine refugees will be kept in limbo for three years after they gain refugee status.
Please, I ask the Labor Party to listen to this:

Psychologists have documented the negative impact of applying for refugee status on the applicantâan ordeal he or she will now have to endure twice. To hold out the prospect that genuine refugees will be returned to the places where they have suffered severe mistreatment is not only callous, but also deprives refugees of the opportunity to rebuild their shattered lives. As if this were not punishment enough, the refugee's family is also kept in limboâleaving the refugee to wonder about the well being of his or her family. In addition to the psychological costs associated with the temporary protection visa, temporary protection also involves a substantial financial cost for Australian taxpayers.

That is the nub of it. You are condemning these people, these asylum seekers, to a limbo of three years. Whether they be genuine or not, you are not allowing proper process for the genuine refugee, that person who is fleeing from real persecution. You are not allowing for thatâgive them three years and try to sort them out after that. You are adding to the trauma, and this is something that is of great concern. I will quote again from the Amnesty International document:
For the 1998-99 financial year, 2106 people arrived illegally by air and 926 by sea.
Of course, that has increased in the last few months. It continues:
Of the 926 unauthorised boat arrivals, only 350 applied for asylum, 166 received a protection visa at the primary stage, and two received a protection visa upon review.

The place is not being flooded by asylum seekers. Let us make that perfectly clear. Let us go back to the point which emerged from the hearings of the committee only on Monday. How many illegals are there in Australia? There are 52,000.

talk.start.para: âSome of them were for three days, four days or a week, not all at once.
âBut there are many long-term overstayers.
âWe catch 14,000 a year.

âYes, but there are 52,000 at this time in Australia. They are not the boat people. They are not the people coming in by boat; they are the ones who come in by the regular airlines. And the statement about them is: `But most of them are British.' What about doing something about that situation?

speech.para: We certainly do have obligations under the refugee convention. It was noticeable from the UNHCR document from which the parliamentary secretary read that the UNHCR was deliberately not giving its approval, I would have thought, to this particular regulation. There was nothing in that document which said that the UNHCR supports this regulation. How could it, because it seems to me to contravene the provisions of article 31?

talk.start.para: âDo you want this document?
âI have got the document and I have read it thoroughly.
âWe have to agree to differ on that, Senator Harradine.
âIf we can go through it.
âI have. I read it into the Hansard .

âBut there is nothing in that document that says that the UNHCR supports this. I come finally to this situation of penalisation. The government says it has legal opinionâI do not know from whom, but it is presumably from A-G'sâthat what it is doing is not contravening the provisions of article 31. Article 31 states:

speech.para: The contracting States shall not impose penalties on account of their illegal entry or presence on refugees who, coming directly from a territory where their life or freedom was threatened in the sense of article 1â

I would be very interested to have a look at a copy of that legal opinion. I do not know how you can suggest that a genuine refugee who is fleeing persecution is not penalised by comparison with others who come in by the airlines, is not penalised by virtue of not having documents. Of course, many of these people cannot get documents. They are in a dictatorial state and they cannot get the documents. Some of them are fleeing for their lives. They might be in Iran having originally fled for their lives from Iraq. Iraq is also a problem. Senators would have heard, as I have heard, that there are moves within Iraq to try to repatriate a number of the refugees who are having a temporary stay there. So far as choosing Australia is concerned, what is wrong with choosing Australia, if there are relatives of the victim already in Australia?

All of the arguments that have been put forward for this regulation do not seem to me to be persuasive. I remind honourable senators that asylum seekers who come in as tourists and students can gain permanent residence if they have their refugee claims accepted, and you are penalising those others who are so desperate that they get on boats by only saying, `They'll have a three-year temporary visa.'
I support the motion of disallowance that has been moved by Senator Bartlett. I think he outlined far better than I could the reasons for disallowance.

talk.start.para: âI rise to correct an impression in some comments made by my colleague Senator McKiernan about what I had to say about the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees having a role to play in processing some of these refugees before they come to Australia. I believe the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees does have a role in seeking to assess refugees in the Middle East, some of whom may come to Australia but who, I think, in a general way could be assessed against United Nations criteria for refugees and diverted to recipient countries, which would include Australia. But Australia should not necessarily be expected to bear the whole load, as we seem to be doing at the moment.

speech.para: As a signatory to the UN Convention on Refugees, Australia meets its responsibilities to the international community by admitting 12,000 refugees per yearâ10,000 who come in through the orderly process of assessment in other countries and some 2,000 who arrive onshore. I think that is a fair enough contribution from a country of Australia's size. Australia's reception facilities at the moment are filled to capacity. A year ago there were only 30 people in the Port Hedland detention centre. That facility, which is incidentally up to three-star motel standard, houses more than 700 illegal immigrants. Numbers in the emergency centre at Curtin air base near Derby are approaching 1,000, and we are told the government plans to use the Woomera village to house more illegal immigrants. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Philip Ruddock, has said that there are several thousand Middle Eastern refugees in Java hoping to gain entry to Australia. Quite clearly, I would have thought, Australia cannot hope to cope with this load alone, and nor should it.

If one thinks back to the aftermath of the war in Vietnam, refugee camps were set up in Thailand where individuals were first assessed by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and then passed on to officials of recipient countries, such as Australia, for further assessment and admission. I believe in this situation, if there is a flood of Iraqi and other refugees coming out of countries in the Middle East like Afghanistan, the UN should be setting up a similar process to deal with this situation. This would enable the UN to assess individuals against the criteria for refugee status and allocate those who have met the criteria to various recipient countries in Europe and North America. Australia would certainly play its part but would not be expected to carry the whole burden.

I understand the UN made this kind of arrangement a few years ago when there was a flood of Sri Lankans into Australia via South-East Asia and that proved to be an effective mechanism. I believe that in this situationâand that was the point I made when I talked about the United Nationsâa similar mechanism set up now would greatly alleviate the situation and see these Iraqis processed in an orderly way and distributed to recipient countries, including Australia, which would play its part but not be expected to bear the full burden.

talk.start.para: âin replyâThere has been a lot of discussion in this debate about the boat people problem. Without getting into another argument about how big that problem is, as I said in my initial comments, I believe, as do the Democrats, it is an issue that Australia needs to address and look at finding the best ways to address. Unfortunately, most of those comments actually have nothing to do with this particular regulation that we are discussing. As the Labor Party themselves admitted in their contributions and their own shadow minister has said and Mr Beazley has said, `This measure is not going to address that problem. So let's just forget about that.' The Democrats support doing something about the boat people issue, about people smuggling. We have supported some measures already. We will support others and there will need to be some long-term work done as part of the global situation that all countries in the world have to face, not just Australia.

speech.para: That is not what this is about; this is about targeting genuine refugees, penalising them for not playing by some obscure, strange and imaginary rule book and putting them in a situation where they clearly have to suffer a lot more than other refugees, creating two classes of refugees and creating extra suffering for those people who have already suffered. That is what this is about. Let's not have some smokescreen that somehow or other this is a solution to the boat people problem.

To those people who still occasionally ask me why I singled out Senator Harradine in my first speech as someone who has a proud record on particular issues, I suggest that they look at the speech he just made and others over many years on this issue. That is why I made that comment.

I agree with the comment Senator McKiernan made that disallowing this regulation will not solve the boat people problem. Voting to disallow this, as you are not going to, sadly, is not going to solve the boat people problem. If you support my motion to disallow, I agree it is not going to solve the boat people problem. It is not aimed at solving the boat people problem. The regulation, if it goes through, and sadly it is going to go through, is not going to solve the boat people problem either. So why don't we focus on what the regulation actually does and whom it does it to. And `whom it does it to' are amongst the most disadvantaged people, those who have suffered the most, and we are putting more suffering upon them.

It is also worth looking at some of the comments about the queue jumping aspect of those who gain protection in Australia. As I said previously, the notion that somehow there is this orderly queue around the world is fairly laughable to start with, but let's look at this link between the onshore and offshore humanitarian program within Australia. The government's justification for this measure partly has been linked to expressed communi ty concerns about the impact of the onshore program on the humanitarian program offshore, people coming here from overseas who have waited in the queuesâpeople who have done the right thing, played by the rules.

This is exactly what the Refugee Council of Australia said would happen when the government linked the onshore and offshore programs in July 1996. When they made that link at that time the Refugee Council issued a statement indicating their view that this linking would create a significant pull factor by reducing the number of places available for offshore applicants so that it would become more attractive for people with strong claims to come directly to Australia rather than waiting in countries of first asylum for selection under the resettlement process.

The Refugee Council also indicated back then that the communities that could be most affected would be those that rely most heavily on the special humanitarian programsâsuch as Afghans and Iraqis. Surprise, surpriseânow that we are getting people from those countries, the government wants to do something to keep them out. As anybody who has looked at this issue in any depth would know, for those people who are waiting overseas for selection through the UNHCR and through the special humanitarian program it is not a nice orderly queue whereby you put in your piece of paper and weigh up all the criteria; it has just as much arbitrariness and politics as any other process. So to suggest that somehow or other if people do not play by this nice, friendly little rule book they somehow should be punished is totally misrepresenting the reality.

This so-called problem is of the government's making and could be solved by unlinking the offshore and onshore programs, as is recommended by the UNHCR, according to the Refugee Council. This is the UNHCR that the government loves to try and pull in every time; it loves to pretend that it supports what they are doing. The UNHCR recommend unlinking onshore and offshore programs. Why don't you do that, if you think you have got such backing by the UNHCR? There's your queue jumping problem solved. Do not punish refugees in the process.

I made a comment, which obviously generated some sensitive reaction from people, that what is proposed here bears some very strong similarities to what the One Nation Party proposed prior to the last election. I think perhaps there was some misunderstanding amongst some senators that One Nation's policy was for a five-year temporary visa and then you are out compulsorily, no questions asked. Far be it from me to try to explain and sell One Nation's refugee policy, because I attacked it then and I will attack it now. But as Senator Harris outlined, that is a misunderstanding. The fundamental nature of it was to only give people temporary visas, to only give people temporary asylum. The underlying principle was that they cannot expect to come here and be able to be accepted in the Australian community. That was criticised very widely by all partiesâquite rightly, in my viewâincluding by the media, by a large number of organisations, and by the minister, Mr Ruddock, who back in 1998 said it was quite inappropriate to suggest that refugees' presence here should only be temporary. One wonders what has changed now.

I think what has changed now is that One Nation is no longer a threat, politically, at the moment. At that time it may have been appropriate for the government to distance itself from what they were doing and say that it was inappropriate. But now it says: `Now that One Nation is much more diminished in impact, that political ground is there for the taking again. Let's move back in there, let's grab all that stuff. Wonderful!' That is clearly what is happening.

Whilst the Democrats have greater numbers in this parliament than One Nation, we nonetheless clearly have a smaller party status than the major parties. We always like to get more votes, more seats, but sometimes you cannot get that. The other way you measure your success is through getting your policies adopted by governments of the day, through getting your policies recognised and taken on board. Sure, One Nation did not win many seats, and they were disappointed about that, but the next best thing is getting your policies and the principles underlying them taken on board, and that is what they have achieved. So much as it saddens me to say it, I say congratulations to One Nation, because they have succeeded in getting their policy principles taken on board and adopted by both the two major parties in this place.

We have had the red herring about the terrible costs to the Australian taxpayer of all these boat people coming in. Yet we are the only country in the world that insists on imprisoning, detaining, every illegal immigrant, at enormous cost to the Australian taxpayer; that is a self-inflicted cost by this government. Now we are compounding it by putting a double assessment procedure on them. We will assess these people not once but twice. And there is the suggestion that somehow or other this is going to make things cheaper.

Other speakers have indicated, if we are trying to put things into perspective, that the number of illegal migrants that are in Australia now is over 50,000. We do not have that figure thrown around in the papers, saying that there are hoards of illegal immigrants all over the place, stealing our jobs. The majority of themâfrom the UK, the US and Europeâare overstayers. Somehow or other that is not a threat to our social fabric, not a national emergency, not on the Richter scale, or whatever the minister was going on about, in relation to a couple of thousand boat people.

Let's be real about this stuff. Senator Patterson talked about how people should come through appropriate and recognised meansâanother euphemism for playing by the rules, doing things the right way, stopping people from jumping the queue. I have to remind the government that the means by which these people come hereâon boats, without authorisationâto gain the protection of Australia is a means of getting protection recognised by the UNHCRâthe mob that you keep trying to say is supportive of what you are doing. It is recognised by the UNHCR as an appropriate means. That is why we have an obligation to offer that protection. If it were not appropriate, we would not have an obligation.

So stop trying to suggest that one way is okay and the other is not playing by the rules: `You are second-class, you should not be here, and we are only doing a minimum for you.' The principle that is being adopted here is that this is a race to the bottom: `We have got to make ourselves as unattractive as possible to people. We have got to treat them as badly as we can. We have to scrape along the bottom of the barrel and still sneak in through the UN convention so that people will not come here.' What a message to send! If other countries around the world adopt that principle, that will really make for a much less humane planet in the 21st century, with all of us trying to out-compete each other to see how unattractive a place we can be for people that are trying to seek some shelter and safety.

There are multitudes more people going to other countries than are coming here, yet we still have this government trying to pretend that we are a soft touch and that everybody else is tougher than us: `Poor little victim Australia, rolling over and letting these nasty queue jumpers sneak in and take advantage of our really kind heart.'

On my understanding, from information provided by people who have worked with some of the arrivals in recent times, the priceâI would call it an extortion amountâthat people are being required to pay by people smugglers to try to save their lives, to try to escape persecutionâ

talk.start.para: âYou are assisting them.

âThere we go. The government could not resist: `Here are the Democrats assisting the people smugglers.' You can't help trying to suggest that anybody who stands up for the rights of people that are the most disadvantaged on the planet are somehow or other helping the criminals. Get a grip! Stop saying this sort of rubbish. How about having an honest debate, a civilised debate. Be reasonable for a change. We are trying to stand up for people that you are trying to crush for some cheap political point, and somehow you want to say that we are supporting the people smugglers. These people charge a cheaper price to come to Australia and Europe. How come we are cheaper if we are the soft touch? What a joke!

speech.para: It is quite ironic that the coalition that likes to talk about rewarding enterprise attacking views of envy of people who have got a bit of dough. Somehow or other it is terrible if people have a bit of money and they try to use that money to save their lives, to save their families. I have got news for you: if someone wants to shoot you in the head, it doesn't really matter whether you have got a few bucks in the bank; the bullet still goes through your brain and you still die.

It is ridiculous to somehow or other suggest that people sit back, go through some brochure and say, `Where will we go to save our lives? Maybe Australia; maybe the UK. I don't know. What do you reckon, love?' The impression you are trying to create is that they sit around the table and discuss it like some sort of holiday shopping exercise. It is so false, and it is disgraceful that you try to generate that sort of thing. You have the minister talking about refugees getting off a boat and asking for shampoo. How terrible! Imagine getting off a boat after you have been sitting on it for weeks and asking for some shampoo. I would like to wash my hair as well if I had been sitting on a boat for two weeks or for months at a time. Somehow or other, this is meant to portray that they are just a pampered bourgeoisie mob sailing around the world on some luxury liner and that they roll up here and say, `Yes, we're here. Give me my Pert. Give me my free medical treatment, you soft touch Aussies.' What a joke!

This measure has been criticised widely by the people who work in the real world with the people who have to endure the sort of persecution that many of these boat people are fleeing. We have had mention of Amnesty International, the Refugee Council of Australia, South Brisbane Immigration and Community Legal Service, the Council of Vietnamese Refugee Supporting Organisations, the Ethnic Community Council of New South Wales, the Ethnic Community Council of Queensland, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, and the Refugee Claimant Support Centre. The Jesuit Refugee Service with Father Frank Brennan is well known in its assessment of human rights. ACOSS and Welfare Rights have pointed out the problem of the government providing access to only inadequate income support.

There are plenty of people who know what this is going to mean. Unfortunately, we have had the Labor Party saying that they are not falling for this political trick. I can understand the politics of this too. I get the phone calls. I hear the talkback radio. They are saying that the government can live with this measure, and they will have to live with the fact that it is not going to work. Well, that is good! Unfortunately, the people who are really going to have to live with it are the refugees. They are the ones who are going to have to work with it.

Look at what we are doing to ourselves as a country. Everybody knows, and it has been said, that they will get a three-year temporary visa. A handful at the end of those three years would be likely to go back to their country of origin. What happens in the meantime? We are making it harder for them to get work. They will have inadequate income support. They will not be able to get education. They will not get access to refugee settlement services. We are going to have these people in limbo for three years, separated from their families. Chances are, quite possibly with many of them, that they will lose touch with them for good. Some of those people have wives and kids in some of those places and, given the places that they are in, it is quite feasible that they could easily be killed.

People have already been through trauma, we put them through this extra trauma and then, at the end of three years, we will say, `Okay, you can stay.' That is really productive! It is really smart to have people who are already traumatised hanging in limbo and hovering around the Australian community for three years before we will say, `Okay, you're here for good now. You're all right. We'll give you a bit of help now.' What has happened to them in three years? You do not have to be Einstein to read and understand all the research into trauma and the impact that has on people in terms of enabling them to get on with their lives and to integrate into the Australian community. We are going to make it 10 times worse for them. We talked about cost before: we will increase the cost. The cost is going to be on the Australian community from trying to pick up the pieces after three years of extra trauma inflicted by Australia, which is ridiculous.

Laurie Oakes indicated in his Bulletin article todayâand I think it was a very insightful article, as is often the caseâthat Labor has, as Labor members have said themselves, realised that this is not going to be effective in countering people smuggling operations. Of course it is not. The article says:
By the same token, though, it does not see anything particularly immoral or dangerous about it.

That is the one line in Laurie's article that is wrong. This is clearly immoral and a very dangerous precedent. It is clearly going to cause enormous pain. Labor has just decided that it did not want to give the government a stick to beat it about the head with, and I can understand that.

But I do say, without trying to sound noble and idealistic, that sometimes you do have to stand up and be a voice for those who are amongst the most disadvantaged. If this means the Democrats are giving the government a stick, does the minister wield it already, saying we are supporting people smugglers? Well, beat me over the head with that stick for as long as you like, because I am still going to support these people and I am still going to speak out for them. You might want to sit there and say, `You're getting tough,' but, as I said before, there is nothing too tough about kicking the most vulnerable people when they are down. That is not tough. It is gutless and pathetic, and the Democrats are not going to be part of it.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Bartlett's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: âLast Sunday I was privileged to attend the opening of a very special house for recovering substance abusers in suburban Adelaide. The house is a former Housing Trust property and was generously made available by the Hon. Dean Brown, the Minister for Human Services in South Australia. I would like to take this opportunity to thank him for his support in this initiative. I am the voluntary Chair of the Australian Drug Treatment and Rehabilitation program, which assists with the administration of the house.

speech.para: The house's opening on Sunday was particularly significant for all of us. It is committed to providing the best possible care for those addicted to drugs and provides a supportive environment for those who want to live drug free. We currently have more than a dozen young men and women who are rebuilding their lives with the support of a dedicated team of professionals and volunteers. In words and in song, some of these people told their stories at the opening ceremony in simple yet moving messages of great relevance to the wider community.

There is no doubt that, as a society, we need to better understand that individuals addicted to drugs may also be our daughters, our sons, our brothers, our sisters, our mothers, our fathers, our relatives and our friends. We now know that to abandon these usually young men and women to their addiction deprives them of the opportunity to contribute to our society in a far more meaningful way. It also leaves them open to a high risk lifestyle, facing both health hazards and the inevitable entry into a life of crime, with the subsequent terms of imprisonment and everything that follows from such a deprivation of personal freedom.

The Prime Minister's announcement last week of the diversion program is another valuable step in our Tough on Drugs initiative. It recognises that, for the first time, offenders who have not offended before can have the opportunity of treatment and education, which is indeed preferable to falling victim to the tangles of the criminal justice system. Together with the additional funding for education initiatives announced today by Minister David Kemp, this government is recognising that there are no simple solutions to this very complicated issue.

South Australia will use its share of the $4 million additional funds announced today to contribute to state funding and implement a whole school community approach supported by professional development for teachers. Implemented just a few years ago, these initiatives would have been of great assistance to some of the residents at our house of hope. Its establishment is a tribute to the work of Ann Bressington, a dedicated and tireless advocate for a fresh approach to the challenge of education and treatment for substance abusers.

This house is named for her daughter, Shay Louise Bressington, who was tragically defeated by heroin but whose spirit lives on in the enthusiasm and courage of the residents who took part in our ceremony last Sunday. Each of our young people at Shay Louise House are on the naltrexone program to assist in their recovery, but they and we know that taking a pill every morning is only one aspect of the life building program that they are engaged in.

Relief and rehabilitation from substance abuse require a multifaceted approach. There is no right or wrong path. It is simply a case of different strokes for different folks. But I must say that the current cost of naltrexone tablets of around $250 a month makes life pretty difficult for many of the young people resident in our house. Rehabilitation centres such Shay Louise House and the variety of policies offered by the federal government's drug strategy recognise that flexibility in treatment against a background of support for the individual and their family offers the best chance of success. As our dedicated counsellor and colleague Peg told the gathering on Sunday, our clients are a little like roses. Eventually, some of them have the most beautiful flowers, despite the thorns we see on their bare branches when they arrive. These young people, like the rose bushes, need a safe, warm and caring environment, the right amount of nurturing and the chance to grow and fully take their place in the wider community. Shay Louise House is the first in a series of rehabilitation centres that we hope to establish around Adelaide to offer hope and healing to some members of our society who need it most.

talk.start.para: âI am rising tonightâand, indeed, I intended to make this contribution last night, but the adjournment collapsed before those involved were able to reach the chamberâto respond to a press release from Senator Abetz which was prepared and distributed to the media yesterday and got a scant amount of coverage, as I understand it, today.
âYou are going to give it some publicity, are you?

âI will give it some publicity, Senator, and I am sure that you will thank me when I am finished. In his press release Senator Abetz said, amongst other things, that, in relation to what he interpreted would be our vote on the message from the House of Representatives and the resolution that the Senate not insist on its amendments, our position would be to insist on our amendmentsâwhich indeed we did, so he was correct. He said:

speech.para: Labor are prepared to sell out Tasmanian workers and Tasmania's timber communities. Fifteen percent of Tasmanians rely on the forests for their employment.
He went on:
Labor's federal representation has been useless. They have achieved nothing for Tasmania in this debate.

Let me tell you what the reality of the debate and the vote has been. The RFA legislation has been passed in the Senate chamber and it was passed with amendments. Labor voted for the third reading of the legislation. Senator Abetz knows this and I challenge him to say that this is not true. But later in his press release, the position that Senator Abetz put to the media in Tasmania was this:
Now Tasmania's Labor Senators are to follow this example of betrayal by voting down the legislation in the Senate.

That is an absolute untruth and Senator Abetz, under the Prime Minister's code of conduct, has to get to his typewriter, get a press release out and withdraw this absolute untruth. This is misleading, and either Senator Abetz unintentionally misledâin which case, he had better get out and withdraw his commentsâor he intentionally misled, and the consequences of that are obvious: he should resign.
Senator Abetz interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Abetz may well laugh, but the reality of the position that Senator Abetz has takenâa position also taken by his colleague Mrs Napier, the Liberal Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, and Mr Barry Chipman from the Forest Protection Societyâis to hold Tasmania to ransom over the question of the RFA in Western Australia. Senator Abetz knows, as do Mrs Napier and Barry Chipman, that the amendments made to the RFA legislationâas Labor insisted on yesterdayâprotect the RFA in Tasmania. He knows that, as do Mrs Napier and Mr Chipman. However, they are holding Tasmania to ransom; they are holding a gun to the head of the timber industry in Tasmania to protect the Western Australian timber industry. It has nothing to do with Tasmania, but he has the gall to mislead the Tasmanian public and to try to pretend that Labor voted against the RFA legislation. That is an absolute untruth and he knows it. In terms of Mr Chipman's position, I have spoken to him on a number of occasions about this. Let me say, frankly, that Mr Chipman understands our position and he has conceded that he understands it. He understands that we have effectively enshrined in our amendments a tick for the Tasmanian RFA. Understanding that, the position that he put back to me was that, on the basis of solidarity with the Western Australian timber workers, the Forest Protection Society was not supporting Labor's amendments.

speech.para: Let us not then have Mr Chipman going to the media, as he did in Tasmania yesterday, and saying that the RFA legislation has become political, because what he is doing is taking a political position not on the basis of the interests of the Tasmanian timber industry but on the basis of the interests, as he and perhaps his organisation perceive them, of timber workers in Western Australia.

What of the Western Australian RFA? This is a document that has been signed up to by a Liberal government. The fact is that Premier Court now wants to withdraw and step back from the RFA. He wants it redrafted; he wants changes. Of course, Mr Tuckey, the federal minister, does not want those changes. The game that is being played is one of holding a gun to the heads of the timber workers in Tasmaniaâand to the heads of those in Gippsland and the Central Highlands in Victoria; to the heads of the Queensland timber workers, where there is an RFA ready to go; and to the heads of those in New South Walesâto prop up an RFA that even the Western Australian Liberal government does not want. That is what this game is about.

Senator Abetz has misrepresented Labor's position by saying that we are voting down the legislation. But I stress again: we voted for this bill at the third reading but insisted on our amendments which protect the position of the Tasmanian RFA. I understand that Senator Abetz has put the nonsense argument that in our provisions there is some legal deficiency which exempts the Tasmanian RFA from a disallowance provision. The fact of the matter is that, when that matter was argued in this chamber, Senator Troeth, who was here to put the case, did not even bother to argue it.

But if we were to assume that somehow there is some validity to that legal deficiency argumentâan argument that the government was not even prepared to put in the committee stageâwhat would happen if the Tasmanian RFA were to be subject to disallowance? Senator Abetz knows that the Labor Party will be supporting it, so the only way that it would go down is if the government were to oppose it. Is Senator Abetz saying that the government would support a disallowance motion moved perhaps by Senator Brown or by the Democrats? Let us speculate for the sake of it. The only way that the Tasmanian RFA could be disallowed would be if Labor and the government were not to vote togetherâand Labor has already committed to the Tasmanian RFA. So, if it is in danger, it is only in danger because Senator Abetz is going to vote against it.

Senator Abetz has had the gall to say that Labor senators voted down this legislation. That is an absolute untruth. I will say again that it is an obligation on the senator who holds a frontbench position with the government to correctâ

talk.start.para: âWell, sit down and let him get up and talk.
âHe is not next, as a matter of fact; Senator Woodley is next.

speech.para: Senator Lightfoot interjectingâ
