âEarlier today Senator Faulkner made a personal explanation concerning Margo Kingston's article on the front page of today's Sydney Morning Herald . He attacked the article and also stated that the vote on Labor's amendment to Senator Greig's same sex amendment to the standing orders was unanimous.

speech.para: At the time I was unclear about that point and said that I wanted to check with Senator Greig. So I took the opportunity to bookmark the debate. This may have left the impression that I and the Australian Democrats supported the substance of what Senator Faulkner was saying. Senator Greig has confirmed with me that the vote on Labor's amendment was not supported by the Democrats, as Senator Greig, on behalf of our party, spoke strongly against it, as shown in Hansard; he called no when the Labor amendment was put. The essence of Ms Kingston's article was that the Australian Labor Party had abandoned the cause of minority rights in this country.
Senator Chris Evans interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou can check the Hansard , Senator Evans.
âYou are confused. He was talking about the procedures committee.
âOrder! Senator Evans, you are out of your seat.

âThe matters raised by Margo Kingston clearly document the now growing catalogue where Labor fails to rise to the challenge of sticking up for the underdog. In that regard, I draw attention to the previous debate on refugees. The essence of Ms Kingston's article was that the Australian Labor Party has abandoned this cause. This remained a cruel financial penalty for a young associate, although at least one State regularly `forgot' to send its account.
And we will not name that one. It continued:

WA justified its inclusion immediately by winning the trophy in its very first season, its top position being determined by percentage. WA came into its own in the 1970s, well after New South Wales had set a Shield record by winning the Shield nine times in a row from 1953/54. The Westerners won the Shield 10 times in 18 seasons from 1971/72.

The Sheffield Shield is something that not only is inextricably bound to our culture of sport in Western Australia but binds us together with the other states. It has often been said that Western Australia is not particularly enamoured of a lot of things that come from the east, but cricket holds it together. How dare a milk company change the name of the Sheffield Shield! How dare the Australian Cricket Board assent to that name for a fistful of dollars! There has got to be something better in sport than just money. Sport, by its very nature, by its definition, is above money. It is above purchase.

Surely the Australian Cricket Board when they made this decision could have been a little more subtle about what they did. Take the Fosters Melbourne Cup, for instance. While I would have preferred the `Melbourne Cup' or the `Australian Melbourne Cup', it kept the Melbourne Cup name alive. Even as appalling as I find Coca-Cola when associated with the Australian Football League, at least we kept the AFL included in that name. Here we have a milk company that thinks it can take the place of the Sheffield Shield. It was not only commercially stupid but naive on the part of Mr Speed, the CEO and chairman of the Australian Cricket Board, to do such a thing.
What is next to go? Are the Ashes going to go? Is that the last we are going to hear of the Ashes? Is the baggy green cap going to go? Is that the same? Is that for sale as well?

The SCG, the WACA, the MCG, the Adelaide Oval and the Gabbaâare all of those for sale? I am appalled. I am genuinely and sincerely appalled that a milk company could think it can take over what is an icon in sport, particularly for Western Australians. We look forward to the Sheffield Shield. We look forward to the competition that we play with the eastern states. I think we are going to hear some more about this.

In conclusion, may I say that, had it not been for the Sheffield Shield, Western Australia would not have the best domestic team in Australia. Were it not for the Sheffield Shield, we would not have two fine young cricketers from Western Australia who are responsible for winning the test. So not only do we have the best domestic team in Australia; we have residing in Western Australia those responsible for the winning of the test and also the one-day events. Lord Sheffield must be turning in his grave at the thought of what has happenedâit is one of the most appalling things to have happened in the history of Australia.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to have the opportunity this evening to correct the quite misleading assertions made by Senator Kerry O'Brien to the Senate during the adjournment debate this evening. Those listening to this broadcast and honourable senators would have been given a particular impression in relation to my media release. I intend in the time remaining to read it out and then highlight the deficiencies of Labor's argument. Senator O'Brien in fact failed to read out in detail the full media release. For example, he said that I had said that he had voted down the legislation. In fact, I said:

speech.para: Today, Labor senators will complete Labor's act of betrayal by voting for amendments which would drive the axe through the legislation.
But allow me to read the whole media release:
The refusal by Labor to support the regional forest agreement legislation was a sell-out of all Tasmanian timber communities, Tasmanian Liberal Senator Eric Abetz said today.
He says it again now. The press release continued:

The regional forest agreement legislation will be before the Senate again today. Labor is committed to join with the Democrats and Greens senators to vote down this legislation which would enshrine regional forest agreements in legislation and thus provide certainty, investments and jobs.

On this point, if I can digress, the Labor Partyâalbeit they tried to get Tasmania out of it somehow, which was legally impossibleâwanted the Senate to be able to vote down and disallow each agreement, thus getting rid of the certainty which the timber industry so desperately needs. The press release goes on:

Senator Abetz said at a time when Tasmanians need every sustainable job and certainty, Labor are prepared to sell our Tasmanian workers and Tasmania's timber communities. Fifteen per cent of Tasmanians rely on the forests for their employment. Labor's federal representation has been useless. They have achieved nothing for Tasmania in this debate. Jim Bacon has had no sway over Kim Beazley on this fundamental issue. All Tasmanians need to know that every federal Labor member voted against jobs and certainty for our timber communities, Senator Abetz said. Today Labor senators will complete Labor's act of betrayal by voting for amendments which would drive the axe through the legislation. We have bipartisan support in the Tasmanian parliament. We have industry and trade union support. The only groups opposed are the extreme Greens and that is with whom Sid Sidebottom, Michelle O'Byrne, Dick Adams, Harry Quick and Duncan Kerr have sided. Now Tasmania's Labor senators are to follow this example of betrayal by voting down the legislation in the Senate, Senator Abetz said.

talk.start.para: âAre you going to withdraw that?
âNo, you did vote down the guts of the legislation and that is why it is not going to beâ
âThe guts of it.
âAbsolutely. The release continued:

speech.para: Tasmania and the Commonwealth government signed a regional forest agreement with bipartisan support. The agreement was enshrined in legislation to be put before the state and Commonwealth parliaments. Tasmania carried its legislation on a bipartisan basis. We were naively hopeful that federal Labor would do the same.

We know that the vote that occurred in the Senate today has occasioned great embarrassment for Labor's federal representatives. During the break that we have just had from the sittings, Dick Adams, Michelle O'Byrne and Sid Sidebottom were sneaking around the forest protection society groups within Tasmania saying, `Dear, oh dear, oh dear, we have been trying to get federal Labor to vote the way you want us to, but we cannot get the others to agree to it.' They have gone around Tasmania basically saying, `We tried our best but we failed. Please vote for us again at the next election.'

Senator O'Brien well knows that his Premier, Jim Bacon, and his Deputy Premier, Paul Lennon, appeared before the Senate committee looking into this legislation urging the federal Labor Party and indeed the Senate to support the legislation without amendment. The trade union movement wanted federal Labor to do the same. Industry wanted you to do the same. The Forest Protection Society wanted you to do the same. The Tasmanian Parliamentary Labor Party wanted you to do the same. The Tasmanian Parliamentary Liberal Party wanted you to do the same. And you, the opposition, for your own political reasons, decided to side with the Greens and the Democrats. Is it not amazing that the one Tasmanian Labor senator who had a background in the forestry union, Senator Shayne Murphy, was absent from the vote.

talk.start.para: âWhere is he?
âHe is fly-fishing, Senator McGauran. At the time when the forest workers of Tasmania needed Senator Shayne Murphy in the Senate he was overseas fly-fishing. Is that correct, Senator O'Brien?

speech.para: Senator O'Brien interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âAddress the chair, thank you, Senator Abetz.

âSenator O'Brien, as opposition whip, might like to tell us why Senator Murphy was not with us. At the time when you would have thought that Senator Shayne Murphy would have been in the Senate to vote for this, he was unfortunately absent.

speech.para: The one thing that Senator O'Brien simply cannot overcome is the fact that federal members Dick Adams, Michelle O'Byrne and Sid Sidebottom in particular have been going around Tasmania saying to timber communities and forest protection societies, `We did our best.' Dick Adams has been reported in the newspapers in Tasmania as saying that he was lobbying hard in Canberra for the timber industry. What has been the result? One big monumental failure because he has not been able to achieveâ
Senator Chris Evans interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Chris Evans interjects and says `Five Labor seats.' He is showing all the arrogance that comes before a defeat. I have never taken the Tasmanian community for granted. That is why I work so hard for them. That is why when a forestry debate is on you will not find me overseas fly-fishing but you will see me trying to do the very best for the Tasmanian people.

speech.para: At the last election, the people of Tasmania were promised a bipartisan approach to forestry and this issue. I am sure that, if Dick Adams, Michelle O'Byrne and Sid Sidebottom had gone to the last federal election saying, `By the way, we will be moving amendments to gut the regional forest agreement legislation,' then definitely Michelle O'Byrne would not be the federal member for Bass.

talk.start.para: âBut she is.
âBecause she did not have the integrity to tell the people of Bass what the Labor Party would be doing on this important issue. There will have to be a lot of explaining by these people.
âDo us a favour and run for Bass.
âHave you quite finished, Senator Chris Evans?
âSenator Abetz, address the chair and ignore the interjections from Senator Evans.
âMadam Deputy President, with respect, I thought part of your role might also be quite correctlyâ
âAnd do not reflect upon the chair, thank you.

âI am allowed to raise issues. One of them is that, whilst it is quite correct for you to bring me to order, I would have thought it appropriate for you to encourage colleagues on your side to not interject. But if that is reflecting on the chair, I will not make that request.

âSenator Abetz, the person in the chair does not take sides. I have been calling both sides to order when they have been unruly. I would appreciate it if you would address the chair and I would appreciate it if Senator Evans and Senator O'Brien would cease and desist from interjecting.
âThe people of Tasmania will be reminded about Labor's voting pattern.

With reference to the effect of the goods and services tax (GST) on the internal operations of the Minister's portfolio (that is, not relating to the services provided to the public), and in relation to each of the agencies within the portfolio:

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs: Departmental Decisions Reviewed under the Administrative Decisions Act
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1447)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 21 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Since 3 March 1996, how many decisions of the department and all portfolio agencies have been the subject of applications for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.
(2) Of these applications, how many related to: (a) agency staffing matters; (b) agency client matters; or (c) other (please specify general area).
(3) How many applications: (a) have been: (i) finalised, and (ii) withdrawn by the applicant; and (b) remain unfinalised.
(4) (a) What was the cost to the department or agency of defending each of these actions; and (b) what was the quantum of costs where they were awarded against the Commonwealth, where appropriate.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Education, Training & Youth Affairs (DETYA) current portfolio responsibilities came into existence on 21 October 1998. From 3 March 1996 until 20 October 1998 this Department's portfolio responsibilities were included within those of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA). The records of DEETYA indicate that from 3 March 1996 until 20 October 1998 two DEETYA decisions were the subject of applications for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. One of these matters was finalised prior to 21 October 1998 and the other subsequently became the portfolio responsibility of the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business as from 21 October 1998.

This Department's records show that from 21 October 1998 to 21 September 1999 no decisions of the Department have been the subject of applications for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.
Departmental Agencies

. The Anglo-Australian Telescope Board (AATB) is an independent bi-national authority equally funded by the governments of Australia and the United Kingdom under the Anglo-Australian Telescope Agreement Act 1970). AATB is a body corporate capable of suing and being sued in its corporate name. AATB has advised that from 3 March 1996 until 21 September 1999 none of its decisions have been the subject of applications for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

. The Australian Maritime College (AMC) is an autonomous national institution for tertiary education set up under the Maritime College Act 1978). AMC has been within the portfolio responsibilities of the Department of Transport and Regional Services since 21 October 1998. AMC is a body corporate capable of suing and being sued in its corporate name. AMC has advised that from 3 March 1996 until 21 October 1998 none of its decisions have been the subject of applications for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

. The Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) is an autonomous body established under the Australian National Training Authority Act 1999 and run by an industry-led board. ANTA is a body corporate capable of suing and being sued in its corporate name. ANTA has advised that none of its decisions have been the subject of applications for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 between 3 March 1996 and 21 September 1999.

. The Australian National University (ANU) is an autonomous institution under the Australian National University Act 1991. ANU is a body corporate capable of suing and being sued in its corporate name. ANU has advised that one of its decisions has been the subject of an application for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 between 3 March 1996 to 21 September 1999.

. The Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA) was established under the Employment Services Act 1994. ESRA is a body corporate capable of suing and being sued in its corporate name. ESRA has been within the portfolio responsibilities of the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business from 21 October 1998. The records of DEETYA for the period from 3 March 1996 to 20 October 1998 indicate that no decisions of ESRA were the subject of applications for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 between 3 March 1996 and 20 October 1998.

. The National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) was established under the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988). A Bill to abolish NBEET is currently before the Senate (Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999). The records of DEETYA (for the period from 3 March 1996 to 20 October 1998) and of this Department (for the period from 21 October 1998 to 21 September 1999) indicate that no decisions of NBEET were the subject of applications for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 between 3 March 1996 and 21 September 1999.

. The University of Canberra (UC) was established pursuant to the University of Canberra Act 1989. The Government of the Australian Capital Territory assumed jurisdiction for UC from 1 December 1997. UC is a body corporate capable of suing and being sued in its corporate name. UC has advised that none of its decisions have been the subject of applications for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 between 3 March 1996 and 31 November 1997.
(2) With respect to the Department, the application finalised prior to 21 October 1998 and referred to in (1) above related to a Departmental staffing matter.
With respect to portfolio agencies, ANU has advised that the application referred to in (1) above related to a staffing matter.

(3) With respect to the Department, the application finalised prior to 21 October 1998 and referred to in (1) above has been finalised and was decided in DEETYA's favour by the Federal Court of Australia. The records of DEETYA up to 21 October 1998 and of this Department from 21 October 1998 show that no other applications have been withdrawn by applicants or remain unfinalised.
With respect to portfolio agencies, ANU has advised that the application referred to in (1) above has been finalised.

(4) With respect to the Department, the total cost to the Department of defending the action finalised prior to 21 October 1998 and referred to in (1) above was $8,298.16. This includes the cost of DEETYA's own lawyers in relation to matters pertaining to the claim, as well as the cost of outside legal providers. The Federal Court of Australia decided the action in the Commonwealth's favour and no costs were awarded against the Commonwealth.

With respect to portfolio agencies, ANU has advised that its legal costs of defending the action referred to in (1) above was $35,786.73 and that, in addition, it voluntarily paid $5,000.00 towards the applicant's legal costs. ANU has also advised that the action was decided in its favour by the Full Court of the Federal Court and that costs were not awarded against it.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: Freedom of Information Requests
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1489)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 21 September 1999:

question.para: (1) What are the: (a) formal qualifications; (b) relevant experience; and (c) employment classification/grade, of each departmental officer who has made initial stage decisions regarding requests under the Freedom of Information Act since 3 March 1996.

(2) What are the: (a) formal qualifications; (b) relevant experience; and (c) employment classification/grade, of each departmental officer who has made internal review decisions regarding requests under the Freedom of Information Act since 3 March 1996.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Freedom of Information Act does not stipulate any particular formal qualifications, experience, or employment classifications for decision makers, and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) therefore does not maintain such statistics in relation to FOI requests. ATSIC considers that it would require an unwarranted diversion of resources to provide the detail requested in relation to every request since 3 March 1996.

However, as required under section 23 of the FOI Act, ATSIC has in place an Instrument of Arrangements which authorises nominated officers to make decisions in respect of FOI requests. Initial stage decisions must be made at Executive 2 level or above, generally by officers having administrative or policy responsibility for the documents sought. Only senior executives are authorised to make decisions on applications for internal review.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission List of Savings
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1572)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: Is the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) going to provide a revised listing of the savings that taxpayers will obtain from the implementation of the goods and services tax.

talk.start.para: âThe Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The ACCC has not issued a list of savings that taxpayers will obtain from the implementation of the goods and services tax. The ACCC will monitor price changes to identify sectors that may not be passing through the benefits of the New Tax System changes.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Insurance Premium Increases
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1582)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Government aware that insurance companies will soon start increasing premiums as a result of the goods and services tax (GST).

(2) Given that both HIH Insurance and AMP recently provided for $76 million in abnormal costs due to the GST (HIH $50 million and AMP $26 million), and given that the Government has estimated that the cost effect for the insurance industry will be a $40 million decrease and for services to finance, investment and insurance, a decrease of $710 million, why then should insurance companies be making a provision in their accounts for GST-related costs.

(3) Will the Government support the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission action being taken against those insurance companies that seek to pass on GST-related costs through higher insurance premiums.
(4) Does the Government concede that the GST will add to insurer's costs, thus necessitating GST-induced premium increases; if not why not.

(5) Will the Government be reviewing the GST legislation as is applies to insurers to allow them to claim input tax credits for insurance claims made before 30 June 2000 but where the settlement of the claim is not made until after 30 June 2000.

(6) Why did the Government not adopt the New Zealand (NZ) model that applied to the NZ insurance industry regarding the transitional treatment of input tax credits in regards to the pre- and post GST systems.

talk.start.para: âThe Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Insurers will be required to remit GST on insurance services provided after 1 July 2000.

(2) Tax reform will remove many of the taxes that insurers currently bear on their business inputs, such as wholesale sales tax and Financial Institutions Duty. The GST will provide operating cost reductions to general insurers since they will be eligible for input tax credits on most of their business inputs.
(3) The Government supports the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission taking action against any business that changes prices in a manner inconsistent with the effects of tax reform.
(4) See (2) above.

(5) GST is applied to the margin of insurers by taxing premiums and providing input tax credits on payouts. Insurers will receive input tax credits on insurance policies on which GST has been paid. Since GST has not been charged on policies providing cover before 1 July 2000, insurers will not be entitled to input tax on credits on events occurring before this date.
(6) See (5) above.

subdebateinfo.title: Export Market Development Grants: Educational Institutions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1633)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 28 September 1999.

question.para: With reference to educational institutions that operate under the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991:

(1) Can a list be provided of educational institutions which have received Export Market Development Grants since 30 June 1997, including information by institution on: (a) Australian Council for Private Education and Training (ACPET) membership; (b) the reason for the grant; (c) the amount of funds applied for; (d) the actual amount of the grant received; (e) the date the grant was given; and (f) details of any departmental evaluation of the effectiveness of the grant.

(2) Can a list be provided of all unsuccessful Export Market Development grant applications from educational institutions since 30 June 1997, including information on: (a) ACPET membership; (b) the reason given for the grant application; (c) the amount applied for; (d) the date of application; and (e) the departmental rationale for rejecting the grant application.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Education, Training & Youth Affairs (DETYA) does not hold this infor-

mation. The Australian Trade Commission (Austrade) has provided a list of educational institutions that have received Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) since 30 June 1997. Annexure A includes the details of those institutions registered on the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS), which have received a EMDG.
(a) Included in Annexure A are those educational institutions that, according to DETYA's records are members of the Australian Council for Private Education and Training.
(b) Austrade has advised us that the reason for grants is for reimbursement of eligible export market development expenses as authorised by the EMDG Act 1997.

(c) The disclosure by Austrade of the information requested is restricted under the provisions of Section 94 of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985. Under the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985, Austrade is only able to provide information on:
1. "the name & address of a person to whom the Commission has authorised a payment;
2.the amount of a GRANT to a person; and
3.the industry to which a grant relates".
The value of the grant paid to the recipients may vary from the amount of funds applied for.
These amounts are recorded in Annexure A.
(d) Austrade has provided the information recorded in Annexure A.
(e) Austrade is only able to advise the year in which the grant was given. This information is recorded in Annexure A.
(f) Austrade has advised that details of departmental evaluations of the effectiveness of grants are restricted under the provisions of Section 94 of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985.

(2) The Australian Trade Commission Act 1985 (as amended), paragraph 94 (b) provides for the release of information concerning persons who have received EMDG payments from the Commission, not applicants or unsuccessful applicants. The detail able to be provided relating to payments under the EMDG Act 1974 & 1997 is restricted to:
1. "the name & address of a person to whom the Commission has authorised a payment;
2. the amount of a GRANT to a person; and
3. the industry to which a grant relates".
ANNEXURE A

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 30 September 1999.

question.para: With reference to educational institutions which operated under the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 and the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students:
(1) How many colleges is the department aware of that have significant problems with student non-attendance or poor attendance.
(2) What is the department's view of the current level of acceptable non-attendance.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Education, Training & Youth Affairs (DETYA) does not maintain this information. However, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) has advised that as well as receiving anecdotal reports, they also receive reports from individual providers themselves on non attendance of students. The meaningfulness of such reports in indicating providers considered to have significant non attendance problems needs to be treated with caution as some are more vigilant than others in making these reports. In this light DIMA regional offices advise that approximately 20 colleges are considered to have problems with non-attendance of students over this period.
(2) The standards of acceptable attendance have been set by DIMA and in accordance with condition 8202 of the Migration Regulations which applies to all student visas, are as follows:
"The holder must:
(a) be enrolled in a registered course; and
(b) attend at least 80% of the classes and tutorials scheduled for the course, as evidenced by records of attendance of the education provider or otherwise; and
(c) if attendance cannot be evidenced, achieve an academic result for the course that is certified by the education provider to be at least satisfactory; and
(d) comply with any requirement of the education provider in relation to payment of fees for the course."
